fields: The {{c1::calvaria}} is the dome-shaped roof of the skull that protects the superior aspect of the brain.
The calvaria includes the frontal, parietal, and occipital bones.
The {{c1::parietal bone}} forms part of the sides and roof of the cranial cavity.
The {{c1::frontal bone}} forms the forehead and the roof of the orbits.
The {{c1::occipital bone}} forms the posterior and inferior portions of the skull.
The {{c1::coronal suture}} is located between the frontal and parietal bones.
The {{c1::sagittal suture}} is located between the paired parietal bones.
The {{c1::lambdoid suture}} is located between the parietal and occipital bones.
The {{c1::bregma}} is the point where the coronal and sagittal sutures meet.
The {{c1::lambda}} is the point where the lambdoid and sagittal sutures meet.
The {{c1::frontal crest}} serves as attachment point for the {{c2::falx cerebri}}.
The falx cerebri is a dural fold that separates the cerebral hemispheres.
The {{c1::groove for the superior sagittal sinus}} is a prominent groove running along the midline of the cranial cavity's roof.
This groove accommodates the superior sagittal sinus, a major venous sinus of the brain.
{{c1::Granular foveolae}} are small pits and depressions marking the location of arachnoid granulations.
Arachnoid granulations are involved in the reabsorption of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
The anterior fontanelle is located where the {{c1::frontal}} and {{c1::parietal}} bones meet.
It is diamond-shaped and typically closes between 7 and 19 months after birth.
The posterior fontanelle is located where the {{c1::parietal}} and {{c1::occipital}} bones meet.
It is triangular and typically closes within 6 to 8 weeks after birth.
{{c1::Fontanelles}} are soft spaces in a newborn's skull that allow for brain growth and skull shifting during birth.
The {{c1::pterion}} is the region where the {{c2::frontal}}, {{c2::parietal}}, {{c2::sphenoid}}, and {{c2::temporal}} bones meet.
The pterion is clinically significant because it overlies the middle meningeal artery.
The visible part of the facial skeleton includes the {{c1::nasal}}, {{c1::maxilla}}, and {{c1::zygomatic}} bones.
The frontal bone articulates with the greater wing of the {{c1::sphenoid bone}}.
The greater wing of the sphenoid bone articulates with the parietal bone at the {{c1::sphenoparietal suture}}.
The greater wing of the sphenoid bone articulates with the temporal bone at the {{c1::sphenosquamous suture}}.
The temporal bone articulates with the occipital bone at the {{c1::occipitomastoid suture}}.
A fracture at the pterion can lead to a tear of the {{c1::middle meningeal artery}}, resulting in an {{c2::extradural hematoma}}.
The {{c1::maxilla}} forms the upper jaw and includes the alveolar process that holds the teeth.
The maxilla also contributes to the inferior and medial borders of the orbit and articulates with the nasal bone.
The maxilla also contributes to the {{c1::inferior}} and {{c1::medial}} borders of the orbit and articulates with the {{c2::nasal bone}}.
The {{c1::zygomatic process}} of the maxilla articulates with the zygomatic bone.
This articulation forms part of the zygomatic arch.
The {{c1::nasion}} is the bridge of the nose located at the intersection of the nasal and frontal bones.
The nasion is an important facial landmark often used in cranial measurements.
The {{c1::zygomatic bone}} forms the prominence of the cheek.
It articulates with the zygomatic process of the temporal bone and maxilla to form the zygomatic arch.
The zygomatic process of the {{c1::temporal}} bone articulates with the {{c2::zygomatic}} bone.
This forms the lateral portion of the zygomatic arch.
The {{c1::frontal bone}} forms the superior part of the rim of each orbit and the forehead.
This bone contributes to both the cranial and facial skeleton.
The {{c1::supra-orbital foramen}} is located along the medial part of the superior rim of each orbit.
This structure allows passage of nerves and blood vessels to the forehead.
The frontal bone forms part of the {{c1::medial}} rim of the orbit.
The zygomatic process of the frontal bone projects inferiorly, forming the {{c1::upper lateral}} rim of the orbit.
It articulates with the frontal process of the zygomatic bone.
The {{c1::nasal bones}} are paired bones that articulate with each other in the midline and with the frontal bone superiorly.
These bones form the bridge of the nose.
The {{c1::zygomaticofacial foramen}} of the zygomatic bone transmits the zygomaticofacial branch of the {{c2::trigeminal}} nerve.
This foramen is located on the anterolateral surface of the zygomatic bone.
The {{c1::paired maxillae}} form the upper jaw and contribute to the inferior and medial rims of the orbit.
These bones also house the upper teeth via the alveolar processes.
The {{c1::frontal process}} of each maxilla articulates with the frontal bone.
This forms part of the superior medial rim of the orbit.
The {{c1::zygomatic process}} of each maxilla articulates with the zygomatic bone.
This articulation contributes to the lateral wall of the orbit.
The {{c1::infra-orbital foramen}} is located on the anterior surface of the maxilla, just below the inferior rim of the orbit.
This foramen transmits the infra-orbital nerve and vessels.
Inferiorly, each maxilla ends as the {{c1::alveolar process}}, which contains the teeth and forms the upper jaw.
The {{c1::squamous}} part of the temporal bone contributes to the lateral wall of the cranium.
This is the largest and most flat section of the temporal bone.
The {{c1::zygomatic process}} of the temporal bone articulates with the temporal process of the zygomatic bone.
The ethmoid bone is {{c1::pneumatized}}, containing air pockets to reduce its weight.
These air pockets form the ethmoidal air cells, part of the paranasal sinuses.

The superior rim of the orbit is formed by:
{{c1::Orbital}} part of the frontal bone

The superior wall (roof) of the orbit consists of:
{{c1::Orbital}} part of the frontal bone
{{c1::Lesser}} wing of the sphenoid

The medial wall of the orbit is formed by:
{{c1::Maxilla}}
{{c1::Lacrimal}} bone
{{c1::Ethmoid}} bone
{{c1::Sphenoid}} bone

The inferior rim of the orbit is formed by:
{{c1::Maxilla}}
{{c1::Zygomatic}} bone

The inferior wall (floor) of the orbit consists of:
{{c1::Maxilla}}
{{c1::Zygomatic}} bone
{{c1::Palatine}} bone

The lateral rim of the orbit is formed by:
{{c1::Zygomatic}} bone
{{c1::Zygomatic process}} of the frontal bone

The lateral wall of the orbit is formed by:
{{c1::Zygomatic}} bone
{{c2::Greater wing}} of the sphenoid bone

Major openings through which nerves and vessels enter or leave the orbit:
{{c1::Optic}} canal
{{c2::Superior orbital}} fissure
{{c2::Inferior orbital}} fissure
{{c3::Lacrimal}} groove
{{c4::Inferior orbital}} foramen
{{c4::Ethmoidal}} foramina

The floor of the cranial cavity is divided into three distinct depressions:
{{c1::anterior}}
{{c1::middle}}
{{c1::posterior}}
These fossae correspond to the base of the brain, providing support for its lobes.
The {{c1::anterior}} cranial fossa is the most shallow and superior of the three cranial fossae.
It supports the anteroinferior portions of the frontal lobes of the brain.
The {{c1::middle}} cranial fossa is centrally located on the cranial floor and has a butterfly shape.
This fossa accommodates the temporal lobes and the pituitary gland.
The {{c1::posterior}} cranial fossa is the most posterior and deepest of the three cranial fossae.

Cranial nerves that carry preganglionic parasympathetic fibers to structures within the head and neck:
  • {{c1::III}}
  • {{c1::VII}}
  • {{c1::IX}}
  • {{c1::X}}
Postganglionic parasympathetic fibers usually travel with branches of {{c1::CN V (trigeminal)}} to get to their destination.
There are {{c1::three}} ganglia in the cervical region along the sympathetic trunk.
These ganglia are part of the sympathetic pathway that innervates structures in the head and neck.
{{c1::Preganglionic sympathetic}} fibers from upper thoracic spinal levels synapse in cervical ganglia.
This pathway allows sympathetic innervation to reach the head and neck.
The superior cervical ganglion is located at vertebral levels {{c1::C1}} and {{c1::C2}}.
This ganglion is the largest of the cervical sympathetic ganglia.
The superior cervical ganglion forms a plexus around the {{c1::internal}} and {{c1::external carotid}} arteries.
This plexus supplies sympathetic fibers to structures served by these arteries.
The middle cervical ganglion lies at vertebral level {{c1::C6}}.
It is located inferior to the superior cervical ganglion.
The inferior cervical ganglion forms a plexus around the {{c1::vertebral}} arteries.
This ganglion lies inferior to the middle cervical ganglion.
Structures supplied by the {{c1::external carotid}} artery receive sympathetic supply from the {{c2::superior cervical}} ganglion.
This includes facial structures and other areas served by branches of the external carotid artery.
The {{c1::superior cervical}} ganglion provides sympathetic innervation to the carotid body and sinus.
These structures help regulate blood pressure and blood flow.
The cranial meninges are {{c1::three::#}} layers of membranes that protect the brain and spinal cord.
They are continuous with the spinal meninges through the foramen magnum.
The {{c1::dura mater}} is the tough outermost layer of the meninges.
The cranial dura mater has two layers: the periosteal and meningeal layers.
The {{c1::arachnoid mater}} is the delicate middle layer of the meninges.
It lies beneath the dura mater and above the pia mater, enclosing the subarachnoid space.
The {{c1::pia mater}} is the innermost meningeal layer, attached to the brain’s surface.
It provides stability and security to the brain and spinal cord.
The cranial dura mater consists of two layers: the {{c1::periosteal}} layer and the {{c1::meningeal}} layer.
Only the meningeal layer is continuous with the spinal dura mater through the foramen magnum.
Only the {{c1::meningeal}} layer of the cranial dura mater is continuous with the spinal dura mater through the foramen magnum.

The periosteal layer is attached to the {{c1::skull}} and contains {{c2::meningeal arteries}}, while the meningeal layer is in contact with the {{c1::arachnoid mater}} and connects to the {{c2::spinal dura mater}}.
The falx cerebri is located between the {{c1::cerebral hemispheres}}.
It provides structural support within the cranial cavity.
Anteriorly, the falx cerebri attaches to the {{c1::crista galli}} of the ethmoid bone and the {{c1::frontal crest}} of the frontal bone.
Posteriorly, the falx cerebri blends with the {{c1::tentorium cerebelli}}.
The falx cerebri is a crescent-shaped projection of the {{c1::meningeal dura}} mater.
It separates the two cerebral hemispheres.
The tentorium cerebelli is a horizontal projection of the {{c1::meningeal dura}} mater.
The {{c1::tentorium cerebelli}} separates the cerebellum from the posterior cerebral hemispheres.
The tentorium cerebelli is attached posteriorly to the {{c1::occipital bone}} along the grooves for the transverse sinuses.
The tentorium cerebelli connects laterally to the {{c1::superior border of the petrous}} part of the temporal bone.
The anterior and medial borders of the tentorium cerebelli are free, forming the {{c1::tentorial notch}}.
The tentorium cerebelli ends at the anterior and posterior {{c1::clinoid processes}}.
The falx cerebelli is a small midline projection of the {{c1::meningeal dura}} mater located in the {{c2::posterior cranial fossa}}.
The falx cerebelli attaches posteriorly to the {{c1::internal occipital crest}} of the occipital bone.
Superiorly, the falx cerebelli connects to the {{c1::tentorium cerebelli}}.
The anterior edge of the falx cerebelli is free and situated between the {{c1::two cerebellar hemispheres}}.
The {{c1::diaphragma sellae}} is a small horizontal shelf of the {{c2::meningeal dura}} mater.
It forms the roof over the hypophyseal fossa.
The diaphragma sellae covers the {{c1::hypophyseal fossa}} in the {{c2::sella turcica}} of the sphenoid bone.
There is a central opening in the diaphragma sellae that allows the {{c1::infundibulum}} to pass through.
The infundibulum connects the pituitary gland with the base of the brain.
The {{c1::middle meningeal artery::Artery}}  is the primary arterial supply to the {{c2::dura mater}}.
It is a key vessel that runs within the cranial cavity.
The middle meningeal artery travels in the {{c1::outer periosteal}} layer of the dura in the {{c2::middle cranial}} fossa.
This path supports the dura in this region.
The <u>middle meningeal artery</u> is a branch of the {{c1::maxillary artery::Artery}}.
The maxillary artery is itself a branch of the external carotid artery.
The middle meningeal artery enters the middle cranial fossa through the {{c1::foramen spinosum}}.
{{c1::Arachnoid granulations}} are small, fluid-filled outpouchings of the arachnoid membrane.
They protrude into venous sinuses of the brain and assist in CSF drainage.
The {{c1::arachnoid mater}} is a thin, <u>avascular</u> membrane.
It lies beneath the dura mater and above the pia mater, enclosing the subarachnoid space.
Thin processes or trabeculae from the arachnoid mater extend downward and become continuous with the {{c1::pia mater}}.
These trabeculae cross the subarachnoid space, creating structural continuity.
The {{c1::pia mater}} is a thin, delicate membrane closely investing the brain's surface.
It follows the contours of the brain, entering grooves and fissures.
The pia mater is closely applied to the roots of the {{c1::cranial nerves}} at their origins.
This ensures continuity between the brain and the peripheral nervous system.
The {{c1::extradural}} space is the potential space between the {{c2::dura mater}} and {{c2::bone}}.
This space is normally nonexistent but can become actual when fluid or blood accumulates.
Bleeding into the extradural space is primarily caused by rupture of a {{c1::meningeal artery}}.
It can also occur from a torn dural venous sinus, though this is less common.
An {{c1::extradural hematoma}} occurs when blood accumulates in the extradural space due to vascular rupture.
This condition often results in increased intracranial pressure and requires urgent intervention.
A {{c1::subdural hematoma}} occurs when blood collects between the {{c2::dura mater}} and {{c2::arachnoid mater}}.
This blood collection results from injury and dissection of the meningeal dura.
Subdural hematomas are commonly caused by tearing of a {{c1::cerebral vein}} as it crosses through the dura to enter a dural venous sinus.
This venous bleeding is often slower than arterial bleeding.
The {{c1::subarachnoid space}} is the only normally occurring fluid-filled space associated with the meninges.
It contains cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and surrounds the brain and spinal cord.
The {{c1::choroid plexus}} is located in the subarachnoid space and produces CSF.
CSF production is crucial for cushioning and protecting the brain.
CSF circulates through the subarachnoid space and returns to the venous system via {{c1::arachnoid villi}}.
Arachnoid granulations are larger outpouchings of the villi that protrude into the superior sagittal sinus.
Dural venous sinuses are located between the {{c1::outer periosteal layer}} and the {{c2::inner meningeal layer}} of the dura mater.
The {{c1::diploic veins::Veins}} run between the internal and external tables of compact bone in the cranial cavity.
They drain into the dural venous sinuses and are associated with bone vascularization.
The {{c1::diploic veins::Veins}} drain into the dural venous sinuses and are associated with bone vascularization.
The {{c1::emissary veins::Veins}} pass from outside the cranial cavity to the dural venous sinuses.
These veins lack valves, making them a conduit for infections entering the cranial cavity.
The dural venous sinuses eventually drain into the {{c1::internal jugular veins::Veins}}.
The emissary veins lack {{c1::valves}}, making them a conduit for infections entering the cranial cavity.
The {{c1::superior sagittal sinus}} is the largest dural venous sinus, running along the midline of the cranial vault.
It drains blood from the brain into the confluence of sinuses.
The inferior sagittal sinus drains into the {{c1::straight sinus}}.
The superior & inferior petrosal sinuses drain the {{c1::cavernous sinuses}} into the {{c2::transverse sinus}}.
This pathway is critical for venous return from the deep parts of the face and orbit.
The {{c1::confluence of sinuses}} is a meeting point of the superior sagittal, straight, transverse, and occipital sinuses.
The superior sagittal sinus is located in the superior border of the {{c1::falx cerebri}}.
The superior sagittal sinus begins anteriorly at the {{c1::foramen cecum}}.
At this point, it may receive a small emissary vein from the nasal cavity.
The superior sagittal sinus receives veins from the {{c1::superior}} surface of the cerebral hemispheres, {{c2::diploic}} and {{c2::emissary}} veins, and veins from the {{c3::falx cerebri}}.
The inferior sagittal sinus is located in the {{c1::inferior}} margin of the falx cerebri.

The {{c1::straight sinus}} receives blood from the {{c2::inferior sagittal sinus}}, {{c3::great cerebral vein::Veins}}, {{c3::cerebral veins::Veins}}, {{c4::superior cerebellar veins::Veins}}, and veins from the {{c4::falx cerebri}}.
The great cerebral vein drains deep areas of the cerebral hemispheres.
The great cerebral vein drains deep areas of the {{c1::cerebral hemispheres}}.
The confluence of sinuses is a dilated space located at the {{c1::internal occipital protuberance}}.
It serves as the central hub for venous drainage in the cranial cavity.
The confluence of sinuses receives blood from the {{c1::superior sagittal sinus}}, {{c1::straight sinus}}, and {{c1::occipital sinus}}.
The confluence of sinuses empties into the {{c1::right and left transverse sinuses}}.
These sinuses channel blood toward the sigmoid sinuses.
The {{c1::cavernous sinuses}} are paired structures located on either side of the {{c2::sella turcica}}, in the lateral aspect of the body of the {{c3::sphenoid bone}}.
The cavernous sinuses receive blood from the {{c1::ophthalmic veins::Veins}} and {{c1::cerebral veins::Veins}}.
The ophthalmic veins connect the orbit to the cavernous sinus, creating a potential pathway for infection.
The emissary veins from the {{c1::pterygoid venous}} plexus drain into the {{c2::cavernous sinuses}}.
These connections facilitate communication between extracranial and intracranial venous systems.
Connections of the {{c1::cavernous sinuses}} provide a route for infections to pass from extracranial sites to intracranial locations.
This is clinically significant in conditions such as cavernous sinus thrombosis.
The structures passing through each cavernous sinus are the {{c1::internal carotid artery::Artery}} and the {{c2::abducent nerve (VI)::Nerve}}.

The structures in the lateral wall of each cavernous sinus are, from superior to inferior:
{{c1::oculomotor nerve (III)::Nerve}}
{{c1::trochlear nerve (IV)::Nerve}}
{{c1::ophthalmic nerve (V1)::Nerve}}
{{c1::maxillary nerve (V2)::Nerve}}.
The {{c1::intercavernous sinuses}} connect the right and left cavernous sinuses on the anterior and posterior sides of the {{c2::pituitary stalk}}.
The brain receives its arterial supply from the {{c1::vertebral arteries::Artery}} and {{c1::internal carotid arteries::Artery}}.
The {{c1::cerebral arterial circle (Circle of Willis)}} is formed by the interconnection of the vertebral and internal carotid arteries in the cranial cavity.
This structure provides collateral blood flow to the brain.
The two <u>internal carotid arteries</u> enter the cranial cavity through the {{c1::carotid canals}}.
These canals are located on either side of the skull base.
The {{c1::anterior communicating artery::Artery}} connects the left and right anterior cerebral arteries.
This artery completes the anterior part of the Circle of Willis.
The {{c1::posterior communicating arteries::Artery}} connect the <u>internal carotid artery</u> to the <u>posterior cerebral arteries</u>.
There is one posterior communicating artery on each side of the Circle of Willis.
The Circle of Willis ensures an anastomotic interconnection between the {{c1::vertebrobasilar}} system and the {{c1::internal carotid}} system.
This interconnection helps maintain blood supply even if one part of the circle is compromised.
The vertebral arteries enter the cranial cavity through the {{c2::foramen magnum}} and fuse to form the {{c1::basilar artery}}.
This fusion occurs at the brainstem level.
Each vertebral artery is a branch of the {{c1::subclavian artery::Artery}} in the lower part of the neck.
The vertebral arteries ascend through the transverse foramina of cervical vertebrae before entering the skull.
The {{c1::basilar artery}} ends as a bifurcation, giving rise to the two {{c2::posterior cerebral arteries}}.
This bifurcation is a major contribution to the Circle of Willis.
The basilar artery gives off the {{c1::posterior communicating arteries::Artery}}, which connect to the {{c2::anterior}} cerebral circulation.
These branches help link the posterior and anterior circulatory systems in the brain.
The {{c1::internal carotid arteries::Artery}} arise from the <u>common carotid arteries</u> and proceed superiorly to the base of the skull.
The internal carotid arteries enter the cranial cavity through the {{c1::carotid canal}}.
This canal is located at the base of the temporal bone.
Branches of the internal carotid arteries in the cranial cavity include the {{c1::anterior communicating artery::Artery}} and the {{c2::middle cerebral artery::Artery}}.

The scalp is the part of the head that extends from the {{c1::superciliary arches}} anteriorly to the {{c2::external occipital protuberance}} and {{c2::superior nuchal lines}} posteriorly. Laterally it continues inferiorly to the {{c3::zygomatic arch}}.

The scalp is a multilayered structure with layers that can be defined by the word itself:
  • S - {{c1::Skin}}
  • C - {{c1::Connective tissue (dense)}}
  • A - {{c1::Aponeurotic layer}}
  • L - {{c1::Loose connective tissue}}
  • P - {{c1::Pericranium}}
The {{c1::skin}} is the outer layer of the scalp.
The skin layer contains hair follicles and sebaceous glands.
The {{c1::dense connective tissue}} layer anchors the skin to the {{c2::aponeurotic}} layer.
This layer contains arteries, veins, and nerves that supply the scalp.
The {{c1::dense connective tissue}} layer in the scalp holds cut vessels open, leading to profuse bleeding.
This structural feature of the connective tissue makes scalp injuries prone to significant blood loss.
The aponeurotic layer includes the {{c1::epicranial aponeurosis}}, connecting the frontal and occipital bellies of the occipitofrontalis muscle.
The epicranial aponeurosis, also known as the galea aponeurotica, helps in coordinated movements of the scalp.
The {{c1::loose connective tissue}} layer facilitates movement of the scalp.
This layer allows for the free movement of the scalp over the skull.
Infections tend to localize and spread within the {{c1::loose connective tissue}} layer of the scalp.
This layer acts as a potential space, making it susceptible to spreading infections.
The {{c1::pericranium}} is the periosteum on the outer surface of the calvaria.
It is the deepest layer of the scalp and provides nutrients to the skull bones.
The pericranium is attached to the bones of the calvaria but can be separated except at the {{c1::sutures}}.
This layer is tightly bound at the sutures, limiting its movement.
The {{c1::supratrochlear}} and {{c1::supra-orbital}} arteries supply the anterior and superior aspects of the scalp.
These arteries are branches of the ophthalmic artery.
Branches from the {{c1::ophthalmic}} artery supply the anterior and superior aspects of the scalp.
The ophthalmic artery branches include the supratrochlear and supra-orbital arteries.
The {{c1::superficial temporal}}, {{c1::posterior auricular}}, and {{c1::occipital}} arteries supply the lateral and posterior scalp.
These arteries are branches of the <u>external carotid artery</u>.
Branches of the {{c1::external carotid}} artery supply the lateral and posterior aspects of the scalp.
The external carotid branches involved are the superficial temporal, posterior auricular, and occipital arteries.
The {{c1::superficial temporal}} vein accompanies the superficial temporal artery in the scalp.
This vein drains into the retromandibular vein.
The {{c1::posterior auricular}} vein accompanies the posterior auricular artery along the lateral scalp.
It drains into the external jugular vein.
The {{c1::occipital}} vein accompanies the occipital artery and drains the posterior scalp.
This vein typically drains into the internal jugular vein.
{{c1::Emissary}} veins are small, valveless veins connecting scalp veins to dural venous sinuses.
These veins allow blood to flow between the scalp (face and sinuses) and the intracranial dural venous sinuses.
Infections in the scalp can spread to the {{c1::meninges}} via emissary veins.
The valveless nature of these veins facilitates the spread of infection into the cranial cavity.
The {{c1::periosteum (pericranium)}} of the scalp can transmit infections from the scalp into the bone or cranium.
Infections may enter through emissary veins, allowing spread into deeper cranial structures.
The muscles of facial expression are innervated by branches of the {{c1::facial nerve (CN VII)}}.
The facial nerve controls these muscles, allowing for various facial expressions.
Muscles of facial expression are located in the {{c1::superficial}} fascia, originating from bone or fascia and inserting into the skin.
This arrangement allows these muscles to move the skin, creating expressions.
The muscles of facial expression are divided into four main groups: {{c1::scalp and forehead}}, {{c1::orbital}}, {{c1::nasal}}, and {{c1::oral}}.
These groups represent the anatomical regions where these muscles are located and function.
Observation of facial muscles can provide insight into an individual's {{c1::general}} health.
Certain facial expressions and muscle tone can indicate neurological or health issues.
The frontal belly of the occipitofrontalis is innervated by the temporal branch of the {{c1::facial (CN VII)}} nerve.
This branch of CN VII allows the frontal belly to raise the eyebrows and wrinkle the forehead.
The occipital belly of the occipitofrontalis is innervated by the posterior auricular branch of {{c1::CN VII}}.
This belly attaches to the superior nuchal line of the occipital bone and the mastoid process of the temporal bone.
The {{c1::epicranial aponeurosis}} connects the frontal and occipital bellies of the occipitofrontalis muscle.
This aponeurosis allows coordinated movement of the scalp over the skull.
The {{c1::occipitofrontalis}} muscle functions to move the scalp, wrinkle the forehead, and raise the eyebrows.
These actions are essential for expressing surprise or alertness.
The {{c1::orbicularis oculi}} muscle closes the eyelids by narrowing the palpebral fissure.
This action protects the eyeball from injury and excessive light.
The {{c1::palpebral}} part of the orbicularis oculi muscle is responsible for gentle blinking.
This inner portion helps to keep the cornea moist by spreading tears.
The {{c1::orbital}} part of the orbicularis oculi muscle enables winking or squinting.
This outer portion helps prevent glare and shields against dust.
The orbicularis oculi muscle is innervated by the {{c1::temporal (upper)}} and {{c1::zygomatic (lower)}} branches of the {{c2::facial (CN VII)}} nerve.
Each part of the muscle is controlled by specific branches of CN VII.
The {{c1::procerus}} muscle wrinkles the skin over the nose.
This muscle is important for creating expressions of frowning or concentration.
Flaring the nostrils can help increase airflow and is often seen during heavy breathing.
The procerus and nasalis muscles are innervated by the {{c1::buccal}} branch of the {{c2::facial (CN VII)}} nerve.
This branch of the facial nerve controls muscles involved in facial expression.
This muscle encircles the mouth and controls lip movements like puckering.
The {{c1::zygomaticus}} muscle raises the corners of the lips to create a smile.
This muscle plays a key role in facial expressions of happiness or friendliness.
The {{c1::buccinator}} muscle compresses the cheek and holds food in the mouth during chewing.
Its name means "trumpeter," indicating its function in compressing the cheeks.
Muscles that produce a frown are innervated by the {{c1::marginal mandibular}} branch of the {{c2::facial}} nerve, below the labial commissure.
These muscles control expressions of sadness or displeasure.
The oral group of facial muscles, including orbicularis oris and buccinator, is innervated by the {{c1::buccal}} branch of {{c2::CN VII}}.
This branch supplies muscles that move the lips and cheeks.
The {{c1::parotid}} gland is the largest of the three pairs of main salivary glands in the head.
The other two main salivary glands are the submandibular and sublingual glands.
The {{c1::parotid}} gland is located superficial, posterior, and deep to the ramus of the {{c2::mandible}}.
This positioning allows the gland to surround the mandible near its angle.
The parotid gland covers the anterior part of the {{c1::sternocleidomastoid}} muscle.
This muscle lies posterior to the parotid gland, providing structural support.
The gland continues across this muscle to aid in saliva secretion into the mouth.
The {{c1::facial (CN VII)}} nerve passes through the {{c2::parotid}} gland but does not innervate it.
This anatomical course makes the facial nerve vulnerable during parotid surgery.
This fascial covering provides structural support and compartmentalizes the gland.
Structures embedded in the parotid gland include {{c1::parotid lymph}} nodes, the {{c1::external carotid}} artery and {{c1::peri-arterial}} plexus, and the {{c1::retromandibular}} vein.
These structures are located within the gland but do not innervate it.
The {{c1::facial}} nerve divides into branches within the parotid gland but does not innervate the gland itself.
This nerve is at risk during parotid surgery due to its location within the gland.
The parotid duct travels over the {{c1::masseter}} muscle, punctures the {{c2::buccinator}}, and empties into the {{c3::oral cavity}} opposite the second maxillary molar.
This pathway allows saliva to enter the mouth near the upper molars.
The facial nerve exits the skull through the {{c1::stylomastoid}} foramen.
This foramen is located at the base of the skull near the mastoid process.
The facial nerve divides into its branches within the {{c1::parotid}} gland.
This anatomical course increases the risk to the nerve during parotid gland surgery.
The five terminal branches of the facial nerve are: {{c1::temporal}}, {{c1::zygomatic}}, {{c1::buccal}}, {{c1::marginal mandibular}}, and {{c1::cervical}}.
These branches control muscles involved in facial expression.
Surgical dissection around the parotid gland is challenging due to the proximity of {{c1::facial}} nerve branches.
Damage to these branches can lead to facial muscle paralysis.
Sensory innervation of the parotid gland is provided by the {{c1::auriculotemporal}} nerve, a branch of the {{c2::mandibular (V3)}} nerve.
This nerve supplies sensation to the gland and carries secretomotor fibers.
The {{c1::auriculotemporal}} nerve also carries secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland.
These fibers help stimulate saliva secretion.
Preganglionic parasympathetic fibers for the parotid gland come from the {{c1::glossopharyngeal (CN IX)}} nerve via the {{c2::lesser petrosal}} nerve.
These fibers synapse in the otic ganglion and increase parotid secretion.
Parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland synapse in the {{c1::otic ganglion}} and increase glandular secretion.
The synapse in the otic ganglion allows for activation of salivary production.
Sympathetic fibers to the parotid gland travel with arteries from the {{c1::superior cervical}} ganglion.
These fibers decrease secretion and originate from spinal levels T1-T4.
The primary arterial supply to the face is from the {{c1::external carotid}} artery.
The external carotid artery supplies most of the facial structures.
The {{c1::internal carotid}} artery provides limited contributions to the arterial supply of the face.
These contributions mainly support the forehead and scalp through branches like the supraorbital artery.
The main pathway for venous return from the face is through the {{c1::internal jugular}} vein.
This vein collects blood from facial veins and transports it back toward the heart.
Facial veins have important connections with the {{c1::cavernous sinus}}, creating a potential route for infection spread.
Infections in the facial area can spread to the cranial cavity due to these venous connections.
The {{c3::facial}} artery originates from the {{c1::external carotid}} artery and terminates as the {{c2::angular}} artery.
This artery supplies the upper and lower lips and nasal septum.
The branches of the facial artery include the {{c1::superior}} and {{c1::inferior labial}} arteries and the {{c1::lateral nasal}} artery.
These branches provide blood to specific regions around the mouth and nose.
The transverse facial artery is a branch of the {{c1::superficial temporal}} artery.
It arises near the parotid gland and crosses the face near the masseter muscle.
The {{c1::maxillary}} artery supplies the face through the {{c2::infra-orbital}} and {{c2::buccal}} arteries.
The infra-orbital artery supplies the lower eyelid and upper lip, while the buccal artery supplies the buccinator muscle.
The {{c1::ophthalmic}} artery supplies the zygomatic bone through the zygomaticofacial and zygomaticotemporal arteries.
These branches provide blood to the facial region around the zygomatic bone.
The {{c1::supra-orbital}} and {{c1::supratrochlear}} arteries, branches of the {{c2::ophthalmic}} artery, supply the {{c3::anterior}} scalp.
These branches also supply parts of the forehead and are crucial for scalp circulation.
The {{c1::facial}} vein is the major vein responsible for draining the face.
It collects blood from the eyelids, nose, lips, cheeks, and chin.
This connection allows for potential spread of infections from the face to the intracranial structures.
The facial vein connects to the {{c1::cavernous}} sinus via {{c2::emissary}} veins.
These connections create a pathway for infections to spread into the cranial cavity.
There are no {{c1::valves}} in the venous channels of the head, allowing blood to flow in any direction.
This lack of valves increases the risk of spreading infections through retrograde flow.
Infections of the face require caution due to the risk of spreading to {{c1::intracranial}} structures.
Retrograde venous flow can carry infections from the face to the brain.
{{c1::Glycerophospholipids}} are based on a glycerol backbone and have fatty acids esterified at the #1 and #2 positions.
The #3 position contains a phosphate group, making it phosphatidic acid (PA), the simplest phosphoglyceride.
{{c1::Phosphatidylserine}} is formed by combining {{c2::phosphatidic acid (PA)}} with {{c2::serine}}.
It is a common glycerophospholipid found in cell membranes.
{{c1::Phosphatidylethanolamine}} is created by adding {{c2::ethanolamine}} to {{c2::phosphatidic acid (PA)}}.
Also known as PE or cephalin, it is found in biological membranes.
{{c1::Phosphatidylcholine}} is produced by adding {{c2::choline}} to {{c2::phosphatidic acid (PA)}}.
It is also known as lecithin, another major membrane phosphoglyceride.
{{c1::Phosphatidylglycerol}} results from the addition of {{c2::glycerol}} to {{c2::phosphatidic acid (PA)}}.
This lipid plays a role in pulmonary surfactant.
{{c1::Phosphatidylinositol}} is synthesized by adding {{c2::inositol}} to {{c2::phosphatidic acid (PA)}}.
{{c1::Sphingomyelins}} have a sphingosine backbone and are primarily found in membrane structures.
Sphingomyelins are a type of sphingolipid, distinct from glycerophospholipids.
In glycerophospholipids, an {{c1::alcohol}} is esterified on the phosphate group.
{{c1::Cardiolipin}} is formed by two molecules of {{c2::phosphatidic acid (PA)}} esterified to an additional molecule of {{c2::glycerol}}.
Cardiolipin plays a critical role in mitochondrial membrane structure and function.
Cardiolipin is localized exclusively to the {{c1::inner mitochondrial membrane}}.
It supports the function of certain respiratory complexes in the <u>electron transport chain</u>.
{{c1::Plasmalogens}} differ from glycerophospholipids by having an {{c2::ether vinyl}} bond at carbon 1 of glycerol.
The ether bond is more oxidized, enhancing their role as antioxidants in cell membranes.
Plasmalogens serve as {{c1::endogenous antioxidants}}, protecting other phospholipids in the membrane.
This antioxidant property helps maintain membrane integrity under oxidative stress.
The platelet-activating factor (PAF) is a short-lived signaling molecule derived from {{c1::plasmalogens}}.
PAF acts at very low concentrations (10⁻¹⁴ M) to mediate intercellular communication.
Platelet-activating factor (PAF) causes {{c1::platelet activation}} and increases {{c2::pulmonary edema}}.
It is involved in hypersensitivity, acute inflammation, and anaphylactic reactions.
The Activated DAG pathway involves the donation of {{c1::phosphatidic acid}} from {{c2::CDP-diacylglycerol}} to an {{c2::alcohol}}.
This pathway is essential for synthesizing glycerophospholipids.
In the activated DAG pathway, the {{c1::CDP-derivative}} is "activated" by a high-energy bond.
Synthesis occurs in the smooth ER and proceeds through the Golgi to membranes or the cell exterior (exocytosis).
In the activated DAG pathway, synthesis occurs in the {{c1::smooth ER}} and proceeds through the {{c1::Golgi}} to membranes or the cell exterior (exocytosis).
Phosphatidic acid synthesis occurs in all tissues except {{c1::erythrocytes}}.
Phosphatidic acid serves as a precursor in phospholipid synthesis.
The Activated alcohol pathway involves the donation of the phosphomonoester of an alcohol from {{c1::CDP-alcohol}} to {{c1::1,2-diacylglycerol}}.
This pathway is critical for the formation of specific phosphoglycerides.
{{c1::Phosphatidylcholine}} and {{c1::phosphatidylethanolamine}} are the <u>most abundant phospholipids</u> in eukaryotic cells.
Choline and ethanolamine, the building blocks, can be obtained from diet or phospholipid turnover.
{{c1::Choline}} is considered an essential dietary nutrient because humans cannot synthesize enough de novo.
Sufficient dietary intake is necessary to meet physiological needs.
{{c1::Dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine}} is a major component of lung surfactant.
It is crucial for treating respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm infants.
The liver produces {{c1::phosphatidylcholine}} when choline levels are low by decarboxylating {{c2::phosphatidylserine}} to {{c2::phosphatidylethanolamine}}.
PE is then methylated in three steps to form PC, which is important for bile secretion and plasma lipoproteins.
This property contributes to its specific interactions within the plasma membrane.
In mammalian tissues, phosphatidylserine synthesis occurs via the {{c1::base exchange}} reaction, where the {{c2::ethanolamine}} of PE is exchanged for {{c2::serine}}.
This reaction helps maintain PS levels in the inner leaflet of the plasma membrane.
Phosphatidylserine is primarily found in the {{c1::inner leaflet}} of eukaryotic plasma membranes.
Its asymmetric distribution is crucial for membrane functionality.
The {{c1::flippase}} enzyme, which is {{c1::ATP}}-dependent, normally retains phosphatidylserine inside the cell membrane.
During processes like apoptosis, "scramblase" exposes PtdSer on the cell surface.

When exposed on the cell surface, phosphatidylserine signals macrophages for {{c1::phagocytosis}} and supports {{c1::blood clotting}} by creating a scaffold for clotting factors on activated platelets.
The negative charge is important for its role in signaling and membrane interactions.
Phosphatidylinositol is primarily located in the {{c1::inner leaflet}} of the plasma membrane.
This asymmetric distribution is crucial for signaling pathways.
Phosphatidylinositol is synthesized from free inositol and {{c1::CDP-diacylglycerol}} via the {{c2::activated DAG}} pathway.
This synthesis pathway is common to several phosphoglycerides.
Phosphatidylinositol usually contains {{c1::stearic acid}} on carbon 1 and {{c1::arachidonic acid}} on carbon 2 of the glycerol.
PI acts as a reservoir for arachidonic acid, which is a substrate for prostaglandin synthesis.
Phosphatidylinositol acts as a reservoir for {{c1::arachidonic acid}}, which is a substrate for prostaglandin synthesis.
This cleavage generates two key second messengers involved in cellular signaling.
IP₃ binds to receptors on the {{c1::endoplasmic reticulum}}, releasing sequestered Ca²⁺.
Calcium release is critical for various cellular responses, including muscle contraction and secretion.
Activated protein kinase C <u>phosphorylates proteins</u>, leading to specific cellular responses.
Specific proteins can be attached to membrane-bound phosphatidylinositol (PI) through a {{c1::carbohydrate bridge}}.
For example, lipoprotein lipase is attached to capillary endothelial cells via a glycosyl phosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor.
{{c1::GPI-anchored}} proteins are not directly anchored to cytoskeletal elements like actin fibers.
This arrangement allows increased lateral mobility on the plasma membrane.
{{c1::Phospholipase C::Enzyme}} can cleave a protein from its GPI anchor.
This cleavage releases the anchored protein from the membrane, enabling downstream signaling.
{{c1::Phospholipase A1::Enzyme}} releases the fatty acid at position 1 of glycerophospholipids.
It is primarily involved in lipid metabolism.
It participates in the degradation of phospholipids by hydrolyzing the acyl chain at position 1.
{{c1::Phospholipase A2}} removes the fatty acid at position 2, releasing {{c2::arachidonic acid}}, a precursor for eicosanoid synthesis.
It plays a role in inflammatory responses and is activated by trypsin in pancreatic secretions.
Phospholipase A2 is found in {{c1::pancreatic juice}} and is activated by {{c2::trypsin}}.
It is abundant in pancreatic secretions, where it requires bile salts for activation.
{{c1::Phospholipase C}} cleaves PIP₂ to generate second messengers DAG and IP₃.
It is essential in the signal transduction pathway, activating intracellular signaling cascades.
Phospholipase C is located in {{c1::liver lysosomes}} and in α-toxin of {{c1::Clostridia}}.
It plays a critical role in producing second messengers in the PIP₂ signaling system.
Phospholipase D removes the {{c1::alcohol head}} group from phosphoglycerides, generating {{c1::phosphatidic acid}}.
This enzyme is involved in signaling processes regulating vesicle trafficking and membrane dynamics.
Phospholipase D is present in {{c1::cell membranes}}, where it facilitates signal transduction by producing {{c2::phosphatidic acid}} and {{c2::choline}}.
It participates in pathways regulating cell growth, stress responses, and membrane remodeling.
Compared to glycerophospholipids, {{c1::sphingomyelins}} are more mechanically stable and chemically resistant.
This stability is due to their unique backbone structure.
This differentiates them from other phospholipids like glycerophospholipids.
Sphingosine forms an amide linkage with a fatty acid to create {{c1::ceramide}}, the simplest sphingolipid.
Ceramide serves as a precursor for other glycosphingolipids.
{{c1::Ceramide}} serves as a precursor for other glycosphingolipids.
Esterification of carbon 1 of ceramide to {{c1::phosphorylcholine}} forms sphingomyelin, an important component of myelin in nerves.
Sphingomyelin is critical for nerve function and insulation.
Serine palmitoyltransferase catalyzes the condensation of {{c1::palmitoyl CoA}} with {{c1::serine}} to form {{c2::sphingosine}}.
CoA and the carboxyl group of serine are lost as CO₂ during this reaction.
This step adds a fatty acid to sphingosine, creating the sphingolipid precursor.
Choline phosphate is transferred from {{c1::phosphatidylcholine}} to {{c1::ceramide}} by {{c2::sphingomyelin synthase}}.
This reaction converts ceramide into sphingomyelin, a major component of cell membranes.
Sphingomyelinase is a {{c1::lysosomal enzyme}} that removes {{c2::phosphorylcholine}} from sphingomyelin to yield ceramide.
This enzyme is crucial for sphingomyelin degradation.
Niemann-Pick disease is caused by {{c1::sphingomyelinase}} deficiency, leading to sphingomyelin accumulation in the {{c2::liver}} and {{c2::spleen}}.
The severe form (Type A) causes neurodegeneration, mental retardation, and early death.
Ceramidase cleaves {{c1::ceramide}} into {{c2::sphingosine}} and a {{c2::free fatty acid}}.
This enzyme is part of the ceramide degradation pathway.
Cerebrosides are simple glycosphingolipids composed of {{c1::ceramide}} linked to a single {{c1::sugar}}, either {{c2::galactose}} or {{c2::glucose}}.
They are the simplest form of neutral glycosphingolipids, found mainly in the nervous system.
{{c1::Globosides}} consist of ceramide linked to multiple neutral sugars.
These are more complex glycosphingolipids, found in various tissues, including blood cells.
Acidic glycosphingolipids have a net {{c1::negative}} charge at physiological pH.
This negative charge is provided by sialic acids in gangliosides or sulfate groups in sulfatides.
{{c1::N-acetylneuraminic acid (NANA)}} is the common sialic acid found in {{c2::gangliosides}}.
It contributes to the negative charge of these glycosphingolipids.
{{c1::Gangliosides}} are derivatives of ceramide oligosaccharides that contain one or more molecules of {{c2::NANA}}.
The notation for gangliosides uses a "G" followed by subscripts to indicate the number of NANA residues (e.g., GM, GD, GT).
Acidic glycosphingolipids are {{c1::negatively}} charged at physiological pH due to {{c2::N-acetylneuraminic acid (NANA)}} in gangliosides or {{c2::sulfate groups}} in sulfatides.
These components provide the net negative charge that characterizes these glycosphingolipids.
Sulfatides are primarily found in the {{c1::brain}} and {{c1::kidneys}}.
The degradation of glycosphingolipids follows a {{c1::'last on, first off'}} pattern.
Enzymes cleave the glycosphingolipid's terminal sugars first, following sequential hydrolysis.
Glycosphingolipids are internalized by {{c1::phagocytosis}} and fuse with lysosomes for degradation.
This is a necessary step for the breakdown of these lipids within cells.
Enzymes required for glycosphingolipid degradation are present in the {{c1::lysosomes}}.
These enzymes cleave glycosphingolipids in a stepwise manner.
In Tay-Sachs disease, {{c1::GM₂ gangliosides}} accumulate due to β-hexosaminidase A deficiency.
Leads to rapid neurodegeneration, blindness, seizures, and cherry-red macula.
In Gaucher disease, {{c1::glucocerebrosides}} accumulate due to β-glucosidase deficiency.
Causes hepatosplenomegaly, bone deformities, and CNS involvement in rare cases.
In Metachromatic leukodystrophy, {{c1::sulfatides}} accumulate due to arylsulfatase A deficiency.
In Krabbe disease, {{c1::galactocerebrosides}} accumulate due to galactocerebrosidase deficiency.
Leads to severe mental and motor deterioration, blindness, and presence of globoid cells.
In GM₁ gangliosidosis, {{c1::GM₁ gangliosides}} accumulate due to β-galactosidase-1 deficiency.
Causes neurological decline, hepatosplenomegaly, and cherry-red macula in infants.
In Sandhoff disease, {{c1::GM₂ gangliosides and globosides}} accumulate due to deficiencies in β-hexosaminidase A and B.
Symptoms mirror Tay-Sachs but include visceral involvement.
In Fabry disease, {{c1::globosides}} accumulate due to α-galactosidase deficiency.
X-linked disorder with symptoms like skin rash, extremity pain, and organ failure.
In Niemann-Pick disease (Types A and B), {{c1::sphingomyelin}} accumulates due to sphingomyelinase deficiency.
Characterized by hepatosplenomegaly, neurodegeneration (Type A), and cherry-red macula.
In Farber disease, {{c1::ceramide}} accumulates due to ceramidase deficiency.
Symptoms include joint deformity, granulomas, and a hoarse cry.
{{c1::Autocrine}} signaling occurs when a cell releases a signal that binds to receptors on the same cell.
It helps regulate processes like cell growth and immune response.
{{c1::Paracrine}} signaling involves the release of signals that act on nearby cells.
It is essential for localized effects, such as inflammation and tissue repair.
{{c1::Intracrine}} signaling refers to signals that act within the same cell without being secreted.
It typically involves hormones or factors functioning inside the cell.
{{c1::Endocrine}} signaling uses general circulation to deliver signals to distant target cells.
This type of signaling is slower than autocrine or paracrine.
{{c1::Neuroendocrine}} signaling combines neural and endocrine mechanisms to target distant cells.
It involves neurosecretory cells releasing hormones into the bloodstream.
It is released from membrane phospholipids by phospholipase A₂ or C.
These classes have distinct roles in inflammation, blood flow, and clotting.
This ring structure differentiates them from other eicosanoids.
Thromboxanes contain a {{c1::6-point ring}} structure with a {{c2::lactone oxygen}} or {{c2::epoxide}}.
This structure contributes to their role in platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction.
This structure supports their function in vasodilation and inhibition of platelet aggregation.
Leukotrienes lack a ring but have {{c1::3 or more double bonds}} in their structure.
This linear structure is key to their role in inflammation and immune response.
Phospholipase A2 specifically targets the sn-2 position of phospholipids.
Phospholipase C cleaves the {{c1::phosphate group}} from the head of the phospholipid.
Arachidonate remains part of {{c1::diacylglycerol (DAG)}} after cleavage by {{c2::phospholipase C}}.
This makes it unavailable to cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes for eicosanoid synthesis.
When phospholipase A2 releases {{c1::arachidonic acid}} from glycerophospholipids, {{c1::lysophosphatidate}} is left in the membrane.
Lysophosphatidate can act as a signaling molecule or be further metabolized.
{{c1::Calcium (Ca²⁺)}} binding drives the membrane association of phospholipase A2.
Calcium binds to the C2 domain of phospholipase A2, facilitating its interaction with the membrane.
{{c1::COX-1}} and {{c1::COX-2}} are found on the {{c2::cytoplasmic}} side of the {{c3::ER}} and {{c3::nuclear}} membranes.
Both COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes catalyze the conversion of arachidonic acid to prostaglandins.
Phospholipase A2 releases arachidonic acid, which is transported to the {{c1::outer}} {{c2::nuclear}} and {{c2::ER}} membranes for delivery to {{c3::COX}} enzymes.
Arachidonic acid is a precursor for prostaglandins and thromboxanes via COX enzymes.
COX-1 is made {{c1::constitutively}} in most tissues and is required for maintaining healthy {{c2::gastric}} tissue, {{c2::renal}} homeostasis, and promoting {{c2::platelet aggregation}}.
COX-1 is constantly produced to maintain basic physiological functions.
COX-2 is {{c1::inducible}} in response to products of activated {{c3::immune}} and {{c3::inflammatory}} cells, leading to increased {{c2::prostaglandin}} synthesis.
COX-2 mediates inflammation, pain, redness, swelling, and fever during infection.
The COX active site has a {{c1::peroxidase}} cycle that generates a {{c2::tyrosine radical}}.
This radical is generated by the heme prosthetic group and initiates the modification of arachidonic acid.
The COX active site has a {{c1::cyclooxygenase}} cycle that modifies {{c2::arachidonic acid}} by adding {{c3::oxygen}}.
This modification leads to the production of prostaglandins and other eicosanoids.
Once {{c1::PGH₂}} is produced by COX, it is converted into mature signaling molecules by various {{c2::prostaglandin synthases}}.
These synthases generate specific eicosanoids like PGE₂, PGD₂, PGF₂α, PGI₂, and TXA₂, which mediate different physiological effects.
PGI₂ is primarily produced by endothelial cells and helps maintain blood flow and prevent thrombosis.
TXA₂ is produced by platelets and is crucial for hemostasis.
Eicosanoids are actively transported out of cells by {{c1::specialized transporters}}.
Specialized transporters ensure <u>efficient release</u>, owing to the short half-life of eicosanoids
Aspirin is a {{c1::non-competitive irreversible}} inhibitor of both COX-1 and COX-2, with a much higher affinity for {{c2::COX-1}}.
Aspirin’s irreversible inhibition makes it different from other NSAIDs, which are typically competitive inhibitors.
Ibuprofen and naproxen are {{c1::competitive}} inhibitors of both COX-1 and COX-2, with a preference for {{c2::COX-2}}.
These NSAIDs are commonly used for pain and inflammation management.
They have a 300-fold preference for COX-2 over COX-1
Paracetamol has minimal anti-inflammatory effects compared to other NSAIDs.
Aspirin acetylates {{c1::Ser530}} on COX-1, blocking the active site cavity.
Ser530 is not directly involved in catalysis, but acetylation of the residue blocks the active site.
Platelets lack DNA, so they cannot {{c1::regenerate COX}} after it is irreversibly inhibited by aspirin.
This makes aspirin's effect on platelet function lasting for the cell's <u>entire lifespan</u>.
{{c1::Vioxx}} and {{c1::Celebrex}} are selective inhibitors of {{c2::COX-2}} and are also called {{c3::Coxibs}}.
{{c1::Leukotriene A₄ (LTA₄)}} is the initial leukotriene produced from arachidonic acid in leukocytes, platelets, mast cells, and vascular tissues.
LTA₄ serves as a precursor to other active leukotrienes in the <u>inflammatory pathway</u>.
{{c1::Leukotriene C₄ (LTC₄)}} is synthesized from LTA₄ and contributes to smooth muscle contraction and increased vascular permeability.
It is a key mediator in allergic responses, including asthma.
{{c1::Leukotriene D₄ (LTD₄)}} is formed from {{c2::LTC₄}} and causes bronchoconstriction, increased mucus secretion, and enhanced vascular permeability.
It is one of the most potent bronchoconstrictors, making it significant in asthma pathology.
{{c1::Leukotriene E₄ (LTE₄)}} is derived from {{c2::LTD₄}} and further contributes to inflammation and bronchial constriction.
LTE₄ is often used as a biomarker for leukotriene activity in asthma and allergic reactions.
{{c1::Thromboxane A₂ (TXA₂)}} is produced primarily by {{c2::platelets}} and promotes platelet aggregation, vasoconstriction, and smooth muscle contraction.
TXA₂ mobilizes intracellular calcium and plays a role in hemostasis and thrombosis.
{{c1::Prostacyclin (PGI₂)}} is mainly produced by {{c2::<u>endothelial</u>}} cells and inhibits {{c3::platelet aggregation}} while promoting vasodilation.
PGI₂ has opposing effects to TXA₂, contributing to vascular homeostasis.
{{c1::Prostaglandin E₂ (PGE₂)}} is produced in the {{c2::kidney}} and is involved in {{c3::inflammation}}, {{c3::fever}}, and {{c3::pain}}.
Also contributes to vasodilation and increased vascular permeability.
{{c1::Prostaglandin F₂α (PGF₂α)}} is produced by {{c3::most tissues}} and promotes {{c2::uterine smooth}} muscle contraction, {{c2::vasoconstriction}}, and {{c2::bronchoconstriction}}.
PGF₂α plays a role in parturition and reproductive processes, as well as in certain inflammatory responses.
COX-2 inhibitors suppress {{c1::prostacyclin (PGI₂)}} synthesis but do not suppress {{c1::thromboxane (TXA₂)}} synthesis.
This shift increases the TXA₂/PGI₂ ratio, <u>favoring clotting</u>.
Platelets primarily express {{c1::COX-1}} and have minimal {{c1::COX-2}} expression due to their lack of nuclei.
COX-1 in platelets primarily produces TXA₂, which promotes clotting.
Vessel wall cells express {{c1::COX-2}} and produce {{c2::prostacyclins}}, which inhibit platelet aggregation.
Inhibition of COX-2 reduces PGI₂ production, increasing the risk of thrombosis.
TXA₂ and PGI₂ normally balance each other, resulting in {{c1::normal clotting behavior}}.
{{c1::COX-2}} selective inhibitors shift the TXA₂/PGI₂ ratio towards {{c2::TXA₂}}, increasing the risk of clot formation.
This imbalance leads to a pro-thrombotic state, raising cardiovascular risk.
{{c1::5-Lipoxygenase::Enzyme}} converts {{c2::arachidonic acid}} to {{c2::5-HPETE}}, which is further converted to leukotrienes.
5-Lipoxygenase acts on arachidonic acid to initiate leukotriene synthesis.
FLAP aids in the transfer of arachidonic acid from PLA₂ to 5-lipoxygenase, facilitating leukotriene synthesis.
FLAP aids in the transfer of arachidonic acid from {{c1::PLA₂}} to {{c1::5-lipoxygenase}}, facilitating leukotriene synthesis.
The iron in 5-lipoxygenase functions similarly to the heme group in COX, but without the involvement of {{c1::tyrosine}}.
The reaction involves O₂ attack on arachidonic acid, leading to lipid radical formation.
{{c1::Lipoxygenases::Enzyme Class}} are expressed primarily in immune cells, such as leukocytes, lymphocytes, granulocytes, monocytes, and macrophages.
Lipoxygenases are key enzymes in the synthesis of leukotrienes, which mediate inflammatory responses.
{{c1::Dietary cholesterol}} from food and drinks can cause the liver to release more cholesterol into the bloodstream.
The liver naturally produces all the cholesterol needed by the body. Excess dietary cholesterol stimulates further production.
Cholesterol is a major component of cell membranes, contributing to their structural integrity and fluidity.
Cholesterol is a precursor of {{c1::bile salts}} and {{c2::steroid hormones}}.
It is essential for synthesizing substances like bile acids, which aid digestion, and hormones like cortisol and sex hormones.
Cholesterol is also involved in the production of other compounds, such as cardiac glycosides and certain plant sterols.
Cholesterol is {{c1::amphipathic}}, meaning it has both hydrophilic and hydrophobic properties.
This characteristic allows cholesterol to interact with both lipid and aqueous environments, essential for its function in membranes.
Cholesterol is particularly abundant in {{c1::nervous tissue}} and is required for nerve transmission.
It plays a crucial role in the formation of myelin and other components essential for nerve function.
Cholesterol efflux involves {{c1::free cholesterol}} in bile, {{c2::bile salts/acids}}, and {{c3::VLDL (Very Low Density Lipoprotein)}}.
Efflux refers to how cholesterol exits the liver and enters circulation or is secreted into bile.
An imbalance between cholesterol influx and efflux can lead to {{c1::coronary artery disease (CAD)::Disease}}.
Proper balance is essential to prevent cholesterol accumulation, which can result in arterial plaque formation.
Cholesterol has a {{c1::steroid nucleus}} with 4 fused rings: A, B, C, D.
The steroid nucleus is the core structure of cholesterol, contributing to its hydrophobic nature.
Ring A of cholesterol contains a {{c1::C-3 hydroxyl}} group.
This hydroxyl group contributes to the molecule's slight polarity, despite being mostly hydrophobic.
Cholesterol contains a double bond between {{c1::C-5 and C-6::Carbon #'s}} on Ring B.
This double bond is part of cholesterol's rigid ring structure.
Cholesteryl esters are more {{c1::hydrophobic}} than free cholesterol.
They result from the esterification of cholesterol's hydroxyl group with fatty acids.
Cholesteryl esters must be transported in {{c1::lipoprotein particles}} in the blood.
Due to their hydrophobicity, they require lipoprotein carriers like LDL or HDL to circulate in the plasma.
Cholesterol is synthesized in {{c1::virtually all}} tissues, with the highest levels in the liver, intestine, adrenal cortex, and reproductive tissues.
These tissues have high metabolic demand for cholesterol, contributing to various functions, including hormone production and cell membrane integrity.
The basic building block for cholesterol synthesis is {{c1::acetate (as acetyl-CoA)}}.
Acetyl-CoA is derived from the oxidation of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins in mitochondria.
{{c1::HMG-CoA synthase}} is the enzyme that converts acetyl-CoA to HMG-CoA.
This is the key initial step in the cholesterol biosynthesis pathway, occurring mainly in the cytosol.
Cholesterol biosynthesis is driven by the hydrolysis of the {{c1::thioester bond}} of acetyl-CoA.
The energy released from this reaction facilitates the conversion of acetoacetyl-CoA to HMG-CoA.
The synthesis of HMG-CoA occurs in the {{c1::cytoplasm}} and {{c1::endoplasmic reticulum (ER)}}.
The process is regulated by cholesterol levels and involves both mitochondrial and cytosolic enzymes.
The rate-limiting step in cholesterol biosynthesis is catalyzed by {{c1::HMG-CoA reductase}}.
This enzyme converts HMG-CoA to mevalonic acid and is a critical regulatory point in cholesterol synthesis.
HMG-CoA is converted to {{c1::mevalonic acid}} in the cholesterol biosynthesis pathway.
This reaction also releases CoA and uses NADPH as a reducing agent.
{{c1::NADPH}} is used as the biosynthetic reductant in the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonic acid.
NADPH provides the necessary reducing power for the reaction.
HMG-CoA reductase is an {{c1::ER}}-associated enzyme that faces the {{c2::cytoplasm}}.
It is a membrane-bound enzyme in the endoplasmic reticulum, involved in cholesterol synthesis regulation.
Statin drugs target {{c1::HMG-CoA reductase}} to lower cholesterol levels.
Statins inhibit this enzyme, reducing cholesterol synthesis and thus blood cholesterol levels.
The synthesis of {{c1::mevalonic acid}} is the rate-limiting step in cholesterol biosynthesis.
This is the committed step in the pathway, catalyzed by HMG-CoA reductase.
The conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonic acid occurs in the {{c1::cytosol}}.
Despite being associated with the ER membrane, the reaction itself takes place in the cytosol.
Regulation of cholesterol synthesis centers on the rate-limiting enzyme {{c1::HMG-CoA reductase}}.
This enzyme is subject to both short-term and long-term regulation.
HMG-CoA reductase is regulated by feedback inhibition from {{c1::cholesterol}}.
Cholesterol acts as an allosteric inhibitor, reducing the enzyme's activity when cholesterol levels are high.
HMG-CoA reductase is also regulated by {{c1::AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK)}} (covalent regulation).
AMPK phosphorylates HMG-CoA reductase, rendering it inactive; the dephosphorylated form is active.
These hormones increase cholesterol synthesis by enhancing enzyme expression.
{{c1::Glucagon::Hormone}} and {{c1::glucocorticoids::Hormone}} suppress the transcription of HMG-CoA reductase.
These hormones decrease cholesterol synthesis, exerting long-term regulation over enzyme expression.
SREBP-dependent regulation involves transcriptional regulation by {{c1::Sterol Response Element Binding Protein (SREBP)}}.
SREBP controls the expression of genes involved in cholesterol biosynthesis.
SREBP-1 regulates {{c1::glucose}}, {{c1::lipid}}, and {{c1::fatty acid}} metabolism, while SREBP-2 is specific for {{c2::cholesterol}} synthesis.
SREBP-1 has two forms, SREBP-1a and SREBP-1c, which are produced from different transcription start sites.
The activation of SREBP is controlled by {{c1::Regulated Intramembrane Proteolysis (RIP)}}.
This process ensures the timely activation of SREBP for cholesterol homeostasis.
{{c1::HMG-CoA reductase}} is the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol biosynthesis.
It acts as the primary control point for cholesterol synthesis and is subject to multiple metabolic regulations.
{{c1::Sterol}}-dependent regulation of gene expression controls the synthesis of HMG-CoA reductase.
When sterol levels are low, transcription factors increase, leading to more HMG-CoA reductase production and increased cholesterol synthesis.
{{c1::Low}} sterol levels {{c2::increase}} the concentration of transcription factors for HMG-CoA reductase.
This promotes the expression of genes involved in cholesterol biosynthesis.
{{c1::SCAP}} is a cleavage-activating protein that binds to full-length {{c2::SREBP}} and contains a {{c2::sterol}} bonding domain.
SCAP plays a key role in regulating SREBP's movement and activation in response to cholesterol levels.
{{c1::INSIG}} associates with {{c2::SCAP}} in a {{c3::sterol}} binding-dependent interaction, localizing the complex to the {{c4::ER}}.
INSIG helps retain SCAP-SREBP in the ER when sterol levels are high.
{{c1::INSIG}} helps retain SCAP-SREBP in the ER when sterol levels are {{c2::high}}.
Decreasing sterol concentration causes INSIG and SCAP to {{c1::dissociate}}, allowing SREBP-SCAP to move to the {{c2::Golgi}} for proteolytic trimming by {{c3::S1P}} and {{c3::S2P}}.
This process activates SREBP, enabling it to enter the nucleus and enhance the transcription of target genes.
In conditions of {{c1::sterol abundance}}, INSIG retains the SCAP-SREBP complex in the ER.
This retention prevents SREBP from moving to the Golgi and activating cholesterol synthesis genes.
Under {{c1::sterol depletion}}, SCAP-SREBP moves from the ER to the Golgi for activation.
Depleted sterol levels trigger dissociation from INSIG, allowing this transport.
In the Golgi, SREBP is sequentially cleaved by {{c1::S1P}} and {{c1::S2P}}.
These proteolytic cleavages release the bHLH-Zip domain, enabling SREBP to act as a transcription factor.
The bHLH-Zip domain of SREBP translocates to the {{c1::nucleus}} after Golgi processing.
This domain binds to sterol regulatory elements (SREs) to upregulate cholesterol synthesis genes.
SREBPs bind to the {{c1::Sterol Response Element (SRE)}} DNA sequence, specifically TCACNCCAC.
SREBPs are transcription factors that regulate genes involved in cholesterol synthesis and uptake.
Helix segments of SREBP intercalate into the {{c1::major groove}} of the DNA duplex.
This interaction allows SREBP to "read" the DNA sequence through hydrogen bonding.
The SRE motif is recognized by the {{c1::hydrogen}} bonding of amino acid side chains to the DNA bases.
This interaction ensures specific binding of SREBP to target genes in the genome.
Statin drugs, such as atorvastatin, lovastatin, and pravastatin, are structural analogs of {{c1::HMG-CoA}}.
These drugs are competitive inhibitors of HMG-CoA reductase and are used to lower cholesterol levels.
By competing with HMG-CoA for the active site, statins decrease cholesterol synthesis in the liver.
Statins are used to decrease plasma {{c1::cholesterol}} levels in patients with hypercholesterolemia.
This reduction helps manage and prevent cardiovascular diseases linked to high cholesterol.
{{c1::Squalene}} is a 30-carbon intermediate that is subsequently converted to {{c2::lanosterol}}, the first sterol in cholesterol biosynthesis.
The synthesis of one molecule of squalene from isoprene units requires {{c1::18}} ATP molecules.
Bile acid synthesis starts with {{c1::cholesterol}} in the liver through a multistep process.
This pathway involves modifications such as hydroxylation, reduction of double bonds, and chain shortening.
The rate-limiting step in bile acid synthesis is catalyzed by {{c1::cholesterol 7-α hydroxylase}}.
This enzyme's activity is feedback-inhibited by cholic acid, a primary bile acid.
The two primary bile acids are {{c1::cholic acid}} and {{c2::chenodeoxycholic acid}}.
These acids are the main products of the bile acid synthesis pathway.
Conjugation of bile acids with {{c1::glycine}} or {{c2::taurine}} produces bile salts.
Bile salts are more acidic (lower pKa) and serve as better emulsifiers than bile acids.
Bacterial flora in the gut can remove {{c1::glycine}} and {{c1::taurine}} from bile salts to regenerate bile acids.
This process helps maintain bile acid levels and contributes to secondary bile acid production.
{{c1::Bacterial flora}} convert some primary bile acids to secondary bile acids by removing a {{c2::hydroxyl}} group.
This conversion results in the formation of deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acid.
Bacterial flora produces the secondary bile acids {{c1::deoxycholic acid}} and {{c1::lithocholic acid}}.
In the enterohepatic circulation, bile acids and salts are reabsorbed in the {{c1::ileum}} and transported back to the {{c2::liver}}.
Approximately 95% of bile acids and salts are reused through this circulation.
The liver converts primary and secondary bile acids into {{c1::bile salts}}, which are then secreted into bile.
This process supports digestion and absorption of dietary fats.
Bile acids contain {{c1::24::#}} carbon atoms with 2 or 3 hydroxyl groups and a side chain ending with a {{c2::carboxyl}} group.
The structure of bile acids allows them to act as detergents in the digestive system.
The pKa of the carboxyl group in bile acids is {{c1::6.0}}.
This pKa value contributes to the acidic nature of bile acids, which enhances their function as emulsifiers.
Bile acids are {{c1::amphipathic}}, with {{c2::methyl}} groups in the β-configuration above the rings and {{c2::hydroxyl}} groups in the α-configuration below the rings.
This amphipathic nature enables bile acids to act as emulsifying agents.
Cholesterol levels can be {{c1::lowered}} by {{c2::increasing}} the excretion of bile acids and bile salts.
Excreting more bile acids and salts forces the body to use more cholesterol for bile acid synthesis, reducing serum cholesterol levels.
{{c1::Cholestyramine}}, a bile acid sequestrant, binds to bile acids or salts and stimulates their excretion.
Cholestyramine helps lower serum cholesterol and reduces the risk of coronary artery disease.
{{c1::Dietary}} fiber can also bind bile acids or salts, promoting their excretion.
This process similarly helps lower cholesterol levels by drawing the biosynthetic pathway forward.
Cholelithiasis (gallstones) is caused by excess secretion of {{c1::cholesterol}} into bile without sufficient phospholipids and bile salts.
The imbalance causes cholesterol to precipitate, forming gallstones.
Causes of {{c1::cholelithiasis}} include malabsorption of bile acids, obstruction of the biliary tract, and liver dysfunction.
Excess feedback inhibition of bile acid synthesis can also contribute to gallstone formation.
Treatment options for cholelithiasis include {{c1::gallbladder removal::surgery}} or long-term treatment with {{c2::chenodeoxycholic acid::acid}}.
Chenodeoxycholic acid treatment can take months to years to dissolve gallstones.
Cholesterol and triglycerides are {{c1::insoluble}} in water and must be transported in association with proteins.
Lipoproteins are necessary to transport these lipids in the aqueous environment of the bloodstream.
Lipoproteins are complex particles with a central core of {{c1::cholesterol esters}} and {{c1::triglycerides}}.
The outer layer of lipoproteins contains {{c1::free cholesterol}}, {{c1::phospholipids}}, and {{c1::apolipoproteins}}.
The function of {{c1::apolipoproteins}} in lipoproteins includes facilitating their formation and function.
Apolipoproteins help in lipid binding and receptor recognition.
Inefficiency in lipoprotein transport and metabolism leads to {{c1::lipid deposition}} in blood vessels and {{c2::atherosclerosis}}.
Atherosclerosis refers to the narrowing of blood vessels due to lipid buildup.
The core of lipoproteins is referred to as the {{c1::neutral lipid}} core.
{{c1::Lipids}} and {{c1::apolipoproteins}} are constantly exchanged between lipoprotein particles, leading to variability.
This dynamic exchange allows for adaptation to different metabolic needs.
{{c1::Chylomicrons}} are the largest lipoproteins and have the {{c1::lowest::Highest/Lowest}} density.
Their large size and low density are due to high lipid content.
{{c1::VLDLs}} and {{c1::LDLs}} are denser than chylomicrons, while {{c2::HDLs}} are the densest.
VLDLs and LDLs have a lower lipid content compared to chylomicrons, making them denser. HDLs have the least lipid content, making them the densest.
Lipoproteins can be separated by {{c1::electrophoretic mobility}} and by density using {{c2::ultracentrifugation}}.
Electrophoretic mobility relies on charge, while ultracentrifugation separates based on size and density.
They transport triacylglycerol, cholesterol, and fat-soluble vitamins to peripheral tissues.
{{c1::Apo B-48}} is unique to chylomicrons and makes up 48% of Apo B-100.
Apo B-48 is <u>essential</u> for chylomicron synthesis.
Assembly of chylomicrons involves the {{c1::microsomal triacylglycerol transfer}} protein.
This protein helps load Apo B-48 with lipids during chylomicron formation.
Chylomicrons are released as {{c1::nascent chylomicrons}} after fusing with the plasma membrane.
"Nascent" indicates they are newly formed and not yet mature.
Chylomicrons receive {{c1::Apo C-II}} and {{c1::Apo E}} from {{c2::HDL's}} to become mature chylomicrons.
Apo C-II is required for lipoprotein lipase activation, while Apo E is needed for receptor-mediated uptake.
{{c1::Lipoprotein lipase}} is activated by Apo C-II in chylomicrons, facilitating TAG digestion.
This enzyme is found in endothelial tissues and breaks down triacylglycerol into fatty acids and glycerol.
Deficiencies in {{c1::Apo C-II}} or {{c1::lipoprotein lipase}} cause {{c2::type 1 hyperlipoproteinemia}}, also known as {{c2::familial chylomicronemia/hypertriacylglycerolemia}}.
This condition is autosomal recessive and involves impaired clearance of chylomicrons from plasma.
Type 1 hyperlipoproteinemia is {{c1::autosomal recessive::Inheritance Pattern}} and involves impaired clearance of {{c2::chylomicrons}} from plasma.
{{c1::Familial lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency}} typically presents in childhood with severe hypertriglyceridemia.
It is characterized by abdominal pain, recurrent acute pancreatitis, and triglyceride accumulation in plasma.
Familial lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency is characterized by {{c2::abdominal}} pain, recurrent acute {{c2::pancreatitis}}, and {{c2::triglyceride}} accumulation in plasma.
Reducing dietary fat helps lower plasma triglyceride levels.
{{c1::Insulin}} stimulates the synthesis and transfer of lipoprotein lipase to the capillary luminal surface.
This mechanism aids in the breakdown of triglycerides for cellular uptake.
VLDL's are packaged with {{c1::Apo B-100}} for export to peripheral tissues.
VLDL's are secreted as nascent VLDL's and acquire {{c1::Apo C-II}} and {{c1::Apo E}} from HDL's to become mature VLDL.
The {{c1::Apo B-100}} in VLDL contains the LDL receptor motif, which aids in cellular uptake.
Apo B-100 is crucial for VLDL's role in lipid transport.
A deficiency in {{c1::Apo E}} causes {{c2::familial type III hyperlipoproteinemia}}.
This condition results in high blood levels of chylomicron remnants and IDL's.
LDL is primarily responsible for cholesterol delivery to tissues.
The main function of {{c1::LDL's}} is to provide cholesterol to peripheral tissues or return it to the liver.
Cholesterol is essential for membrane synthesis and other functions.
LDL's bind to high-affinity cell surface receptors that recognize {{c1::Apo B-100}} and {{c1::Apo E}}.
These receptors are often called Apo B-100/Apo E receptors.
This specificity differentiates LDL binding from chylomicron remnant binding.
Chylomicron remnants and IDL's, which also contain {{c1::Apo E}}, are endocytosed and metabolized similarly to LDL.
This specificity differentiates LDL binding from chylomicron remnant binding.
LDL receptors are {{c2::negatively}} charged glycoproteins clustered in {{c1::clathrin-coated pits}}.
These pits facilitate the internalization of LDL particles.
{{c1::Apo B-100}} binds to LDL receptors for uptake.
A deficiency in {{c1::LDL receptors}} leads to {{c2::Type II hyperlipidemia (familial hypercholesterolemia)}}.
This condition results in high blood cholesterol levels due to reduced LDL clearance.
In endosomes, a drop in pH causes {{c1::LDL}} to separate from its {{c1::receptor}} in the {{c2::CURL (Compartment for Uncoupling of Receptor from Ligand)}} compartment.
The receptor is recycled back to the cell surface, while LDL is directed for degradation or processing.
{{c1::Evolocumab}} and {{c1::Alirocumab}} are agents that target and inactivate {{c2::PCSK9}}.
PCSK9 is a hepatic protease involved in the internalization and degradation of LDL receptors.
PCSK9 is a {{c1::hepatic protease::Enzyme Type}} involved in the internalization and degradation of LDL receptors.
Apo A-1 is secreted from the {{c1::liver}} and {{c1::intestine}} to form {{c2::HDL}}.
Apo A-1 is the main protein component of HDL.
Apo A-1 and lipid combine in the blood to form HDL and activate {{c1::lecithin acyltransferase (LCAT)}}.
LCAT is responsible for converting free cholesterol into cholesteryl esters.
{{c1::LCAT}} is responsible for converting free cholesterol into cholesteryl esters.
One important function of HDL is acting as a {{c1::reservoir for apolipoproteins}}, such as Apo C-II and Apo E.
Apo C-II activates lipoprotein lipase, while Apo E is needed for endocytosis of some lipoproteins.
HDL is involved in the uptake of {{c1::unesterified cholesterol}}, which it collects from other lipoprotein particles and cell membranes.
This process helps HDL's mature from its nascent discoidal form into a spherical shape.
Cholesterol is esterified by {{c1::lecithin acyltransferase (LCAT)}} or {{c1::phosphatidylcholine acyltransferase (PCAT)}} upon uptake.
LCAT is activated by Apo A-1 and converts free cholesterol into cholesteryl esters, making it more hydrophobic.
LCAT is activated by {{c1::Apo A-1}} and converts free cholesterol into cholesteryl esters, making it more hydrophobic.
As cholesteryl ester content increases, HDL transitions to {{c1::HDL3}} and then to a round micellar-like particle {{c1::HDL2}}.
This transition is part of HDL maturation, which increases its capacity to carry cholesterol.
{{c1::Cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP)}} transfers cholesteryl ester from HDL to VLDL in exchange for {{c2::TAG}}.
This exchange process converts VLDL to LDL and facilitates cholesterol transport to the liver.
A deficiency in CETP is associated with {{c1::increased HDL}} levels and {{c2::decreased LDL}} levels, creating an antiatherogenic profile.
High HDL and low LDL levels reduce the risk of atherosclerosis.
Cholesterol is transported to the liver via two routes: the {{c1::direct route}} and the {{c1::indirect route}}.
The direct route involves HDL cholesterol uptake by the liver, while the indirect route involves HDL-C ester transfer to ApoB-containing lipoproteins.
The direct route involves {{c1::HDL cholesterol}} uptake by the liver, while the indirect route involves {{c1::HDL-C ester transfer}} to ApoB-containing lipoproteins.
In the direct route, HDL cholesterol (HDL-C) is taken up by the liver through {{c1::hepatic lipase}} and other receptors like {{c1::SR-BI}}.
SR-BI is the scavenger receptor class B type I.
In the indirect route, HDL-C ester is transferred to {{c1::ApoB-containing lipoproteins}} in exchange for triglycerides.
These lipoproteins are then taken up by the liver via receptor-mediated endocytosis.
HDL's can alleviate {{c1::atherosclerosis}} and other cardiovascular diseases.
HDL helps <u>remove cholesterol from arteries</u>, reducing plaque buildup.
Reverse cholesterol transport involves HDL transferring cholesterol from {{c1::peripheral tissues}} to the {{c2::liver}} or {{c2::steroidogenic}} cells.
This process helps reduce peripheral cholesterol levels and lowers atherosclerosis risk.
HDL uses the {{c1::ATP-Binding Cassette A1 (ABCA1)}} transport protein to transfer cholesterol from {{c2::peripheral}} cells.
Deficiency in ABCA1 leads to Tangier Disease, characterized by low HDL levels.
Deficiency in ABCA1 leads to {{c1::Tangier Disease::Illness}}, characterized by low HDL levels.
The liver cell surface receptor {{c1::SR-B1}} binds HDL and transfers {{c2::cholesteryl esters}} into liver cells.
