SR-B1 plays a crucial role in hepatic cholesterol uptake and bile acid synthesis.
{{c2::Lipoprotein(a)}} is similar to LDL and contains an additional apolipoprotein called {{c1::apo(a)}} linked to {{c1::Apo B-100}}.
Lp(a) levels are increased by {{c1::trans fatty acids}} and decreased by {{c1::estrogen}}.
Lp(a) is structurally similar to {{c1::plasminogen}} and may increase heart disease risk by competing with {{c2::plasminogen}} for binding to {{c2::fibrin}}.
This competition slows down clot dissolution.

children.name: 05. Steroid Hormones & Variations of Genital Development

fields: The three classes of steroid hormones are {{c1::glucocorticoids}}, {{c1::mineralocorticoids}}, and {{c1::sex hormones}}
Steroid hormones are synthesized in the {{c1::adrenal cortex}}, {{c1::ovaries and placenta}}, and {{c1::testes}}

glucorticoids = cortisol 
mineralocorticoids = aldosterone
sex hormones = androgens, estrogens, progestins
Steroid hormones are transported by the blood complexed with {{c1::plasma proteins}} to target organs
The initial step of steroid hormone synthesis occurs on the {{c1::inner mitochondrial membrane}} and is the {{c1::rate-limiting step}}

The conversion of cholesterol to pregnenolone requires three enzymes:

1) {{c1::side-chain cleavage enzyme}}
2){{c1::cytochrome P450 (CYP) oxidase}}
3) {{c1::desmolase}}
The conversion of cholesterol to pregnenolone requires cofactors {{c1::NADPH}} and {{c1::O<sub>2</sub>}} for the reaction
{{c1::Pregnenolone}} and {{c1::progesterone}} serve as the parent compounds for all subsequent steroid hormones

Progesterone is further modified by {{c1::hydroxylation}} or {{c1::reduction}} reactions, which occur at different carbons on the steroid nucleus; these reactions are performed by {{c1::addition CYP enzymes::Enzyme}}
The receptor for steroid hormones is a {{c1::non-membrane associated cytoplasmic protein}}
Steroid hormones {{c1::passively}} diffuse into the cell and bind to their receptor, inducing translocation of the resulting complex into the {{c1::nucleus}}
The steroid hormone receptor also has {{c1::DNA binding}} capabilities
The ligand-receptor complex acts as a {{c1::transcriptional regulator}} to alter gene expression
The SRY gene is located on the {{c1::Y}} chromosome and drives the expression of genes required for the development of {{c1::male genitalia}} and inhibits the development of {{c1::female genitalia}}
In the absence of the Y chromosome and SRY, development proceeds into anatomical {{c1::female}}
SRY is a {{c1::transcription factor}} that drives the expression of genes required to produce {{c1::testosterone}} and subsequently anatomical male development

{{c1::Nondisjunction}} is the failure of sister chromatids to segregate properly during meiosis resulting in an improper number of chromosomes in the developing fetus; this may affect {{c1::sex development}}

Sex development may be altered by genetic alterations such as:

1) {{c1::nondisjunction}}
2) {{c1::the fertilization of one ovum by two sperm}}
3) {{c1::translocation of the male sex gene SRY onto the X chromosome in a subset of cells}}
4) {{c1::mutations in key proteins, receptors, or enzymes that alter their function}}
{{c1::Klinefelter Syndrome}} results from nondisjunction of the X chromosomes in either the ovum or sperm in {{c2::karyotypic males}}
The karyotype for Klinefelter Syndrome is typically {{c1::47, XXY}}, with more pronounced symptoms in {{c1::48, XXXY}} or {{c1::49, XXXXY}}
X chromosomes have a {{c1::pseudoautosomal region}} that is not silenced in daughter cells
Pseudoautosomal region is located at {{c1::telomere end of p arm [PAR1] and q arm [PAR2]}}
Clinical manifestations of Klinefelter Syndrome in children include: {{c1::weaker muscle strength}}, {{c1::taller}}, and {{c1::less muscle control}}
Clinical manifestations of Klinefelter Syndrome during puberty include: {{c1::less facial/body hair}}, {{c1::broader hips}}, and possible {{c1::breast development}}

Clinical manifestations of Klinefelter Syndrome in adulthood include: {{c1::an appearance similar to non-affected karyotypic males}}, {{c1::taller}}, {{c1::some level of gynecomastia}}, and {{c1::infertility}}
Potential karyotypes for Turner Syndrome include {{c1::45X}}, {{c1::46X del(Xp)}}, or {{c1::46Xi(Xq)}}

Clinical manifestations of Turner Syndrome include:
- {{c1::lymphedema}}
- {{c1::low set ears}}
- {{c1::short stature}}
- {{c1::rudimentary ovaries}}
- {{c1::amenorrhea}}
- {{c1::reproductive sterility}}
- {{c1::webbed neck}}
- {{c1::cardiac issues}}
{{c1::Ovotesticular Disorder}} is a condition where an individual is born with internal reproductive organs of both sexes that may be ovaries, testes, or ovotestes
Division of one ovum, followed by fertilization of each haploid ovum and fusion of the two zygotes early in development may result in {{c1::ovotesticular disorder::what disorder}}
The fertilization of an ovum by two sperm followed by trisomic rescue in one or more daughter cells may result in {{c1::ovotesticular disorder::what disorder}}
Two ova may be fertilized by two sperm to produce one male and one female zygote; if these zygotes fuse to form a tetragametic zygote, {{c1::ovotesticular disorder::what disorder}} may result

The clinical manifestations of ovotesticular disorder may include:
- {{c1::presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue}}
- {{c1::ambiguous genitalia ranging from anatomic male to anatomic female in appearance}}
- {{c1::underdeveloped uterus, if present}}
- {{c1::hypospadia, if penis is present}}
- {{c1::undescended testicles, if present}}
hypospadia = opening of urethra not at tip of penis
{{c1::Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)}} results from mutations in enzymes involved in {{c2::the biosynthesis of steroid hormones from cholesterol}}
The {{c1::classic}}  form of CAH is the most severe and result from {{c2::severe loss}} or {{c2::inactivity of key enzymes}}
CAH follows an {{c1::autosomal recessive}} inheritance pattern
{{c1::Salt-wasting CAH}} results from a lack of {{c2::cortisol}} and {{c2::aldosterone}} leading to an inability to retain the correct amount of salt in the blood
{{c2::Non-salt wasting CAH}} allows for sufficient production of {{c1::aldosterone}}, but not {{c1::cortisol}}; the enzyme shortage is less severe
{{c1::Non-classic CAH}} is less severe and non-life threatening; results from a less severe loss or inactivity of key enzyme(s)

3-β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency (CAH) results in {{c1::hypospadia}} and {{c1::ambiguous genitalia}} in karyotypic males and {{c2::slight genital abnormalities}}, {{c2::irregular menstruation}}, and {{c2::impaired fertility}} in karyotypic females; both show {{c1::salt excretion}} in urine
hypospadia = opening of urethra not at tip of penis

17-α-hydroxylase deficiency (CAH) results in karyotypic males being born with {{c1::female genitalia but no internal anatomic female organs}} with a complete deficiency or {{c1::ambiguous genitalia}} with a partial deficiency

Karyotypic females with 17-α-hydroxylase deficiency (CAH) may have {{c1::no secondary sex characteristics}} and {{c1::amenorrhea}} with a complete deficiency or may develop {{c1::some secondary sex characteristics}} and {{c1::irregular menstruation}} with a partial deficiency
Both males and females with 17-α-hydroxylase deficiency (CAH) experience {{c1::infertility}}
21-α-hydroxylase deficiency (CAH) results in {{c1::nearly complete loss of the enzyme}} with {{c1::life-threatening salt wasting}} in severe (classic CAH) cases
Karyotypic females with 21-α-hydroxylase deficiency (classic CAH) may present with genitalia that appear {{c1::ambiguous}} or {{c1::male with unaffected internal female organs}}
Karyotypic males with 21-α-hydroxylase deficiency (classic CAH) have {{c1::unaffected male genitalia}}
The childhood onset variant of 21-α-hydroxylase deficiency (simple viralizing CAH) results in {{c1::residual}} enzyme activity with possible {{c1::genital ambiguities}}
Late onset 21-α-hydroxylase deficiency (classic CAH) results in a mild affect on {{c1::androgen}} levels and often goes {{c1::unrecognized in childhood}}

The classic form of 11-β1-hydroxylase deficiency (CAH) results in {{c1::ambiguous genitalia with unaffected internal organs}} in karyotypic females and {{c1::early onset puberty}} in both males and females

The non-classic form of 11-β1-hydroxylase deficiency (CAH) results in {{c1::unaffected}} genitalia with possible {{c1::excessive hair growth}}, and {{c1::irregular menstruation}} later in life in karyotypic females
Aromatase deficiency is an {{c1::autosomal recessive::what inheritance pattern}} disorder that results in the absence or inactivity of {{c2::aromatase}} preventing the production of {{c2::estrogen}}
{{c1::Neonatal}} karyotypical females with aromatase deficiency present with {{c2::ambiguous genitalia with internal female organs}}
{{c1::Pubescent}} karyotypic females with aromatase deficiency present with {{c2::virilization}}, {{c2::absence of growth spurt}}, and {{c2::delayed puberty}}
{{c1::Adult}} karyotypic females with aromatase deficiency present with {{c2::absent breasts}}, {{c2::amenorrhea}}, and {{c2::infertility}}

In karyotypic males, aromatase deficiency results in {{c1::tall stature}} and potential medical conditions like {{c1::type II diabetes}}, {{c1::lipid metabolism disorders}}, and {{c1::liver function impairments}}
During pregnancy, placental aromatase deficiency may cause the mother to become {{c1::virilized}} with increased {{c1::circulating testosterone}}
5α-reductase deficiency is an {{c2::autosomal recessive::what inheritance pattern}} disorder that results in the loss or inactivity of the enzyme converts {{c1::testosterone}} to {{c1::DHT}}
5α-reductase deficiency affects male genital development, causing birth with {{c1::anatomic female appearing genitalia}},  {{c1::ambiguous genitalia}} or {{c1::micropenis and hypospadia}}
hypospadia = opening of urethra not at tip of penis

At puberty, individuals with 5α-reductase deficiency may have increased levels of {{c2::testosterone}} causing {{c1::deepening of the voice}}, {{c1::growth spurt}}, and {{c1::enlargement of the penis and scrotum}}
{{c2::Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS)}} is an {{c2:: X-linked recessive::what inheritance pattern}} condition  where the {{c1::androgen receptor}} is unresponsive to {{c1::testosterone}}
e.g., unable to bind and/or transmit the signal
Individuals with Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome are karyotypically {{c1::XY}}

Complete Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (CAIS) is caused by {{c2::full loss of function of androgen receptor}} and results in individuals having the external anatomical characteristics of {{c1::females}} but lacking a {{c1::uterus}} and {{c1::undescended testes}} with a small risk of becoming cancerous later in life

Partial Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (PAIS) results in genitalia that may appear anatomically {{c1::female}}, {{c1::male}}, or {{c1::ambiguous}} depending on nature of mutation; individuals may experience {{c2::breast enlargement}} at puberty

Examples of issues that people born with variable genital development may face:

- {{c1::emotional and physical consequences of having undergone irreversible surgical interventions}}
- {{c1::gender confusion}}, {{c1::sexual orientation confusion}}
- {{c1::fear of intimacy}}
- {{c1::poor sexual functioning}}
- {{c1::mistrust of medical profession/parents}}

children.name: 06. Amino Acid and Nitrogen Disposal - Urea Cycle

fields: The incidence of urea cycle disorders in the United States is predicted to be 1 patient for every {{c1::35,000}} births.
This translates to about 113 new patients per year across all age groups.
The body maintains a constant amount of protein because the rate of protein {{c1::synthesis}} matches the rate of degradation.
In healthy adults, {{c1::300-400}}g of protein is synthesized and degraded daily.
Pathways of protein degradation include the {{c1::Ubiquitin/26S proteasome}} and the {{c2::lysosome (autophagy)}}.
Autophagy includes microautophagy, macroautophagy, and chaperone-mediated microautophagy.
In the Ubiquitin/26S proteasome pathway, proteins tagged with {{c1::ubiquitin}} are recognized and degraded by the proteasome.
The proteasome unfolds ubiquitinated proteins and transports them to its proteolytic core.
The N-end rule indicates that proteins with {{c1::valine}} at the N-terminus are long-lived, while those with {{c1::glutamine}} are short-lived.
This rule correlates the half-life of proteins with their N-terminal residues.

(Proline, Glutamate, Serine, Threonine)

These sequences mark proteins for proteolysis.
{{c1::Post-translational}} modifications, such as phosphorylation, dephosphorylation, and SUMOylation, act as signals for protein degradation.
These modifications regulate protein turnover by the proteasome.
{{c1::Macroautophagy}} involves the formation of a phagophore that expands into a double-membrane autophagosome capable of fusing with the lysosome.
Macroautophagy is a major process of lysosome-mediated protein degradation.
In {{c1::chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA)}}, proteins with a consensus peptide sequence are recognized by the hsc70-containing chaperone complex for translocation to the {{c2::lysosome}}.
This process allows for non-selective protein degradation within lysosomes.
The Ubiquitin/26S proteasome degrades {{c1::short}}-lived proteins in cells.
It targets proteins marked for degradation by ubiquitin tagging.
The lysosome (autophagy) degrades {{c1::long}}-lived proteins through processes like macroautophagy, microautophagy, and chaperone-mediated autophagy.
Autophagy is essential for the breakdown of cellular components over longer periods.
Digestion of dietary proteins begins in the stomach with the activation of {{c1::pepsin}} by {{c2::HCl}}.
Pepsinogen is converted to pepsin in an acidic environment.
Enteropeptidase (also called enterokinase) activates pancreatic {{c1::zymogens}} in the {{c2::small intestine}}.
Enteropeptidase initiates the activation cascade of proteases such as trypsin.
The hormones {{c1::CCK}} and {{c1::secretin}} stimulate the pancreas to secrete protease enzymes.
These hormones are released in response to the presence of dietary protein in the small intestine.
Amino acids and dipeptides are absorbed into enterocytes via {{c1::Na⁺}}-linked transport for free amino acids and {{c1::H⁺}}-linked transport for di- and tripeptides.
These transport mechanisms facilitate amino acid uptake from the intestinal lumen.
Primary intestinal {{c1::enteropeptidase}} deficiency leads to severe protein malabsorption, poor growth, and development.
Enteropeptidase deficiency is confirmed by biochemical analysis showing absent enzyme activity in the duodenum.
{{c1::Primary intestinal enteropeptidase}} deficiency is characterized by the total absence of enteropeptidase activity in the small intestine.
It leads to severe protein malabsorption, poor growth, and development.
{{c1::Enteropeptidase}} deficiency results in very low proteolytic activity in native duodenal juice.
Normal levels of proteolytic activity can be induced in vitro using porcine enteropeptidase.
{{c1::Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (EPI)}} results in a lack of pancreatic enzymes, causing incomplete digestion of {{c2::fats}} and {{c2::proteins}}.
This condition leads to undigested lipids (steatorrhea) and proteins in the feces.
{{c1::Cystinuria}} is a disorder of the {{c2::proximal tubule’s::Location}} reabsorption of {{c3::cystine}}, {{c3::ornithine}}, {{c3::arginine}}, and {{c3::lysine}}.
Cystinuria leads to accumulation and precipitation of cystine stones in the urinary tract.
The defective transport system in {{c1::cystinuria}} decreases reabsorption of {{c2::basic}} or {{c2::positively charged}} amino acids, such as cystine, ornithine, arginine, and lysine.
Mutations in the genes coding for this transport system cause amino acids to be concentrated in the urine.
Dietary restriction of {{c1::methionine}} is recommended in cystinuria to reduce cystine production.
Methionine is a precursor in the biochemical pathway leading to cystine formation.
It involves a different amino acid transport defect than cystinuria.
{{c1::Cystinosis}} is distinct from cystinuria and results from a defect in the transport of cysteine out of {{c2::lysosomes}}.
This defect leads to cysteine crystal accumulation within lysosomes and tissue damage.
Nitrogen from amino acids is ultimately converted into {{c1::urea}} and excreted.
This process plays a crucial role in amino acid metabolism.
{{c1::Aminotransferase}} enzymes, along with {{c2::pyridoxal phosphate (PLP)}}, facilitate the transamination process.
Glutamate acts as the main carrier of amino groups in amino acid metabolism.
{{c1::Lysine}} and {{c1::threonine}} do not undergo transamination but lose their amino groups via {{c2::deamination}}.
This makes them exceptions in the transamination process.
{{c2::Aminotransferases}} transfer amino groups from one {{c1::carbon skeleton}} to another.
Each aminotransferase is specific to one or a few amino group donors.
Elevated levels of plasma {{c1::aminotransferases}} indicate potential liver diseases, viral hepatitis, toxic injury, or other conditions.
Low levels are typically found in healthy individuals.
{{c1::Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)}} is found in many tissues, especially in the liver, and catalyzes the transfer of the amino group from alanine to glutamate.
{{c1::Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)}} is predominantly found in the liver and transfers amino groups from glutamate to oxaloacetate.
AST is an exception to the general rule that amino transferases form glutamate.
Aminotransferases transfer amino groups to {{c1::pyridoxal phosphate (PLP)}}, the active form of Vitamin {{c2::B6}}.
PLP is covalently linked to the ε-amino group of a lysine residue at the enzyme's active site.
Pyridoxamine phosphate reacts with {{c1::α-keto acid}} to form a new amino acid and the {{c2::aldehyde}} form of PLP.
This is the second step in the transamination reaction mechanism.
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) catalyzes the transfer of an amino group from {{c1::alanine}} to {{c1::α-ketoglutarate}}, forming {{c2::pyruvate}} and {{c2::glutamate}}.
This reaction is essential for amino acid catabolism.
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) transfers an amino group from {{c1::aspartate}} to {{c1::α-ketoglutarate}}, forming {{c2::oxaloacetate}} and {{c2::glutamate}}.
AST is involved in both amino acid and nitrogen metabolism.
{{c1::Oxidative deamination}} is the process by which glutamate releases its amino group as ammonia (NH₃).
This reaction is catalyzed by glutamate dehydrogenase and involves NAD⁺ or NADP⁺ as coenzymes.
The sequential action of {{c1::transamination}} and {{c1::oxidative deamination}} of glutamate allows for the release of amino groups as ammonia (NH₃) from most amino acids.
This pathway is crucial for nitrogen disposal in the body.
{{c1::Glutamate dehydrogenase}} catalyzes the oxidative deamination of glutamate, converting it to α-ketoglutarate.
The reaction produces NADH or NADPH, depending on the coenzyme used.
The end products of oxidative deamination by glutamate dehydrogenase are {{c1::α-ketoacid}} and {{c1::ammonia}}.
α-Ketoacid enters energy metabolism, while ammonia serves as a nitrogen source in urea synthesis.
{{c1::GTP}} acts as an allosteric inhibitor, while {{c1::ADP}} activates glutamate dehydrogenase.
GTP inhibits the enzyme, while ADP signals low cellular energy, promoting enzyme activity.
Glutamate dehydrogenase uses {{c1::NAD⁺}} for oxidative deamination or {{c1::NADPH}} for reductive amination.
NAD⁺ leads to ammonia loss, while NADPH results in ammonia gain.
High {{c1::glutamate}} levels, often seen after a protein-rich meal, shift reactions toward amino acid {{c2::degradation}} and ammonia {{c2::formation}}.
High levels of {{c1::ammonia}} drive the reaction toward glutamate synthesis via {{c2::reductive amination}}.
This mechanism helps manage excess nitrogen by converting it to glutamate.
{{c1::D-amino acids}} are found in plants, cell walls of microorganisms, and can be synthesized from L-amino acids by racemases.
Racemases require pyridoxal phosphate as a cofactor in humans.
{{c1::D-aspartate (D-Asp)::D-amino acid}} plays a role in the development of the nervous and endocrine systems.
D-Asp has significant physiological functions related to hormone regulation.
{{c1::D-serine (D-Ser)::D-amino acid}} plays a regulatory role in the central nervous system and is associated with learning, memory, and behavior.
D-Ser is a co-agonist of the NMDA receptor, impacting synaptic plasticity and neurotoxicity.
{{c1::D-amino acid oxidases (DAO)}} are {{c2::FAD}}-dependent enzymes that catalyze the oxidative deamination of D-amino acids, producing α-keto acids and ammonia.
Dysfunction of DAO has been linked to schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, Alzheimer's disease, and ALS.
{{c1::D-serine::D-amino acid}} acts as a potent co-agonist of the {{c2::NMDA glutamate}} receptor, contributing to glutamate-induced neurotoxicity.
This involvement in NMDA receptor activity links it to neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative conditions.
This reaction occurs in most tissues to detoxify ammonia, which is toxic to cells.
Ammonia is transported to the liver as {{c1::glutamine}} for conversion to {{c2::urea}}.
Glutamine acts as a safe carrier of ammonia in the bloodstream.
In the liver, {{c1::glutaminase}} converts glutamine back to glutamate, releasing {{c2::ammonia}}.
The released ammonia enters the urea cycle for detoxification and excretion.
The {{c1::glucose-alanine}} cycle helps muscles remove toxic ammonia by converting it to alanine.
Alanine transports ammonia to the liver, where it is used for gluconeogenesis and urea production.
Mechanism 1 of ammonia transport from muscle involves {{c1::glutamine synthetase}}, which combines {{c2::ammonia}} with {{c2::glutamate}} to form glutamine.
This mechanism detoxifies ammonia in muscle tissues by converting it into a non-toxic form.
Mechanism 2 involves the formation of {{c1::alanine}} by transamination of {{c2::pyruvate}}, which is produced from glycolysis and the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids.
Alanine carries ammonia from muscles to the liver, where it is converted back to pyruvate.
In the liver, {{c1::alanine}} is converted to {{c2::pyruvate}}, which enters gluconeogenesis, generating glucose.
The glucose is then sent back to the muscles to sustain glycolysis, completing the cycle.
The {{c1::urea cycle}} is the major disposal pathway for amino groups derived from amino acids.
It accounts for about 90% of the nitrogen-containing components in urine.
One nitrogen of the urea molecule is supplied by {{c1::free NH₃}}, while the second nitrogen is supplied by {{c1::aspartate}}.
Glutamate provides ammonia through oxidative deamination, while aspartate nitrogen is provided via transamination of oxaloacetate.
The carbon and oxygen of urea are derived from {{c1::CO₂}}.
Carbon dioxide contributes to the structure of urea, linking nitrogen disposal to carbon metabolism.
Urea is produced in the {{c1::liver}} and transported through the blood to the kidneys for excretion.
This process helps regulate nitrogen levels in the body and prevent ammonia toxicity.
The urea cycle involves {{c1::2::#}} reactions in the mitochondria and {{c1::3::#}} reactions in the cytosol.
This distribution allows the cycle to function across different cellular compartments.
{{c1::Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I}} is the first enzyme of the urea cycle and requires {{c2::N-acetylglutamate}} as an allosteric activator.
This enzyme catalyzes the formation of carbamoyl phosphate from ammonia and bicarbonate.
{{c1::Citrulline}} is synthesized in the mitochondria and transported to the cytosol for further steps in the urea cycle.
{{c1::Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I::Enzyme}} catalyzes the formation of {{c2::carbamoyl phosphate}} from ammonia, bicarbonate, and ATP.
This is the first step of the urea cycle and occurs in the mitochondria.
Synthetases use high-energy nucleoside triphosphates such as {{c1::ATP}} or {{c1::GTP}} to create molecules.
In contrast, synthases facilitate the creation of molecules without using ATP.
{{c1::N-acetylglutamate}} is synthesized from {{c2::acetyl-CoA}} and {{c2::glutamate}} by {{c3::N-acetylglutamate synthase}}.
N-acetylglutamate is an allosteric activator of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I.
Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I in the {{c1::mitochondria}} uses {{c2::2 ATP}}, {{c2::NH₃}}, and {{c2::CO₂}} to produce carbamoyl phosphate.
NH₃ for carbamoyl phosphate synthesis primarily comes from the oxidative deamination of {{c1::glutamate}} by mitochondrial {{c1::glutamate dehydrogenase}}.
This process contributes free ammonia for urea cycle initiation.
{{c1::Ornithine transcarbamoylase}} uses {{c2::carbamoyl phosphate}} to form {{c3::citrulline}} in the mitochondria.
Citrulline is then exported to the cytosol, and ornithine is regenerated later.
{{c1::Ornithine}} and {{c1::citrulline}}, basic amino acids, are not used for protein synthesis as they lack corresponding codons.
These amino acids are primarily intermediates in the urea cycle.
{{c1::Argininosuccinate synthetase}} catalyzes the formation of {{c2::argininosuccinate}} from {{c3::citrulline}} and {{c3::aspartate}} in the cytosol.
This reaction is the third and final ATP-requiring step of the urea cycle.
The cleavage of {{c1::argininosuccinate}} by {{c2::argininosuccinate lyase}} produces {{c3::arginine}} and {{c3::fumarate}}.
This reaction occurs in the cytosol and is part of the urea cycle.
{{c1::Fumarate}} produced in the urea cycle is hydrated to {{c2::malate}} and then oxidized to {{c3::oxaloacetate}}.
Oxaloacetate can be transaminated back to aspartate, linking the urea and TCA cycles.
This reaction occurs almost exclusively in the liver and is the final step of the urea cycle.
Urea produced in the liver diffuses to the kidneys for excretion, but some urea is cleaved to NH₃ and CO₂ by bacterial {{c1::urease}} in the intestines.
This process contributes to ammonia recycling and can affect blood ammonia levels.
Patients with reduced kidney function may experience elevated circulating {{c1::urea}} levels, increasing the risk of ammonia poisoning.
Antibiotics can reduce intestinal bacteria, lowering ammonia levels in these patients.
The urea cycle is irreversible because it consumes {{c1::four}} high-energy phosphates for each molecule of urea produced.
This energy requirement ensures that the cycle drives forward.
Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I uses {{c1::2::#}} ATP molecules to form carbamoyl phosphate from CO₂ and NH₃.
This reaction is the initial step of the urea cycle and occurs in the mitochondria.
Argininosuccinate synthetase uses {{c1::1::#}} ATP to form argininosuccinate from citrulline and aspartate.
This step occurs in the cytosol and represents the third ATP-consuming reaction of the urea cycle.
The urea cycle takes in {{c1::3}} ATPs and produces {{c1::2}} ADPs and {{c1::1}} AMP. Since AMP is equivalent to {{c2::2}} ATPs, the total energy cost is {{c2::4}} ATPs per urea molecule produced.
The high energy cost makes the urea cycle energetically irreversible.
Ammonia from glutamine is released in the liver and kidneys by {{c1::renal glutaminase}}, and in enterocytes by {{c1::intestinal glutaminase}}.
Glutamine from blood or dietary proteins contributes to this ammonia source.
Ammonia is formed from urea by {{c1::bacterial urease}} in the intestine, and then transported to the liver for conversion back to urea.
This recycling process helps regulate nitrogen balance.
Ammonia arises from amines through the action of {{c1::amine oxidase}} on dietary amines and monoamines like neurotransmitters.
This pathway contributes to overall nitrogen metabolism.
{{c1::Glutamine}} acts as a non-toxic form of ammonia and removes ammonia from tissues, including the brain.
It is synthesized by glutamine synthetase and transports ammonia safely in the blood.
Ammonia in circulation is converted to {{c1::glutamine}} or enters the urea cycle in the liver for detoxification.
Glutamine formation occurs in most tissues, while urea synthesis occurs mainly in the liver.
{{c1::N-acetylglutamate (NAG)}} is an <u>activator</u> of {{c2::carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I}}.
NAG is essential for initiating the urea cycle by activating the first enzyme.
{{c1::N-acetylglutamate synthase}} catalyzes the formation of N-acetylglutamate from {{c2::acetyl-CoA}} and {{c2::glutamate}}.
This synthesis is crucial for regulating urea cycle activity.
A high-protein diet increases levels of both {{c1::N-acetylglutamate}} and {{c1::glutamate}}, leading to an increase in urea cycle activity.
The increased protein intake stimulates nitrogen disposal through the urea cycle.
The two major causes of hyperammonemia are {{c1::acquired}} and {{c2::congenital}} hyperammonemia.
Hyperammonemia is characterized by elevated levels of ammonia in the blood.
It results from impaired liver function, reducing ammonia detoxification.
{{c1::Congenital}} hyperammonemia is caused by genetic deficiencies in urea cycle enzymes (all five enzymes).
This condition leads to ineffective ammonia detoxification from birth.
Defects in any of these enzymes can lead to hyperammonemia.
Early signs of hyperammonemia in neonates include lethargy, irritability, poor feeding, vomiting, seizures, and {{c1::grunting respiration}}.
These symptoms result from elevated ammonia levels affecting the central nervous system.
{{c1::Ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC)}} deficiency is the most common urea cycle disorder.
It results in impaired conversion of carbamoyl phosphate and ornithine to citrulline in the urea cycle.

OTC deficiency is characterized by {{c1::low}} BUN, {{c1::low}} blood arginine, {{c2::undetectable}} blood citrulline, {{c3::elevated}} blood ammonia, {{c3::elevated}} blood glutamine, and {{c3::elevated}} orotic acid.
Elevated orotic acid results from excess carbamoyl phosphate entering the pyrimidine synthesis pathway.
Hyperammonemia is a symptom of OTC deficiency, but not of {{c1::UMPS}} deficiency.
{{c1::Argininosuccinate synthetase}} deficiency, also known as {{c1::citrullinemia type 1 (CTLN1)}}, leads to the accumulation of {{c2::citrulline}} in the blood and urine.
CTLN1 occurs in approximately 1 in 57,000 births and impairs the conversion of citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate.
CTLN1 can present as a {{c1::neonatal acute}} (classic) form (Type I), which can be detected by newborn screening.
Early detection is crucial to prevent hyperammonemia and brain damage.
In some cases, CTLN1 remains {{c1::asymptomatic}}, while in others, there is a {{c2::late-onset}} form (Type II) that begins during or after pregnancy.
The late-onset form of CTLN1 presents distinct clinical challenges compared to the neonatal form.
{{c1::Argininosuccinate lyase}} deficiency leads to the accumulation of {{c2::argininosuccinate}} in argininosuccinic aciduria.
This condition impairs the conversion of argininosuccinate to arginine and fumarate in the urea cycle.
Argininosuccinic aciduria is part of newborn screening and is diagnostic for {{c1::argininosuccinate lyase}} deficiency.
In severe and late-onset cases, it may be associated with neurologic abnormalities, developmental delays, and cognitive impairment.
{{c1::Arginase-I}} deficiency, also called argininemia or hyperargininemia, leads to the accumulation of arginine in the blood and urine.
This condition impairs the conversion of arginine to urea and ornithine in the final step of the urea cycle.
Hyperammonemia in arginase deficiency is often {{c1::less}} severe because arginine contains {{c2::two}} waste nitrogens and can be excreted in the urine.
Arginine's ability to carry excess nitrogen reduces ammonia levels compared to other urea cycle defects.

Patients with arginase deficiency may appear healthy at birth, with normal development in the first {{c1::1}} to {{c1::3}} years. Symptoms such as developmental delays and intellectual disability may appear later.
Hyperammonemia may be episodic and triggered by high-protein meals, stress, or fasting.
{{c1::N-acetylglutamate synthase (NAGS)}} deficiency impairs the production of {{c2::N-acetylglutamate}} from {{c3::acetyl-CoA}} and {{c3::glutamate}}.
N-acetylglutamate is an essential activator of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I, initiating the urea cycle.
{{c1::N-acetylglutamate synthase}} deficiency results in developmental delays and intellectual disability, with less severe forms being episodic, triggered by high-protein meals, stress, or fasting.
Symptoms are due to impaired ammonia detoxification.
{{c1::N-carbamylglutamate}} ({{c2::Carbaglu}}), a synthetic analog of {{c3::N-acetylglutamate}}, can activate CPS-I and is FDA-approved in the US and EU.
It is used as a treatment for NAGS deficiency to promote urea cycle activity.
The {{c1::hyperinsulinism/hyperammonemia (HI/HA)}} syndrome is caused by a {{c2::gain-of-function}} mutation in {{c3::glutamate dehydrogenase}}.
This mutation reduces sensitivity to the allosteric inhibitor GTP, leading to increased enzyme activity.
Limiting {{c1::protein}} intake in the diet is a key strategy to prevent protein catabolism in hyperammonemia management.
This reduces the production of ammonia by limiting the breakdown of amino acids.
Ammonia scavenging drugs like {{c1::phenylbutyrate}} conjugate with {{c2::glutamine}} to reduce ammonia levels.
Phenylbutyrate is converted to phenylacetate, which binds glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine, aiding in nitrogen excretion.
{{c1::Benzoate}} binds to glycine and facilitates the excretion of ammonia as hippurate.
This approach reduces glycine and glutamine, helping to lower blood ammonia levels.
{{c1::Arginine}} supplements are necessary in some urea cycle disorders, as {{c1::arginine}} becomes an essential amino acid.
This is particularly relevant in conditions where the urea cycle is disrupted, preventing endogenous arginine synthesis.
{{c1::Phenylbutyrate}} and {{c1::benzoate}} are not effective in patients with {{c2::acquired}} hyperammonemia, such as those with liver cirrhosis.
Both urea and glutamine production are reduced in acquired hyperammonemia, limiting the drugs' effectiveness.
Drug conjugation with phenylbutyrate and benzoate requires a {{c1::healthy}} liver to perform the reactions necessary for ammonia detoxification.
Liver dysfunction impairs the conversion of these drugs to hippurate and phenylacetylglutamine.

List the glucogenic amino acid intermediates:
  1. {{c1::α-ketoglutarate}}
  2. {{c1::Oxaloacetate}}
  3. {{c1::Pyruvate}}
  4. {{c1::Fumarate}}
  5. {{c1::Succinyl CoA}}

List the ketogenic amino acid intermediates:
  1. {{c1::Acetyl CoA}}
  2. {{c1::Acetoacetate}}
Ketogenic amino acids are unable to be converted to glucose as both carbon atoms in the ketone body are ultimately degraded to {{c1::CO2}} in the {{c2::TCA cycle}}.
{{c1::Methotraxate}} is an antifolate drug that inhibits {{c2::dihydofolate reductase}}.
Folate is reduced to {{c1::dihydrofolate (DHF)}} and then {{c2::THF}} by {{c3::dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR)}}.
Dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) requires {{c1::NADPH}} as a cofactor.
{{c1::THF}} is the central compound in 1-carbon metabolism.

It can carry many forms of carbon, but only one at a time.
  • Methyl (-CH3)
  • Methylene (-CH2-)
  • Formyl (-CH=O)
  • Formimino (-CH=NH)
  • Methenyl
Biotin can only transfer carbon in the form of {{c1::carbon dioxide}}.
Conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine requires {{c1::SAM::1-carbon pool}}.
Asparaginase is an anti-cancer drug that kills cancer cells via {{c1::asparagine deprivation}}.

Cancer cells, especially leukemic cells, cannot produce enough asparagine; thus, asparagine levels are low in cancer patients. Asparaginase further breaks down asparagine, causing cancer cells to die from asparagine deprivation.
Arginine is converted into ornithine by {{c1::arginase}}, which is converted into glutamate by {{c1::aminotransferase}}.
Histidinemia is caused by a mutation in the gene coding for {{c1::histidase}}.

Autosomal Recessive

Histidinemia typically causes no health problems, and most people with elevated histidine levels are unaware that they have this condition.
Alanine is a major gluconeogenic amino acid
Glycine is converted to {{c1::serine}} via {{c2::serine hydroxymethyltransferase}}.

This reaction provides the largest part of the one-carbon units available to the cell.

NOTE: N5,N10-Methylenetetrahydrofolate and Tetrahydrofolate (THF) are involved!

Serine can then be converted into pyruvate via serine dehydratase.

Or glycine could be oxidized CO2 and NH3.
{{c1::Benzoate}} is a drug that binds to {{c2::glycine}} in the treatment of hyperammonemia.
{{c1::Cystine}} is a dimeric amino acid formed by the oxidation of two {{c2::Cysteine}} residues which covalently link to make a disulphide bond.
Branched chain amino acids are {{c1::essential}} amino acids.
Branched chain amino acids are metabolized primarily by {{c1::peripheral}} tissues.
Catabolism of branched chain amino acids uses branched-chain {{c1::α-keto aminotransferase::enzyme}} and {{c1::α-keto dehydrogenase::enzyme}}.
Maple syrup disease results in accumulation of amino acids and their keto acids, which interferes with {{c1::brain}} function.
Characterized by feeding problems, vomiting, dehydration, severe metabolic acidosis, and a characteristic maple syrup odor to the urine.
Maple syrup disease is sometimes referred to as {{c1::BCKD}} defects.

What happens if E3 is deficient in BCKD?

{{c1::The E3 component is shared among all three enzymes. Therefore, mutation in E3 affects all three enzymes and results in classic maple syrup disease.}}
Individuals with MSUD must remain on a protein-restricted diet that limits {{c1::branched-chain amino acid}} intake.
No individual with MSUD has been treated solely with thiamine.
Methylmalonic CoA mutase deficiency causes metabolic {{c1::acidosis}} and developmental problems.
{{c1::Methionine}} is special because it is converted to {{c2::SAM}}, the major methyl-group donor in one-carbon metabolism.
Source of homocysteine, a precursor for cysteine, and cystine.
SAM is a high-energy compound that is unusual in that it contains no {{c1::phosphate}}.
The synthesis of SAM is driven by {{c1::all three}} phosphate bonds in ATP.
If there is a {{c1::deficiency}} of methionine, {{c2::homocysteine}} is converted into methionine.
If methionine stores are {{c1::adequate}}, homocysteine enters the {{c2::transsulfuration}} pathway, where it is converted into {{c3::cysteine}}.
{{c1::Cysteine}} is not an essential amino acid as long as sufficient {{c2::methionine}} is available.
Elevated {{c1::homocysteine (Hcy)}} levels in pregnant women usually indicate a deficiency in {{c2::folic acid}}.
Homocystinuria is a disease caused by {{c1::cystathionine synthase}} deficiency.

Accumulation of homocysteine in the liver

Symptoms:
  • Dislocation of the lens (Characteristic)
  • Mental retardation
  • Osteoporosis
  • MI

Accumulation of cystathionine and its metabolites.
No clinical symptoms are present.

Homocysteine inhibits the formation of the three main structural components of the artery:
  1. {{c1::Collagen}}
  2. {{c1::Elastin}}
  3. {{c1::Proteoglycans}}
Homocysteine permanently degrades {{c1::cysteine disulfide bridges}} and {{c1::lysine}} amino acid residues in proteins.
{{c1::Cystinurea}}: defect in the transport system of the proximal tubule of the kidney.
{{c1::Leucine}} and {{c1::lysine}} are exclussively ketogenic amino acids.
When {{c1::tryptophan}} is broken down, it forms {{c2::alanine}} and {{c2::acetoacetyl CoA}}.
One atom of molecular O2 becomes the hydroxyl group on tyrosine and the other is reduced to water.
Tyrosine is nonessential only in the presence of adequate dietary {{c1::phenylalanine}}.
Phenylketonuria is caused by a {{c1::phenylalanine hydroxylase}} deficiency.
It is a more common inborn error (1:15,000)
Phenylketonuria leads to an accumulation of {{c1::phenylalanine}} and deficiency of {{c1::tyrosine}}.
{{c1::Phenylketonuria (PKU)}} was the first disorder to benefit from newborn screenings and can be manageable if detected early in life.
The treatment for classical PKU is a {{c1::low phenylalanine}} diet alongside {{c1::tyrosine}} supplementation.
The treatment for non-classical PKU is {{c1::DOPA}} and {{c1::5-Hydroxy-trypotophan}} supplementation.
PKU often causes {{c1::hypopigmentation}} because tyrosine is required for melanin production.
PKU treatment must begin during first {{c1::7-10}} days of life to prevent mental retardation.
Methionine is classified as a/an {{c1::essential}} amino acid and {{c2::glucogenic}}.
Threonine is classified as a/an {{c1::essential}} amino acid and {{c2::glucogenic}}.
Valine is classified as a/an {{c1::essential}} amino acid and {{c2::glucogenic}}.
Isoleucine is classified as a/an {{c1::essential}} amino acid and {{c2::both glucogenic and ketogenic}}.
Phenylalanine is classified as a/an {{c1::essential}} amino acid and {{c2::both glucogenic and ketogenic}}.
Tryptophan is classified as a/an {{c1::essential}} amino acid and {{c2::both glucogenic and ketogenic}}.
Leucine is classified as a/an {{c1::essential}} amino acid and {{c2::ketogenic}}.
Lysine is classified as a/an {{c1::essential}} amino acid and {{c2::ketogenic}}.
Alanine is classified as a/an {{c1::non-essential}} amino acid and {{c2::glucogenic}}.
Arginine is classified as a/an {{c1::non-essential}} amino acid and {{c2::glucogenic}}.
Asparagine is classified as a/an {{c1::non-essential}} amino acid and {{c2::glucogenic}}.
Aspartate is classified as a/an {{c1::non-essential}} amino acid and {{c2::glucogenic}}.
Cysteine is classified as a/an {{c1::non-essential}} amino acid and {{c2::glucogenic}}.
Glutamate is classified as a/an {{c1::non-essential}} amino acid and {{c2::glucogenic}}.
Glutamine is classified as a/an {{c1::non-essential}} amino acid and {{c2::glucogenic}}.
Glycine is classified as a/an {{c1::non-essential}} amino acid and {{c2::glucogenic}}.
Histidine is classified as a/an {{c1::non-essential}} amino acid and {{c2::glucogenic}}.
Proline is classified as a/an {{c1::non-essential}} amino acid and {{c2::glucogenic}}.
Serine is classified as a/an {{c1::non-essential}} amino acid and {{c2::glucogenic}}.
The "one-carbon pool" refers to single carbon units attached to carrier compounds like {{c1::tetrahydrofolate (THF)}}, {{c2::S-adenosylmethionine (SAM)}}, and {{c3::biotin}}.
These single carbon units are essential for various biosynthetic and modification processes.
{{c1::THF}} transfers one-carbon units in the form of {{c2::methyl}}.
Tetrahydrofolate plays a crucial role in amino acid and nucleotide metabolism.
S-adenosylmethionine is a major methyl donor in biochemical reactions.
Biotin is a coenzyme in carboxylation reactions, critical for fatty acid synthesis and gluconeogenesis.
{{c1::Tetrahydrofolate (THF)}} is the active form of folate and is central to one-carbon metabolism.
{{c1::Methotrexate}} is an anticancer drug that inhibits {{c2::dihydrofolate (DHF) reductase}}.
{{c1::Dihydrofolate (DHF) reductase}} uses {{c2::NADPH}} as a cofactor to convert dihydrofolate to THF.
The conversion of {{c2::serine}} to {{c2::glycine}} requires the enzyme {{c1::serine hydroxymethyltransferase::Enzyme}} and {{c1::THF::Cofactor}}.
Folate deficiency can occur in alcoholics because alcohol affects {{c1::folate absorption}}.
Pregnant women are at risk for folate deficiency due to the increased folate demand during {{c1::rapid cell proliferation}} in embryos.

Genetic deficiencies leading to folate deficiency include:
  • {{c1::DHF reductase}} deficiency
  • {{c2::methylene THF reductase}} deficiency
  • {{c3::Formiminotransferase}} deficiency
  • {{c4::THF methyltransferase}} deficiency
{{c1::S-adenosylmethionine (SAM)}} is synthesized from {{c2::L-methionine}} using ATP and {{c3::S-adenosylmethionine synthetase::Enzyme}}.
After donating a methyl group, SAM is converted into {{c1::S-adenosylhomocysteine}}.
The enzyme responsible for converting norepinephrine to epinephrine is {{c1::Phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase (PNMT)}}.
{{c1::S-adenosylmethionine (SAM)}} is the methyl donor in the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine.
{{c1::Biotin (Vitamin B7)}} is a cofactor involved in the transfer of one carbon group in the form of {{c2::carbon dioxide}}.
Biotin serves as a cofactor for enzymes like {{c1::acetyl-CoA carboxylase}} and {{c2::pyruvate carboxylase}}.
In gluconeogenesis, {{c1::pyruvate carboxylase}} uses biotin to add carbon dioxide to pyruvate, forming {{c2::oxaloacetate}}.
{{c1::Asparagine}} and {{c1::Aspartate}} enter metabolism as {{c2::oxaloacetate}} in the TCA cycle.
{{c1::Asparaginase}} is an anti-cancer drug that depletes asparagine, starving cancer cells of this amino acid.
{{c1::Glutamine}} is converted to glutamate by the enzyme {{c2::glutaminase}}, releasing {{c2::ammonia (NH₃)}}.
The reaction controlled by glutamate dehydrogenase results in the production of {{c1::NADH}} or {{c1::NADPH}}, depending on the cofactor used.
{{c1::Proline}} is oxidized to {{c2::glutamate}}, which is then converted into {{c3::α-ketoglutarate}}.
{{c1::Arginine}} is converted to {{c2::ornithine}} by the enzyme {{c3::arginase}} in the liver.
This reaction is part of the urea cycle, which helps remove ammonia from the body.
The conversion of arginine to ornithine and α-ketoglutarate occurs primarily in the {{c1::liver::Organ}}.
{{c1::N-formiminoglutamate (FiGlu)}} is converted into glutamate with the help of {{c2::tetrahydrofolate (THF)::co-factor}}.
High levels of {{c1::N-formiminoglutamate (FiGlu)}} excretion after histidine ingestion is a diagnostic test for {{c2::folic acid}} deficiency.
Histidinemia is caused by a mutation in the gene that codes for the enzyme {{c1::histidase}}.
Histidine levels are {{c1::elevated}} in the {{c2::blood}} and {{c2::urine}} in individuals with histidinemia.
The enzyme {{c1::alanine aminotransferase}} converts alanine to pyruvate, while the cofactor {{c2::α-ketoglutarate}} is converted to {{c2::glutamate}}.
{{c1::Glycine}} is converted to {{c2::serine}} by the enzyme {{c2::serine hydroxymethyltransferase}}, using {{c3::tetrahydrofolate (THF)}} as a cofactor.
Serine is converted to {{c1::pyruvate}} via the enzyme {{c2::serine dehydratase}}.
{{c1::Benzoate}} binds to glycine to help remove excess ammonia by forming {{c2::hippurate}}.

Treats hyperammonemia
Hippurate is excreted in urine, aiding in nitrogen clearance.
This reaction takes place in the liver and initiates the pathway for either glycine regeneration or oxalate production.
Glyoxylate is transaminated back to {{c1::glycine}} by the enzyme {{c2::alanine-glyoxylate aminotransferase}}.
This reaction prevents the formation of oxalate and maintains glycine levels.
In the absence of {{c1::alanine-glyoxylate aminotransferase::Enzyme}}, glyoxylate is oxidized to {{c2::oxalate}}.
Oxalate accumulation leads to the formation of kidney stones
Hyperoxaluria type I is caused by a deficiency of {{c1::alanine-glyoxylate aminotransferase}} in the liver, leading to excess {{c2::oxalate}} and kidney damage.
This genetic disorder results in severe metabolic complications, including kidney stone formation.
{{c1::Cystine}} is reduced to cysteine using {{c2::NADH + H⁺}} as a reductant.
Tyrosine is metabolized into {{c1::fumarate}} and {{c1::acetoacetate}}, making it both glucogenic and ketogenic.
Phenylalanine is converted into {{c1::tyrosine}} by the enzyme {{c2::phenylalanine hydroxylase}}.
{{c1::Threonine}} is converted into {{c2::succinyl-CoA}} with the help of biotin and B12 cofactors.
{{c1::Leucine}}, {{c1::valine}}, and {{c1::isoleucine}} are metabolized via transamination and then oxidative decarboxylation.
All are branch chained amino acids

The enzymes responsible for Branched Chain Amino Acid catabolism are:
  • Transamination: {{c1::α-keto aminotransferase}}
  • Oxidative Decarboxylation: {{c1::α-keto dehydrogenase}}
{{c1::Maple syrup urine}} disease results from a mutation in one of the three components of the {{c2::branched-chain α-keto acid dehydrogenase (BCKD)}} complex, particularly the {{c3::E1}} subunit.
Vitamin B1 (thiamine pyrophosphate) can improve the activity of the enzyme in some patients.
A deficiency in {{c1::branched-chain α-keto acid dehydrogenase}} leads to the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids, causing {{c2::Maple Syrup Urine Disease}}.
This metabolic disorder causes severe metabolic acidosis and a characteristic maple syrup odor in the urine.

The major symptoms of Maple syrup urine disease are:
  • Build up of {{c1::Amino Acids}} & {{c1::Keto Acids}}
  • {{c2::Brain function impairment}}
Other symptoms include:feeding  problems, vomiting, dehydration, severe metabolic acidosis, and a characteristic maple syrup odor to the urine
{{c1::Classic}} MSUD is the most severe form, with BCKD activity less than {{c2::3%}}.
This phenotype is characterized by early onset of severe symptoms and high levels of BCAAs.
In {{c1::intermediate}} MSUD, BCKD activity ranges from {{c2::3% to 30%}}, with less severe symptoms compared to classic MSUD.
Neurological impairment is present, but acute metabolic decompensation is less common.
{{c1::Intermittent}} MSUD has normal early development, with symptoms triggered by stress or infection, and BCKD activity between {{c2::5% to 50%}}.
Initial symptoms typically appear between 5 months to 2 years.
{{c1::Thiamine-responsive}} MSUD improves with thiamine treatment, but thiamine alone cannot maintain low {{c2::BCAA}} levels.
A low-protein diet combined with thiamine supplementation helps manage symptoms.
{{c1::Type 2}} MSUD is caused by a mutation in the DBT gene, affecting the {{c2::E2}} subunit of the BCKD complex.
This mutation leads to dysfunctional branched-chain transacylase (E2).
{{c1::E3-deficient}} MSUD is due to a mutation in the DLD gene, which affects the {{c2::E3}} subunit of the BCKD complex.
This mutation causes dysfunction of dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase (E3).
Most individuals with MSUD are {{c1::compound heterozygotes}}, meaning they have two different mutant alleles of the BCKD complex gene.
{{c1::Methylmalonic acidemia (MMA)}} results from a <u>deficiency</u> in {{c2::methylmalonyl CoA mutase}}.
This metabolic disorder leads to elevated methylmalonic acid levels, metabolic acidosis, and developmental issues.
{{c1::Homocysteine}} can be converted to methionine or enter the transsulfuration pathway to form {{c2::cysteine}}.
The transsulfuration pathway involves vitamin B6 as a coenzyme.
Methionine is converted to {{c1::S-adenosylmethionine (SAM)}}, a key {{c2::methyl-group}} donor in one-carbon metabolism.
SAM is involved in numerous methylation reactions, including DNA, RNA, and protein methylation.
Elevated homocysteine levels in {{c1::pregnant women}} indicate folic acid deficiency and are associated with {{c2::neural tube defects}}.
A defect in the enzyme {{c1::cystathionine β-synthase}} results in {{c2::homocystinurea}}.
A defect in the enzyme {{c1::γ-cystathionase}} results in {{c2::cystathioninurea}}.

The major symptoms of homocystinurea are:
{{c1::Mental Retardation}}
{{c1::Osteoporosis}}
Also can have: Myocardial Infarctions or Lens Dislocation
Homocysteine permanently degrades {{c1::disulfide bridges}} and {{c1::lysine residues}} in proteins.
Homocysteine is described as a 'corrosive' of {{c1::long-living proteins}} like collagen and elastin.
Causes an increased risk of myocardial infarction
{{c1::Homocysteine}} inhibits the formation of collagen, elastin, and proteoglycans in arterial walls.
Causes an increased risk of myocardial infarction
Cystinuria is caused by a defect in {{c1::a transport system}} of the proximal tubule of the {{c2::kidney}}.
Cystinosis results from defects in a {{c1::lysosomal}} transporter.
It causes cystine accumulation within lysosomes of various tissues.
When tryptophan is catabolized, it produces {{c1::alanine}} and a {{c1::ketone body}}.
{{c1::Lysine::Amino Acid}} is unusual because it never undergoes transamination.
{{c1::Leucine}} and {{c1::lysine}} are amino acids that form {{c2::acetoacetyl CoA}} and {{c2::acetyl CoA}}.
Both are classified as ketogenic amino acids.
Nonessential amino acids are synthesized from {{c1::metabolic intermediates}} or from {{c1::essential amino acids}}.
Examples include pyruvate converting to alanine and phenylalanine converting to tyrosine.
Nonessential amino acids can also be synthesized by {{c1::amidation}} (e.g., {{c2::asparagine::AA}}, {{c2::glutamine::AA}}).
Amidation involves adding an amide group to a precursor molecule.
{{c1::Homocysteine}} is converted to {{c2::cysteine}} via {{c3::cystathionine β-synthase}} and {{c3::γ-cystathionase}}.
{{c1::Phenylketonuria (PKU)}} is caused by a <u>deficiency</u> of {{c2::phenylalanine hydroxylase}}.
This deficiency leads to an accumulation of phenylalanine and a deficiency of tyrosine.
A mutation in dihydropteridine reductase will force PHH to remain inactive & cause PKU
Classical PKU is caused by a deficiency of {{c1::phenylalanine hydroxylase}}.
It is managed by a low phenylalanine diet and tyrosine supplementation.
Non-classical PKU results from defects in {{c1::BH4 synthesis}}, affecting neurotransmitter production.
Management includes DOPA and 5-hydroxytryptophan supplementation to address the deficiency.
{{c1::Dihydropteridine (DHP) reductase}} deficiency leads to reduced synthesis of BH4, a critical cofactor.
BH4 is necessary for neurotransmitter production, affecting tyrosine, catecholamine, and serotonin synthesis.
{{c1::BH4::Cofactor}} is required by {{c2::phenylalanine hydroxylase}}, {{c2::tyrosine hydroxylase}}, and {{c2::tryptophan hydroxylase}} for neurotransmitter synthesis.
Tyrosine hydroxylase is involved in catecholamine synthesis, while tryptophan hydroxylase is involved in serotonin synthesis.
PKU is characterized by elevated {{c1::phenylalanine}} and metabolites like {{c2::phenylpyruvate}}, {{c3::phenylacetate}}, and {{c4::phenyllactate}} in tissue, plasma, and urine.
These metabolites contribute to the characteristic musty odor of urine in PKU.
CNS symptoms of PKU include {{c1::mental retardation}}, failure to {{c2::walk}} or {{c2::talk}}, and {{c3::microcephaly}}.
These symptoms result from elevated metabolites interfering with amino acid transport into the brain.
{{c2::Hypopigmentation}} in PKU is due to the inhibition of {{c1::tyrosinase::Enzyme}} by high phenylalanine levels.
Tyrosine is essential for melanin production.
PKU treatment includes {{c1::dietary protein restriction}}, {{c2::GMP with limited aromatic amino acids}}, {{c3::LNAA supplementation}}, and {{c4::BH4 analogs}}.
Tyrosinemia Type 1 is caused by a deficiency in {{c1::fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase}}.
This leads to the accumulation of fumarylacetoacetate and its metabolites, such as succinylacetone, in the urine.
Symptoms of Tyrosinemia Type 1 include {{c1::liver failure}} and {{c1::renal tubular acidosis}}.
Treatment for Tyrosinemia Type 1 includes dietary restriction of {{c1::phenylalanine}} and {{c1::tyrosine}}.
Alkaptonuria is caused by a deficiency in {{c1::homogentisic acid oxidase (HAO)}}.
Due to the oxidation of homogentisic acid to dark pigment.
Ochronosis is the deposition of dark pigment in connective tissues, particularly affecting cartilage.
The treatment for Alkaptonuria involves a {{c1::low-protein}} diet, restricting {{c2::phenylalanine}} and {{c2::tyrosine}} intake.
Albinism is due to a defect in {{c1::tyrosinase}}, leading to melanin deficiency.
Albinism can be inherited as {{c1::autosomal recessive}}, {{c1::autosomal dominant}}, or {{c1::X-linked}}.
Additional symptoms may include amblyopia (lazy eye) and changes in the retinal pigment epithelium.
{{c1::Dietary Reference Intake (DRI)}} provides estimates of nutrient amounts needed to prevent deficiencies and maintain optimal health.
DRI includes four different dietary reference standards for health maintenance.
{{c1::Estimated average requirement}} is the nutrient intake level estimated to meet the needs of 50% of healthy individuals.
This is one of the four DRI standards.
{{c1::Recommended dietary allowance (RDA)}} is the nutrient intake sufficient to meet the requirements of nearly all (97-98%) individuals.
RDA aims to cover the nutrient needs of almost all healthy individuals.
{{c1::Adequate intake}} is set when there is insufficient evidence to establish an RDA.
Adequate intake serves as a provisional guideline in the absence of RDA data.
The {{c1::tolerable upper intake level}} is the highest nutrient intake level likely to pose no risk of adverse health effects.
This standard helps to prevent nutrient overdose and toxicity.
Energy generated from nutrients is used for the {{c1::resting metabolic rate}}, {{c1::physical activity}}, and the {{c1::thermic effect of food}}.
{{c1::Resting metabolic rate (RMR)}} refers to energy expended by an individual at rest.
RMR involves energy required to maintain normal body functions like breathing and blood flow.
The {{c1::thermic effect of food}} refers to heat production during digestion and absorption.
This effect accounts for 5-10% of total energy expenditure, increasing nearly 30% during food digestion.
The thermic effect of food accounts for {{c1::5-10}}% of total energy expenditure, increasing nearly {{c1::30}}% during food digestion.
{{c1::Kwashiorkor}} is caused by protein deprivation greater than reduction in calories.
Often seen in children with carbohydrate-heavy diets, causing decreased synthesis of visceral proteins.
Symptoms of {{c1::Kwashiorkor}} include bilateral pitting edema, swollen belly, stunted growth, and depigmented hair.
Edema is due to low albumin, altering fluid distribution between blood and tissues.
{{c1::Marasmus}} results from greater calorie deprivation than protein intake reduction.
Often seen in developing countries where breast milk is replaced with cereal-based gruels.
{{c1::Marasmus}} symptoms include arrested growth, muscle wasting, and subcutaneous fat depletion (emaciation).
Unlike Kwashiorkor, marasmus does not present with edema.
{{c1::Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)}} serves as an intermediary in the formation or degradation of alpha-ketols.
This is its basic molecular mechanism.
The biologically active form of Thiamine is {{c1::Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)}}.
TPP is crucial for energy metabolism.
Key metabolic pathways using TPP include {{c1::pyruvate dehydrogenase}}, {{c1::alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase}}, {{c1::BCKD}} and {{c1::transketolase}}.
These pathways link glycolysis to the TCA cycle and are part of the pentose phosphate pathway.
Nutritional sources of Thiamine include {{c1::whole grains}}, {{c1::meat}}, and {{c1::fish}}.
Consuming these foods helps maintain adequate thiamine levels.
Thiamine deficiency leads to decreased production of {{c1::ATP}} and impaired cellular function.
ATP is essential for cellular energy.
{{c1::Beriberi}} is found in areas where low-thiamine foods, like polished rice, are a major dietary component.
{{c1::Wet}} beriberi affects the cardiovascular system, causing fast heart rate, shortness of breath, and edema.
This form is primarily associated with fluid retention and cardiac stress.
{{c1::Dry}} beriberi affects the nervous system, causing numbness, confusion, and difficulty moving legs.
It primarily impacts nerve function and mobility.
{{c1::Wernicke-Korsakoff}} syndrome is commonly associated with chronic alcoholism.
It results from thiamine deficiency or impaired absorption and involves mental confusion, ataxia, and eye muscle weakness.
{{c1::Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)}} has a basic molecular function of reversibly accepting two hydrogen atoms.
This function is key in redox reactions.
The biologically active forms of riboflavin are {{c1::flavin mononucleotide (FMN)}} and {{c1::flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)}}.
FAD is found in its reduced form as FADH₂.
{{c1::Riboflavin}} serves as a cofactor in redox reactions involved in the metabolism of carbohydrates, amino acids, and fats.
These metabolic processes are essential for cellular energy production.
Key enzymes that utilize riboflavin include {{c1::succinate dehydrogenase}} in the TCA cycle and enzymes transferring protons to {{c1::Complex II}} in the electron transport chain.
These enzymes are crucial for cellular respiration and energy production.
Nutritional sources of {{c1::riboflavin}} include eggs, organ meats, lean meats, milk, and fortified grains.
These foods help maintain adequate levels of riboflavin in the body.
{{c1::Vitamin B3 (Niacin)}} functions as a coenzyme in redox reactions by accepting two electrons from a hydride ion.
This is its basic molecular function.
The biologically active forms of niacin are {{c1::NAD+}} and {{c1::NADP+}}.
In their reduced forms, they are NADH and NADPH, respectively.
Nutritional sources of {{c1::niacin}} include milk, lean meats, unrefined grains, and fortified cereals.
Lean meats, especially liver, are particularly high in niacin.
Niacin deficiency results in decreased production of {{c1::ATP}} and impaired cellular function.
ATP is crucial for cellular energy processes.
{{c1::Pellagra}} is a systemic disease caused by severe niacin deficiency.

It is characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and, if untreated, death (the "fourth D").
4 Ds
The three main symptoms of pellagra are {{c1::dermatitis}}, {{c1::diarrhea}}, and {{c1::dementia}}.
These are commonly referred to as the "three D's" of pellagra.
{{c1::Hartnup}} disorder is an autosomal recessive disorder that impairs the transport of neutral amino acids, like tryptophan.
It leads to decreased absorption of niacin from the gut and presents with symptoms similar to pellagra.
{{c1::Niacin::Vitamin}} may be used to treat hyperlipoproteinemia by inhibiting lipolysis in adipose tissue.
High doses of niacin (100 times the RDA) reduce free fatty acids (FFA), which are used by the liver to make triacylglycerol (TAG).
The liver uses free fatty acids (FFA) to synthesize {{c1::triacylglycerol (TAG)}}, which is required for Very Low-density Lipoproteins (VLDL).
VLDL is a precursor to Low-density Lipoproteins (LDL), a form of "bad" cholesterol.
High doses of niacin ultimately decrease circulating {{c1::LDLs}}, the "bad" form of cholesterol.
A common side effect of high-dose niacin therapy is severe {{c1::flushing}}.
Flushing is due to increased blood flow to the skin.
The basic molecular function of {{c1::Vitamin B5 (Pantothenic acid)}} is as a component of CoA, involved in the transfer of acyl groups.
CoA stands for Coenzyme A, which is crucial in various metabolic pathways.
Examples of key metabolic pathways using CoA include {{c1::succinyl CoA}} (TCA cycle), {{c1::acetyl CoA}} (entry into the TCA cycle), and {{c1::fatty acyl CoA}} (fatty acid biosynthesis).
These pathways are essential for energy production and biosynthesis.
Nutritional sources of {{c1::Vitamin B5}} include fortified cereals, beef, poultry, starchy foods, vegetables, and some non-citrus fruits.
These foods help maintain adequate levels of pantothenic acid.
Deficiency in {{c1::Vitamin B5}} can cause EEG abnormalities, dermatitis, scaling on the lips, cracks at the corners of the mouth, swollen tongue, depression, fatigue, and diarrhea.
{{c1::Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)}} has a basic molecular function involving transamination and decarboxylation.
These activities are crucial in amino acid metabolism.
The active form of Vitamin B6 is {{c1::pyridoxal phosphate (PLP)}}.
B6 is a collective term for pyridoxine, pyridoxal, and pyridoxamine.
Key metabolic enzymes utilizing Vitamin B6 include {{c1::aspartate transaminase}}, {{c1::glutamate decarboxylase}}, and {{c1::glycogen phosphorylase}}.
These enzymes are involved in amino acid metabolism, neurotransmitter synthesis, and glycogenolysis.
Pyridoxine is found primarily in {{c1::plant}} sources, while pyridoxal and pyridoxamine are found primarily in {{c1::animal}} sources.
Different forms of B6 are derived from distinct dietary sources.
Deficiency in {{c1::Vitamin B6}} can cause dermatitis, numbness, sore tongue, mouth cracks, and confusion.
Symptoms may include irritability and depression as well.
The basic molecular function of {{c1::Vitamin B7 (Biotin)}} is to act as a carrier of activated carbon dioxide (CO₂) in carboxylation reactions.
The biologically active form of biotin is covalently bound to a {{c1::lysine}} group in biotin-dependent enzymes.
This form ensures proper enzymatic function.
Key enzymes utilizing biotin include {{c1::acetyl-CoA carboxylase}} for fatty acid biosynthesis and {{c1::propionyl CoA carboxylase}} for fatty acid beta-oxidation.
Nutritional sources of biotin are {{c1::widely distributed}} in foods.
Biotin is commonly found in a variety of dietary sources.
The basic molecular function of {{c1::Vitamin B9 (Folic Acid)}} is that THF receives one-carbon units from donors and transfers them to receiver molecules.
THF stands for tetrahydrofolate, a key coenzyme form of folate.
The biologically active form of folate is {{c1::tetrahydrofolate (THF)}}, which can be methylated at N⁵, N¹⁰, or both.
Key metabolic pathways utilizing {{c1::folate}} include the synthesis of amino acids, purine nucleotides, and thymidine monophosphate.
Nutritional sources of folate include {{c1::leafy, dark-green vegetables}}.
Consuming these vegetables helps maintain adequate folate levels.
{{c1::Vitamin B9 (folate)}} deficiency is the most common vitamin deficiency in the United States.
It is especially prevalent among pregnant women and individuals with alcoholism.

Causes of folate deficiency include {{c1::increased demand (e.g., pregnancy)}}, {{c1::poor absorption (e.g., small intestine pathology)}}, and treatment with {{c1::dihydrofolate reductase inhibitors (e.g., methotrexate)}}.
Increased demand and poor absorption are major risk factors for folate deficiency.
{{c1::Megaloblastic anemia}} is a primary result of folate deficiency, caused by diminished production of purine nucleotides.
This leads to an inability to make or replicate DNA, causing cells to be unable to divide.
Folate deficiency can result in {{c1::neural tube}} defects, such as spina bifida and anencephaly.
Critical folate-dependent development occurs in the first weeks of fetal development.
The basic molecular functions of {{c1::Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin)}} include remethylation of homocysteine to methionine and isomerization of methylmalonyl CoA.
These processes are involved in amino acid degradation and odd-chain fatty acid metabolism.
The biologically active form of Vitamin B12 has a {{c1::Corrin ring}} structure with a central {{c2::cobalt}} atom held by {{c2::nitrogen}} bonds.
The Corrin ring is similar to heme but differs in its chemical structure and function.
{{c1::Vitamin B12}} is synthesized only by {{c2::microorganisms}} and must be obtained from the microbiota or animal sources like meat, eggs, and liver.
Fortified grains and cereals can also provide Vitamin B12.
The {{c1::folate trap}} hypothesis describes how {{c2::cobalamin}} deficiency affects rapidly dividing cells, such as those in bone marrow and gut mucosa.
These cells require different forms of THF (tetrahydrofolate) for nucleotide synthesis.
In {{c1::cobalamin}} deficiency, the utilization of N⁵-methyl form of THF in B12-dependent methionine synthesis is impaired.
This prevents the conversion of N⁵-methyl THF to other forms.
The accumulation of {{c1::N⁵-methyl THF}} leads to a folate trap, as other THF forms become diminished.
This ultimately results in a functional folate deficiency.
In the folate trap, if {{c1::methionine synthase}} is not functional (e.g., due to cobalamin deficiency), all folate accumulates as 5-methyl-THF.
This form cannot be converted back to free THF, leading to a functional folate deficiency.
The conversion of 5-methyl-THF to free THF is {{c1::irreversible}} unless methionine synthase is active.
This reaction is critical for maintaining THF availability for purine synthesis.
{{c1::Methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR)}} catalyzes the conversion of 5,10-methylene THF to 5-methyl THF.
This is part of the methionine cycle, which is linked to folate metabolism.
{{c1::Vitamin B12}} is unique among water-soluble vitamins because the body can store {{c2::significant}} amounts of it.
It may take years for deficiency symptoms to develop due to these stores.
Clinical symptoms of Vitamin B12 deficiency may take {{c1::months}} to appear in cases of impaired absorption.
Impaired absorption can occur despite sufficient dietary intake.
Vitamin B12 deficiency can be determined by elevated levels of {{c1::methylmalonic acid}} in the blood.
Methylmalonic acid is a marker of B12 metabolic function.
Lack of Vitamin B12 can lead to {{c1::pernicious anemia}}, characterized by a lack of red blood cells.
B12 deficiency can affect the nervous system, causing {{c1::numbness}}, {{c1::memory loss}}, and {{c1::poor balance}}.
Neurological symptoms often appear later than anemia.
The basic molecular function of Vitamin C (Ascorbic Acid) is to act as a {{c1::reducing agent}} involved in hydroxylation reactions.
Vitamin C is essential for the hydroxylation of {{c1::prolyl}} and {{c1::lysyl}} residues in collagen.
This process is necessary for proper collagen formation and stabilization.
Vitamin C aids in the hydroxylation of {{c1::dopamine}} to {{c1::norepinephrine}} during epinephrine synthesis.
This reaction is part of catecholamine biosynthesis.
Vitamin C maintains iron in its {{c1::reduced (ferrous)}} form, which is necessary for enzymatic activity.
The reduced form of iron is crucial for the function of hydroxylase enzymes.
These foods help maintain adequate levels of Vitamin C.
Vitamin C deficiency leads to {{c1::scurvy}}, which presents with sore gums, loose teeth, and fragile blood vessels.
The basic molecular function of {{c1::Vitamin A}} is to bind to retinoic acid receptors, promoting their binding to DNA and activating gene expression.
This process regulates transcription of specific genes.
The biologically active forms of {{c1::Vitamin A}} include retinol, retinal, retinoic acid, and beta-carotene.
Each form has distinct roles in the body, from vision to cell maintenance.
{{c1::Vitamin A}} plays a key role in the visual cycle, as a component of rods and cones and the pigment rhodopsin.
{{c1::Vitamin A}} is essential for epithelial cell maintenance and normal reproduction.
It supports spermatogenesis in males and prevents fetal resorption in females.
Nutritional sources of {{c1::Vitamin A}} include liver, kidney, egg yolk, and yellow, orange, and dark-green vegetables.
Animal sources provide preformed Vitamin A, while plant sources contain carotenoids.
{{c1::Night blindness}} is the earliest sign of Vitamin A deficiency.
It results from impaired production of rhodopsin in the retina.
Prolonged Vitamin A deficiency can lead to {{c1::irreversible loss}} of visual cells.
This can cause severe vision impairment over time.
Severe Vitamin A deficiency can result in {{c1::xerophthalmia}}, which is dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea.
Xerophthalmia is a major cause of blindness in developing countries.
{{c1::Retinoic acid}} and its derivatives are used to treat acne.
They help reduce sebum production and inflammation in the skin.
{{c1::All-trans retinoic acid}} is used in the treatment of promyelocytic leukemia, characterized by t(15;17).
It fuses the retinoic acid receptor to a protein called PMN, aiding in differentiation therapy.
The basic molecular function of {{c1::Vitamin D}} is to bind to receptor proteins that activate gene expression.
This process influences calcium and phosphorus metabolism.
The active form of Vitamin D is {{c1::calcitriol}}, which is metabolized from precursor forms.
Calcitriol is the most potent form of Vitamin D.
Key biological processes of Vitamin D include stimulating intestinal absorption of {{c1::calcium}} and promoting bone resorption to increase serum {{c1::calcium}} levels.
These functions help maintain proper calcium balance in the body.
Nutritional sources of {{c1::Vitamin D}} include fatty fish, liver, egg yolk, and exposure to light.
Vitamin D can be synthesized in the skin upon sunlight exposure.
Symptoms of {{c1::Vitamin D}} deficiency include fatigue, insomnia, bone pain, depression, hair loss, muscle weakness, and loss of appetite.
These symptoms result from impaired calcium absorption and bone health.
Nutritional {{c1::rickets}} is caused by Vitamin D deficiency, leading to net demineralization of bone.
This results in soft, pliable bones and increases susceptibility to fractures.
{{c1::Rickets}} results from the continued formation of the collagen matrix of bone without complete mineralization.
This process makes bones structurally weak and deformable.
The basic molecular function of {{c1::Vitamin E}} is as an antioxidant that protects red blood cells and cellular membranes from free radical damage.
It helps prevent oxidative stress in cells.
The biologically active form of {{c1::Vitamin E}} includes eight naturally occurring tocopherols, with alpha-tocopherol being the most active.
Alpha-tocopherol is the main form used by the human body.
A primary nutritional source of Vitamin E is {{c1::vegetable oils}}.
The basic molecular function of {{c1::Vitamin K}} is to act as a coenzyme in the carboxylation of specific {{c2::glutamic acid}} residues in proteins.
This process is essential for blood clotting.
The biologically active forms of Vitamin K include {{c1::phylloquinone (Vitamin K1)}} from plants and {{c1::menaquinone (Vitamin K2)}} from intestinal bacteria.
Both forms play crucial roles in the coagulation process.
{{c1::Vitamin K}} is primarily involved in coagulation, modifying coagulation factors VII, IX, and X.
It also facilitates the interaction of prothrombin with the membrane.
Nutritional sources of {{c1::Vitamin K}} include dark green leafy vegetables, such as kale, cabbage, and spinach.
These foods are rich in Vitamin K1 (phylloquinone).
{{c1::Calcium}} is the most abundant mineral in the body, with {{c2::98}}% found in bones.
It is also involved in signaling, muscle contraction, and blood clotting.
Free {{c1::phosphate (Pi)}}, or {{c1::inorganic phosphate}}, is the most abundant anion in the body.
85% of it is found in inorganic hydroxyapatite, while the remainder is in phospholipids, nucleic acids, ATP, and creatine phosphate.
It plays a critical role in energy transfer and enzyme activation.
{{c1::Magnesium}} is required for phosphorylation by kinases, DNA polymerase (replication), and RNA polymerase (transcription).
It is crucial for numerous enzymatic functions in the body.
{{c1::Sodium}}, {{c1::chloride}}, and {{c1::potassium}} maintain water balance, acid-base balance, and electrical gradients across cell membranes.
These macrominerals are crucial for renal function, pH regulation, and nerve/muscle function.
{{c1::Sodium}} and {{c1::chloride}} are primarily extracellular electrolytes that are readily absorbed from foods containing salt (NaCl).
They are abundant in processed foods.
It plays a key role in maintaining cell function and electrical excitability.
{{c1::Copper}} is a key component of enzymes that oxidize ferrous iron (Fe²⁺) to ferric iron (Fe³⁺).
Copper is also needed for intracellular iron transport or storage.
The body contains approximately {{c1::3-4}} grams of iron, which is a component of many enzymes (e.g., prolyl hydroxylase).
Iron is also linked to sulfur in Fe-S proteins of electron transport and is part of the heme group in myoglobin and hemoglobin.
{{c1::Zinc}} has both structural and catalytic functions and is involved in over 100 enzymes, including alcohol dehydrogenase.
Zinc is essential for forming key domains in DNA-binding proteins (e.g., Zn finger).
{{c1::Iodine}} is utilized in the synthesis of thyroid hormones triiodothyronine (T₃) and thyroxine (T₄).

children.name: 09. Amino Acids Conversion to Specialized Products

fields: In heme, the central metal ion in the porphyrin ring is {{c1::iron}}.
{{c1::Porphyrins}} are important components of proteins like hemoglobin, myoglobin, and cytochromes.
Porphyrins have roles in oxygen transport, catalysis, and electron transport.
{{c1::Cytochrome P450}} is a type of cytochrome that utilizes <u>porphyrin</u> for catalytic functions.
Vitamin {{c1::B12}} contains a porphyrin-like ring structure with a cobalt atom at its center.
Porphyrins contain four {{c1::pyrrole rings}} joined by {{c2::methenyl bridges}}.
The arrangement is symmetrical, with alternating acetate (A) and propionate (P) around the tetrapyrrole ring.
{{c1::Coproporphyrin}} contains {{c2::methyl}} and {{c2::propionate}} groups as side chains.
It has a simpler structure compared to uroporphyrin, which has larger side chains.
Protoporphyrin IX is a component of heme, found in hemoglobin and myoglobin.
The most common metal ions bound by porphyrins are {{c1::Fe²⁺}} or {{c1::Fe³⁺}}.
The side chains of porphyrins are arranged around the {{c1::tetrapyrrole nucleus}} in four different ways, labeled I to IV.
The ordering of side chains influences the biological function of porphyrins.
In Type {{c2::I}} porphyrins, the side chains are arranged {{c1::symmetrically}} around the tetrapyrrole ring.
<u>Uroporphyrin I</u> is an example of a <u>Type I</u> porphyrin, which is not common in human physiology.
In Type {{c2::III}} porphyrins, acetate and propionate side chains are {{c1::reversed}} on ring D compared to Type I.
This reversal makes <u>Type III</u> porphyrins critical for biological functions like <u>heme synthesis</u>.
Only Type {{c1::III}} porphyrins, with an asymmetric substitution of side chains on ring D, are physiologically important in humans.
An example of a Type III porphyrin is protoporphyrin IX, crucial in heme synthesis.
Heme is a {{c1::protoporphyrin IX::Porphyrin Type}} with an iron atom at its center.
It acts as a prosthetic group in hemoglobin, myoglobin, and various enzymes like cytochromes and catalase.
The three types of side chains attached to heme include {{c1::methyl}}, {{c1::vinyl}}, and {{c1::propionyl}} groups.
These side chains contribute to the heme's <u>function and binding properties</u>.
Heme synthesis occurs in {{c1::all cells::Location}} because heme acts as a prosthetic group on {{c2::electron transport}} proteins and {{c2::enzymes}}.
The major sites of heme biosynthesis are the {{c1::liver}} and {{c1::bone marrow}}.
The initial reaction and the last three steps of porphyrin synthesis occur in the {{c1::mitochondria}}.
The intermediate steps of porphyrin synthesis pathway take place in the {{c1::cytosol}}.
Step I of heme biosynthesis involves the formation of {{c1::δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA)}}.
The rate-limiting step of heme synthesis is catalyzed by {{c1::ALA synthase}}.
These provide the carbon and nitrogen atoms for the porphyrin ring.
{{c1::Pyridoxal phosphate}} acts as a coenzyme in the formation of δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA).
It is derived from vitamin B6 and essential for ALA synthase function.
{{c1::Heme}} acts as a feedback inhibitor of ALA synthase.
When heme production exceeds demand, it is converted to hemin, which inhibits ALA synthase.
ALS1 is present in all tissues, while ALS2 is erythroid-specific; mutations in ALS2 can lead to sideroblastic anemia and iron overload.
ALS1 is present in {{c1::all tissues}}, while ALS2 is present in {{c1::erythrocytes}}.
<u>Mutations in ALS2</u> can cause {{c1::sideroblastic anemia}} and {{c1::iron overload}}.
These drugs increase the synthesis of cytochrome P450 monooxygenase, a hemeprotein, which decreases heme levels and leads to the accumulation of hemin.
Step II of heme biosynthesis involves the formation of {{c1::porphobilinogen}} from {{c2::two::#}} molecules of δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA).
This reaction is catalyzed by ALA dehydratase, a zinc-containing enzyme.
