The enzyme {{c1::δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase}} condenses two ALA molecules to form porphobilinogen.
ALA dehydratase is inhibited by {{c1::heavy metal ions (Lead)}}, leading to ALA accumulation and anemia.
{{c1::Porphobilinogen (PBG)}} is the first intermediate in the heme biosynthetic pathway that includes a pyrrole ring.
{{c1::Hydroxymethylbilane synthase}}, also known as {{c2::uroporphyrinogen I synthase}}, catalyzes the conversion of {{c3::porphobilinogen}} to {{c3::hydroxymethylbilane}}.
Hydroxymethylbilane has a {{c1::linear tetrapyrrole}} structure before cyclization to uroporphyrinogen III via {{c2::uroporphyrinogen III synthase::Enzyme}}.
Uroporphyrinogen III undergoes decarboxylation of {{c1::acetate}} groups to form {{c2::coproporphyrinogen III}}.
Decarboxylation results in the conversion of acetate groups to methyl groups.
Step III of heme biosynthesis involves the formation of {{c1::coproporphyrinogen III}} from hydroxymethylbilane.
In Step IV of heme biosynthesis, coproporphyrinogen III enters the {{c2::mitochondrion}} where {{c3::two::#}} propionate side chains are decarboxylated to {{c1::vinyl groups}}.
This reaction produces <u>protoporphyrinogen IX</u>, which is further oxidized to protoporphyrin IX.
In the mitochondria, protoporphyrinogen IX is further oxidized to produce {{c1::protoporphyrin IX}}.
Protoporphyrin IX is converted to heme by the addition of {{c1::Fe²⁺}} via the enzyme {{c2::ferrochelatase}}.
{{c1::Lead poisoning}} inhibits ferrochelatase, leading to decreased heme production and anemia.
<u>Porphyrias</u> are rare, {{c1::inherited}} or occasionally acquired defects in {{c2::heme}} synthesis.
These defects lead to the accumulation and excretion of porphyrins or porphyrin precursors, which can cause purple-colored urine.
<u>Porphyrias</u> can be classified into {{c1::erythropoietic}} and {{c1::hepatic}} types.
<u>Hepatic porphyrias</u> can further be classified as {{c1::chronic}} or {{c1::acute}}, based on their clinical presentation.
Neurological symptoms in porphyria are caused by {{c1::autonomic neuropathy}}.
Symptoms include nausea, abdominal pain, vomiting, muscle weakness, urinary retention, confusion, and seizures.
Also includes abdominal pain, muscle weakness, hallucinations, and urinary retention
Cutaneous symptoms in porphyria arise from {{c1::photosensitization}} due to porphyrins reacting with molecular oxygen.
Oxygen radicals damage cell membranes, releasing destructive lysosomal enzymes.
Porphyria causes {{c1::red-blue colored}} urine that fluoresces red under UV light due to the presence of porphyrins.
This symptom reflects the origin of the term "porphyria," which is derived from the Greek word for purple.
Administration of {{c1::barbiturates}} and {{c1::ethanol}} can precipitate porphyria symptoms by inducing {{c2::cytochrome P450}} synthesis.
This induction decreases heme concentration, enhancing ALA synthase activity and exacerbating the condition.
Enzyme defects occurring before {{c1::tetrapyrrole}} synthesis in porphyria lead to abdominal and neuropsychiatric symptoms.
These symptoms are linked to the accumulation of non-tetrapyrrole intermediates.
Enzyme defects leading to the accumulation of {{c1::tetrapyrrole}} intermediates cause photosensitivity in porphyria.
Tetrapyrrole intermediates absorb light and generate reactive oxygen species (ROS), which can damage cells.
Increased {{c1::ALA synthase::Enzyme}} activity is a common feature of porphyria and results from decreased heme synthesis.
Elevated ALA levels contribute to the accumulation of porphyrin precursors, worsening symptoms.
{{c1::Sunlight avoidance}} is the main defense against photosensitivity in porphyria.
Reducing light exposure helps prevent skin damage caused by porphyrins.
{{c1::Therapeutic phlebotomy}} is used as a treatment in porphyria to reduce iron levels.
Lowering iron levels can decrease the synthesis of heme and its precursors.
Low doses of {{c1::chloroquine}} can help mobilize and excrete excess porphyrins from the {{c2::liver}}.
This treatment is used selectively for some types of porphyria to reduce porphyrin load.
Intravenous {{c1::heme (Panhematin)}} injections help inhibit {{c2::ALA synthase}}, reducing the accumulation of porphyrin precursors.
{{c1::Beta-carotene}} protects skin by quenching {{c2::reactive oxygen species (ROS)}} formed during light exposure.
This treatment helps mitigate oxidative damage in photosensitive porphyria patients.
A {{c1::high glucose}} diet is recommended to decrease heme synthesis in porphyria.
A high-glucose diet (also known as "glucose loading") helps decrease heme synthesis by inhibiting ALA synthase
Lead poisoning inhibits ferrochelatase and ALA dehydratase, leading to acquired porphyria.
In children, lead poisoning can cause {{c1::developmental defects}}, a drop in {{c1::IQ}}, hyperactivity, and insomnia.
In adults, lead poisoning can lead to {{c1::severe abdominal pain}} and {{c1::mental confusion}}.
False positive urine porphyrin tests can occur in porphyria cases induced by {{c1::liver cancer}} or {{c1::hepatitis}}.
Liver diseases can lead to altered porphyrin metabolism, mimicking porphyria symptoms.
Red blood cells are taken up and degraded by the reticuloendothelial system after approximately {{c1::120::#}} days in circulation.
The first step in heme degradation involves cleavage of the heme ring by the enzyme {{c1::heme oxygenase}}.
Heme oxygenase is found in {{c1::reticuloendothelial}} cells and initiates {{c2::bilirubin}} formation.
Heme oxygenase adds a {{c1::hydroxyl group}} to the methenyl bridge between two pyrrole rings during heme degradation.
This reaction marks the initial conversion of heme to biliverdin.
The green pigment {{c1::biliverdin}} is produced after the cleavage of the porphyrin ring by heme oxygenase.
Ferric iron (Fe³⁺) and carbon monoxide (CO) are released during this reaction.
In the second reaction of heme degradation, {{c1::biliverdin reductase}} reduces the central methenyl bridge of biliverdin to form {{c2::bilirubin}}.
This reaction converts the green pigment biliverdin into the red-orange pigment bilirubin.
Bilirubin and its derivatives are collectively termed {{c1::bile pigments}}.
These pigments are responsible for the color changes observed in a bruise as heme degradation progresses.
Bilirubin is only slightly soluble in plasma and is transported to the {{c2::liver}} by binding non-covalently to {{c1::albumin}} in the blood.
Albumin helps keep bilirubin soluble during its transport in the bloodstream.
This displacement increases the risk of bilirubin entering the central nervous system, potentially causing neural damage in infants.
Inside the liver, bilirubin binds to the cytoplasmic transport protein {{c1::ligandin}}.
Ligandin facilitates bilirubin’s transport and conjugation within liver cells.
The conversion of bilirubin to {{c2::bilirubin diglucuronide}} is catalyzed by {{c1::bilirubin glucuronyltransferase}}.
Bilirubin glucuronyltransferase uses {{c1::UDP-glucuronic acid::Cofactor}} as the glucuronate donor, increasing bilirubin's solubility.
Bilirubin is transported into liver cells by organic anion transporting polypeptides {{c1::OATP1B1}} and {{c1::OATP1B3}}.
Unconjugated bilirubin is {{c1::not usually::usually/not usually}} secreted into bile.
{{c1::Conjugated bilirubin (bilirubin diglucuronide)}} is actively secreted into the bile and subsequently enters the intestine.
In Gilbert syndrome, Crigler-Najjar syndrome, Lucey-Driscoll syndrome, and breast milk jaundice, there is defective conjugation of {{c1::glucuronic acid}} to {{c1::bilirubin}}.
Impaired {{c2::bilirubin excretion into bile}} occurs in Dubin-Johnson syndrome, due to defective {{c1::MRP2}} protein.
Dubin-Johnson syndrome results in the buildup of conjugated bilirubin within liver cells.
Rotor syndrome is characterized by defective {{c1::transport}} of bilirubin within the {{c2::liver}}, affecting its clearance from the body.
OATP1B1 and OATP1B3 are transporters involved in bilirubin uptake in liver cells.
In the intestine, bilirubin is converted to {{c1::urobilinogen}} after the hydrolysis and removal of the {{c2::glucuronic acid}} residue by bacteria.
Urobilinogen is a colorless compound and an intermediate in the metabolism of bilirubin.
Most urobilinogen is oxidized by intestinal bacteria to {{c1::stercobilin}}, giving feces its characteristic brown color.
<u>Stercobilin</u> is the end product of bilirubin metabolism in the gut.
Some {{c1::urobilinogen}} is reabsorbed from the gut and enters the portal blood, participating in the enterohepatic cycle.
In the enterohepatic cycle, the liver reabsorbs and re-secretes urobilinogen into the bile.
Urobilinogen that reaches the kidneys is converted to {{c1::urobilin}}, which gives urine its characteristic {{c2::yellow}} color.
Urobilin is an end product excreted in the urine, indicating normal bilirubin metabolism.
Jaundice is characterized by a {{c1::yellow}} color of the skin, nail beds, and sclerae (whites of the eyes) due to {{c1::bilirubin}} deposition.
Jaundice results from elevated levels of bilirubin in the blood.
In hemolytic jaundice, the liver can conjugate and excrete over {{c1::3,000}}mg of bilirubin per day, while normal bilirubin production is around {{c1::300}}mg/day.
Despite the liver's high capacity for bilirubin processing, rapid red blood cell breakdown can overwhelm this capacity.

<u>Hemolytic jaundice</u> can be caused by massive lysis of red blood cells, such as in {{c1::sickle cell anemia}}, {{c1::pyruvate kinase deficiency}}, or {{c1::glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency}}.
These conditions lead to excessive production of unconjugated bilirubin, which cannot be conjugated quickly enough by the liver.
In hemolytic jaundice, increased bilirubin is excreted into the bile, leading to higher levels of {{c1::urobilinogen}} in the enterohepatic circulation.
As a result, both urinary urobilinogen and unconjugated bilirubin levels in the blood rise, causing the characteristic jaundice.
This leakage occurs due to impaired hepatic function, contributing to elevated bilirubin levels in the bloodstream.
The <u>pale stools</u> result from <u>reduced stercobilin</u> formation, as bilirubin is not adequately excreted into the bile.
Hepatocellular jaundice increases {{c1::urobilinogen}} in the urine because hepatic damage decreases {{c2::enterohepatic circulation}}.
More urobilinogen re-enters the blood and is filtered into the urine, leading to its dark color.
In hepatocellular jaundice, damage to liver cells causes increased levels of {{c1::unconjugated bilirubin}} in the blood due to decreased conjugation.
Liver cell damage reduces the liver's ability to conjugate bilirubin effectively (e.g., cirrhosis or hepatitis).
Obstructive jaundice is caused by {{c1::obstruction of the bile duct}}, preventing bilirubin from reaching the intestine.
Examples of obstructions include hepatic tumors or bile stones blocking the bile ducts.
In obstructive jaundice, the liver releases {{c1::conjugated bilirubin}} back into the blood.
This backflow occurs because the bile cannot be properly excreted into the intestines.
In neonatal jaundice, the activity of {{c1::bilirubin glucuronyltransferase::Enzyme}} is low, leading to elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels.
This enzyme deficiency is more pronounced in premature infants.
Phototherapy for neonatal jaundice uses blue fluorescent light, converting {{c1::bilirubin}} to more polar, water-soluble isomers.
These isomers can be excreted into the bile without conjugation to glucuronic acid.
In neonatal jaundice, serum levels of bilirubin rise after birth, and premature infants may reach toxic bilirubin concentrations due to {{c1::lower enzyme activity}}.
In contrast, full-term infants have a higher level of enzyme activity.
The van den Bergh reaction uses {{c1::diazotized sulfanilic acid}} to react with bilirubin, forming red azodipyrroles for colorimetric measurement.
This method is commonly used to determine bilirubin levels in the blood.
Only {{c2::conjugated bilirubin}}, which is water-soluble, reacts directly and is called {{c1::direct bilirubin}}.
Direct bilirubin indicates the fraction of bilirubin that is already conjugated in the liver.
To measure <u>unconjugated bilirubin</u>, alcohol is added to release it into solution, making it react as {{c1::indirect bilirubin}}.
Indirect bilirubin is bound to albumin and not initially water-soluble.
The formula to determine unconjugated bilirubin is: {{c1::total bilirubin - direct bilirubin = indirect bilirubin}}.
Elevated indirect bilirubin is often seen in pre-hepatic jaundice, while elevated direct bilirubin is seen in post-hepatic jaundice.
Epinephrine is derived from {{c1::tyrosine}} and produced in the {{c2::adrenal medulla}} and some {{c2::CNS}} cells.
It plays a key role in the "fight or flight" response, increasing heart rate, and releasing glucose into the blood.
Norepinephrine is derived from {{c1::tyrosine}} and acts mainly in the {{c2::CNS}} and {{c3::sympathetic nerves}}.
It helps regulate blood pressure, heart rate, and blood glucose levels.
Dopamine is derived from {{c1::tyrosine}} and is primarily produced in {{c2::dopaminergic}} neurons within the CNS.
It is involved in reward, motivation, and motor control processes.
Both norepinephrine and epinephrine increase the degradation of {{c1::glycogen}} and {{c1::triacylglycerol}} in response to stressors like fright, exercise, or cold.
They regulate carbohydrate and lipid metabolism outside the nervous system.
Degradation of Catecholamine Step I: {{c1::Monoamine oxidase (MAO)::Enzyme}} inactivates catecholamines by {{c2::oxidative deamination}}, leading to {{c3::aldehyde}} formation.
The aldehydes are subsequently oxidized to their corresponding carboxylic acids.

Degradation of Catecholamine Step II: {{c2::Catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT)::Enzyme}} inactivates catecholamines by {{c1::methylation}} using {{c3::S-adenosylmethionine (SAM)}} as the methyl donor.
This reaction can occur in either direction and is part of catecholamine metabolism.
VMA is excreted in the urine and serves as a marker for catecholamine breakdown.
Dopamine is degraded to {{c1::homovanillic acid (HVA)}} through the combined actions of {{c2::MAO}} and {{c2::COMT}}.
HVA is a major metabolite of dopamine, found in the urine.
It is primarily involved in regulating mood, sleep, and appetite.
It plays a significant role in gastrointestinal motility.
In the brain, serotonin regulates functions like {{c1::sleep}}, {{c1::appetite}}, and {{c1::body weight}}.
It is critical for mood stabilization and feeding behavior.
Serotonin is stored in {{c1::platelets::Cell Type}}, which release it during clot formation to promote blood clotting.
This release aids in the hemostatic process when platelets bind to a clot.
The conversion of tryptophan to 5-hydroxytryptophan is catalyzed by {{c1::tryptophan hydroxylase}}.
Genetic polymorphisms in the {{c1::tryptophan hydroxylase 2 (TPH2)}} isozyme can predispose individuals to anxiety and depression.
TPH2 is a variant of tryptophan hydroxylase primarily found in the brain.
5-hydroxytryptophan is converted to serotonin by {{c1::aromatic L-amino acid decarboxylase::Enzyme}}.
This step releases CO₂ and completes serotonin synthesis.
<u>Serotonin</u> is degraded by {{c1::monoamine oxidase (MAO)}} in the {{c2::synaptic cleft}}.
MAO is an enzyme that inactivates serotonin by oxidative deamination.
Histamine acts through {{c1::G-protein coupled}} receptors to mediate allergic and inflammatory responses.
These receptors play roles in various physiological processes across different cell types.
H1 receptors are expressed in {{c1::smooth muscle}} and {{c1::endothelial}} cells, mediating {{c2::acute allergic}} responses.
H1 blockers (e.g., Benadryl™, Claritin™) are used to treat allergies, hives, and itching, and they can cause drowsiness.
H1 blockers such as {{c1::Benadryl™}} and {{c1::Claritin™}} are used to treat allergies, hives, and itching, and they can cause drowsiness.
H1 blockers (e.g., Benadryl™, Claritin™) are used to treat allergies, hives, and itching, and they can cause drowsiness.
H2 receptors are found in {{c1::gastric parietal}} cells and are responsible for {{c2::gastric acid secretion}}.
H2 blockers (e.g., Tagamet™) reduce acid secretion in the stomach, often used to treat ulcers.
H2 blockers such as {{c1::Tagamet™}} reduce acid secretion in the stomach, often used to treat {{c2::ulcers}}.
H3 receptors are located in the {{c1::central nervous system}} and are involved in modulating neurotransmission.
H3 receptors play a role in regulating the release of various {{c1::neurotransmitters}}.
H4 receptors are expressed on {{c1::mast}} cells, {{c1::eosinophils}}, {{c1::T}} cells, and {{c1::dendritic}} cells, regulating immune responses.
Histamine is synthesized from histidine by {{c1::histidine decarboxylase::Enzyme}}, which is a {{c2::pyridoxal-5'-phosphate}}-dependent enzyme.
This enzyme catalyzes the removal of CO₂ from histidine.
One major route of histamine inactivation in mammals is methylation by {{c1::histamine N-methyltransferase::Enzyme}} using {{c2::SAM (S-adenosylmethionine)::Cofactor}} for methyl transfer.
SAM serves as the methyl donor in this reaction.
Another route of histamine inactivation is oxidative deamination of the primary amino group, catalyzed by {{c1::diamine oxidase::Enzyme}}.
This process helps regulate histamine levels in the body.
Creatine acts as a storage form of high-energy phosphate called {{c1::creatine phosphate}}.
It is mainly found in muscle, brain, and blood tissues.
The phosphate of ATP is transferred to creatine by {{c1::creatine phosphokinase}}, forming creatine phosphate.
This reaction involves the creation of a high-energy phosphoramidate bond.
When energy demand is high, creatine phosphate donates its phosphate to {{c1::ADP}} to regenerate {{c1::ATP}}.
This reversible reaction is crucial during muscle exertion.
Creatine is synthesized from {{c1::glycine}} and the guanidino group of {{c1::arginine}}.
The synthesis begins with the formation of guanidinoacetate.
The enzyme {{c1::amidino-transferase}} facilitates the transfer of the guanidino group from arginine to glycine in creatine synthesis.
This reaction releases ornithine as a byproduct.
The methyl group for creatine synthesis is provided by {{c1::S-adenosylmethionine (SAM)}}.
SAM donates a methyl group to guanidinoacetate, forming creatine.
Creatine and creatine phosphate spontaneously cyclize to form {{c1::creatinine}}, which is excreted in the urine.
This reaction occurs at a slow but constant rate.
Serum creatinine levels are used as a measure of {{c1::kidney}} function.
Presence of creatine kinase in the plasma can indicate tissue damage, such as in {{c1::myocardial infarction}}.
Creatine kinase release is a marker of muscle or heart tissue injury.
The enzyme {{c1::tyrosinase}} catalyzes the oxidation of DOPA to a reactive intermediate in melanin synthesis.
Tyrosinase has both hydroxylase and oxidase activities, essential for the production of melanin.
Melanin is found in tissues such as the {{c1::eye}}, {{c1::hair}}, and {{c1::skin}}.
It is responsible for pigmentation in these tissues.
Fibrinogen is converted to fibrin during blood clotting.
Prothrombin is activated to thrombin in the clotting cascade.
Tissue Factor initiates the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.
Calcium ions play a crucial role in several steps of the coagulation cascade.
Proaccelerin, also known as labile factor, accelerates the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.
Proconvertin is involved in the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.
Deficiency of Factor VIII leads to Hemophilia A.
Deficiency of Factor IX leads to Hemophilia B.
Stuart Factor is important for the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.
Plasma Thromboplastin is involved in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation.
Hageman Factor activates the intrinsic pathway and the kinin cascade.
Fibrin Stabilizing Factor strengthens the fibrin clot by cross-linking fibrin strands.
{{c1::Fibrinogen deficiency}} is an inherited bleeding disorder that reduces proper clot formation.
The disorder may arise from reduced fibrinogen production or malfunctioning fibrinogen.
Elevated {{c1::plasma fibrinogen}} levels are associated with coronary atherosclerosis and are a significant risk factor for {{c2::cardiovascular}} diseases.
High fibrinogen levels contribute to increased clot formation and cardiovascular risks.
The {{c3::prothrombin}} {{c1::20210 guanine to adenine}} mutation is associated with an increased risk of {{c2::thrombosis}}.
{{c2::Prothrombin}} deficiency slows the {{c1::blood clotting}} process, leading to prolonged bleeding.
{{c1::Prothrombin G20210A}} is the second most common inherited thrombophilia after factor V Leiden.
Aberrant expression of tissue factor triggers {{c1::intravascular thrombosis}}, associated with diseases like {{c2::atherosclerosis}}, {{c2::cancer}}, and {{c2::sepsis}}.
Tissue factor plays a crucial role in the rapid activation of the clotting cascade upon exposure to extravascular sites.
The absence of tissue factor in {{c1::tissue factor-deficient}} embryos/humans indicates that tissue factor is {{c2::essential for life}}.
Tissue factor deficiency is incompatible with embryonic development, underscoring its vital role in hemostasis.
Tissue factor is a transmembrane receptor for Factor {{c1::VII::#}}, expressed by cells surrounding blood vessels.
Tissue factor initiates clotting when exposed due to endothelial damage, activating the clotting cascade.
The death of homozygous tissue factor deficient embryos and the absence of TF-deficient humans indicate that TF is {{c1::essential for life}}.
{{c3::Factor V Leiden}} is an inherited disorder involving a {{c1::point}} mutation in the Factor V gene, leading to {{c2::thrombophilia}}.
Thrombophilia causes a tendency to form clots more quickly, increasing the risk of thrombosis.
In the United States, <u>Factor V Leiden</u> is present in about {{c1::1 in 20::Ratio}} Caucasians and about {{c2::1 in 100::Ratio}} African-Americans.
<u>Factor V</u> is synthesized primarily in the {{c1::liver}}.
It circulates as a single-chain molecule with a plasma half-life of 12 hours.
{{c1::Factor V}} plays a critical role in the activation of {{c2::prothrombin}}.
{{c1::Factor VII}} deficiency can lead to severe bleeding symptoms, including life-threatening <u>intracerebral hemorrhage</u>.
Patients with Factor VII levels below {{c1::1%}} often present with significant bleeding symptoms.
Elevated {{c2::Factor VII}} levels are associated with {{c1::fatal myocardial infarctions}}.
{{c1::Factor VII}} initiates the clotting cascade upon binding to {{c2::tissue factor}}, playing a key role in clot formation.
<u>Factor VII</u> is synthesized in the {{c1::liver}} and circulates in plasma.
Recombinant {{c2::Factor VIIa (rFVIIa)}} is used as a hemostatic drug for {{c1::hemophilia patients}} with inhibitors.
It ensures hemostasis during major surgeries and stops serious bleeding episodes.
{{c1::Factor VIII}} is critical for clot formation, and its deficiency causes {{c2::hemophilia A}}.
{{c1::Hemophilia A}}, also known as <u>Factor VIII deficiency</u>, is a genetic disorder caused by missing or defective Factor VIII.
High Factor VIII levels are a risk factor for {{c1::venous thrombosis}} and may also contribute to arterial thrombosis in {{c2::coronary heart disease}} and {{c2::stroke}}.
Elevated Factor VIII increases the risk of clot formation in both veins and arteries.
During clotting, Factor VIII is activated by {{c1::thrombin}} or {{c1::Factor IXa}} to form a complex that converts Factor X to {{c2::Factor Xa}}.
{{c3::Factor IX}} deficiency, known as {{c1::hemophilia B}}, is an {{c2::X-linked::Inheritance Pattern}} bleeding disorder.
It is usually manifested in <u>males</u> and transmitted by females who carry the mutation on the X chromosome.
Factor IX is a {{c1::vitamin K}}-dependent glycoprotein synthesized in the {{c2::liver}}.
It undergoes extensive post-translational modification to become fully gamma-carboxylated and functional in blood clotting.
Recombinant {{c2::Factor IX}} is used to treat {{c1::hemophilia B}}.
The primary plasma inhibitor of {{c2::Factor Xa}} is the serine protease inhibitor {{c1::antithrombin (AT)}}.
The inhibition of Factor Xa by antithrombin is <u>accelerated by</u> <u>heparin</u>.
Clotting Factor X is a {{c1::vitamin K}}-dependent serine protease that serves as the first enzyme in the common pathway of {{c2::thrombus}} formation.
In the blood coagulation cascade, {{c1::Factor X}} is activated by Factors {{c2::IXa}} & {{c2::VIIIa}}.
Hemophilia C differs from Hemophilia A and B, as it is not {{c1::sex}}-linked and can affect both {{c2::males}} and {{c2::females}}.
{{c2::Factor XI}} deficiency is an {{c3::autosomal::Inheritance Pattern}} disorder associated with bleeding, known as {{c1::Hemophilia C}}.
Factor XI is activated by {{c1::thrombin}} on the surface of activated {{c2::platelets::Cell Type}}, which is the main mechanism of its activation during hemostasis in vivo.
Factor XI circulates as a {{c1::homodimer}}, with each subunit containing {{c2::four::#}} apple domains.
Factor XI contributes to fibrin formation and clot stability by activating {{c1::Factor IX}}.
Individuals with {{c1::Factor XII}} deficiency {{c2::do not::do/do not}} have a bleeding tendency, even after significant trauma or surgery.
Factor XIII deficiency is an extremely rare inherited blood disorder characterized by {{c1::abnormal}} blood clotting.
It may result in abnormal bleeding, with affected individuals experiencing poor wound healing due to inadequate clotting.
Factor XIII stabilizes the fibrin clot by {{c1::crosslinking fibrin strands}}, essential for proper clot formation.
Factor XIII is a {{c1::heterotetramer}} consisting of {{c2::two::#}} enzymatic A peptides and {{c2::two::#}} non-enzymatic B peptides.
The activated form, Factor XIIIa, is a dimer of the A peptides.
Primary hemostasis involves {{c1::blood vessel contraction}} and the formation of a {{c2::platelet plug}} at the site of injury.
It is the initial response to vessel injury, temporarily stopping blood flow by platelet aggregation.
Secondary hemostasis involves the release of {{c2::clotting factors}}, leading to the formation of {{c1::fibrin}} which stabilizes the clot.
Fibrin forms a mesh over the platelet plug, solidifying the clot and ensuring long-term hemostasis.

The {{c1::cell-based}} model is better than the cascade model because it explains how procoagulant reactions occur on specific cell surfaces, preventing coagulation from spreading throughout the vascular system.
The cascade model fails to localize procoagulant reactions to the injury site, as happens in the body.
The 3 phases of the <u>cell based model</u> are {{c1::initiation}}, {{c1::amplification}}, and {{c1::propagation}}.

Cell Based Model:
The initiation phase of coagulation occurs on {{c1::TF-bearing}} cells, activating Factors {{c2::VIIa}}, {{c2::Xa}}, and {{c2::thrombin (IIa)}}.

Cell Based Model:
In the amplification phase, the coagulant response moves from TF-bearing cells to the {{c1::platelet surface}}. Activated platelets accumulate cofactors such as {{c2::Va}} and {{c2::VIIIa}}.

Cell Based Model:
In the propagation phase, proteases and cofactors on the {{c1::platelet::cell}} surface generate a burst of {{c2::thrombin}}, leading to {{c3::fibrin polymerization}}.
<u>Platelet membrane asymmetry</u> is maintained by the action of {{c1::aminophospholipid translocase (Flippase)::Enzyme}}.
This enzyme actively transports phosphatidylserine (PS) and phosphatidylethanolamine (PE) to the intracellular membrane leaflet.
When platelets are activated, {{c1::scramblase}} leads to rapid loss of membrane asymmetry.
Having <u>fewer than 150,000</u> platelets is known as {{c1::thrombocytopenia}}.
{{c1::Procoagulant platelets}} serve as a scaffold for the assembly of coagulation Factors {{c2::FVa}}, {{c2::FVIIIa}}, {{c3::FIXa}}, and {{c3::FXa}}.
This assembly results in a "thrombin burst," leading to fibrin formation and clot stabilization.
<u>Procoagulant platelets</u> are a subpopulation of platelets that have {{c2::phosphatidylserine (PS)}} exposed on their surface.
This PS exposure allows binding of coagulation factors and thrombin generation.
Platelet aggregation measures the ability of platelets to {{c1::stick}} at the site of injury.
Glanzmann's thrombasthenia & Bernard-Soulier syndrome causes {{c1::severe bleeding}} due to {{c2::impaired platelet aggregation}}.
Platelet function tests involve checking {{c1::Annexin V }} binding to PS in activated platelets by flow cytometry.
Annexin V binding is used to detect phosphatidylserine exposure on platelets, indicating activation.
Platelet aggregation under high {{c1::shear stress}} is used to assess for platelet dysfunction.
This test evaluates how well platelets can adhere and aggregate under conditions that mimic blood flow in the vessels.

Clot Localization:
{{c1::Thrombin (IIa)}} activates {{c2::protein C}} by binding to thrombomodulin on the endothelial cell surface.

Clot Localization:
Activated protein C (APC) inactivates factors {{c1::Va}} and {{c1::VIIIa}} to reduce clot formation.

Clot Localization:
{{c1::Endothelial cell protein C receptor (EPCR)}} aids in the activation of protein C on the endothelial surface.
{{c1::Fibrinolysis}} is the process that clears the hemostatic plug after vessel repair.
It prevents prolonged blood clot presence by breaking down the fibrin network.
The fibrinolytic system breaks down fibrin into soluble products using the enzyme {{c1::plasmin}}.
{{c1::Tissue-type plasminogen activator (tPA)::Enzyme}} initiates the fibrinolytic system.
tPA converts plasminogen to plasmin, which degrades fibrin clots.
Thrombosis is the formation of abnormal clots due to inadequate fibrin degradation.
Key vitamin K-dependent proteins include coagulation Factors {{c1::II (prothrombin)}}, {{c1::VII}}, {{c1::IX}}, and {{c1::X}}.
Vitamin K-dependent anticoagulation proteins include {{c1::protein C}}, {{c1::protein S}}, and {{c1::protein Z}}.
Protein C and S play roles in downregulating the coagulation cascade, while protein Z assists in the inhibition of factor Xa.
Without {{c1::vitamin K}}, the carboxylation of glutamic acid residues does not occur, rendering proteins biologically inactive.
This leads to failure in clot formation or regulation, depending on the protein affected.
A normal <u>prothrombin time (PT)</u> ranges from {{c1::11-15}} seconds, indicating normal levels of clotting factors.
A normal <u>activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)</u> ranges from {{c1::32-37}} seconds.
{{c1::Zymogens}} are proteins that display <u>no catalytic activity</u> but are converted into active enzymes.
Zymogens often become active by cleavage or other modifications within the organism.
{{c1::Proteases}} are enzymes responsible for <u>breaking peptide bonds</u> during protein catabolism.
They initiate proteolysis, breaking down polypeptide chains into individual amino acids.
{{c1::Cofactors}} are proteins that lack catalytic domains and are necessary for optimal enzyme activity.
Cofactors assist enzymes in executing their catalytic functions effectively.
They require activation to participate in enzymatic reactions.
Synthesizing enzymes as zymogens enables {{c1::tight control}} over their activation.
A <u>Zymogen</u> is activated when its {{c1::prosegment}} is removed.
Prosegments in zymogen activation are never found at the {{c1::C-terminus}}.
They can be found at the N-terminus or within the primary sequence
Other roles of prosegments include {{c1::protein folding}}, {{c2::intracellular sorting}}, and acting as {{c3::inhibitors}}.
The active site cleft of serine proteases contains the catalytic triad: {{c1::Asp}}, {{c1::His}}, and {{c1::Ser}}.
The triad works together to facilitate the cleavage of peptide bonds, with serine acting as the nucleophile.
The {{c1::chymotrypsin}} family of serine proteases consists of two {{c2::beta-barrel}} domains connected by a central beta sheet, with the active site located in a crevice between the domains.
{{c1::Calcium ions (Ca++)}} are involved in the conformational change of {{c2::prothrombin}}, exposing the {{c3::GLA}} domains for binding to the lipid membrane.
Prothrombin undergoes a conformational change in the presence of {{c1::7::#}} calcium ions.
<u>Protein C deficiency</u> occurs in about {{c1::1}} out of every {{c1::200 to 500}} people.
It is one of the more common deficiencies among natural anticoagulants.
<u>Protein S deficiency</u> can be expected in about {{c1::1}} out of every {{c1::500}} individuals.
Protein S works as a cofactor for protein C to inhibit clot formation.
<u>Antithrombin deficiency</u> occurs in about {{c1::1}} out of every {{c1::2000 to 5000}} people.
Antithrombin plays a key role in inhibiting factors IIa (thrombin) and Xa.
Tissue Factor Pathway Inhibitor (TFPI) acts as an inhibitor of Factor {{c1::Xa}}.
TFPI (Tissue Factor Pathway Inhibitor) helps regulate the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.
Thrombomodulin is a protein on the surface of {{c1::endothelial}} cells that binds thrombin, which then activates {{c2::protein C}}.
Antithrombin III is a major physiological inhibitor of coagulation, controlling thrombin activity and reducing clot formation.
{{c1::Hemostasis}} involves the formation of a blood clot at the site of vascular injury, preventing further bleeding.
{{c1::Thrombosis}} refers to the formation of a blood clot inside a blood vessel, which can lead to complications such as embolism.
Most cases of <u>arterial thrombosis</u> are caused by {{c1::atherosclerosis}}.
Atherosclerosis damages the artery walls, making them prone to clot formation.
{{c1::Thrombophilia}} is a condition characterized by a <u>tendency to form blood clots</u>.
It can be hereditary or acquired, leading to a hypercoagulable state.
Arterial thrombi in thrombophilia usually occur in areas of {{c1::atherosclerotic plaques}}.
Venous thrombi in thrombophilia can result in {{c1::deep vein thrombosis (DVT)}} or {{c2::pulmonary embolism}}.
{{c2::Factor V Leiden}} is the most common inherited form of {{c1::thrombophilia}}.
It involves a single point mutation in the factor V gene, increasing the risk of clot formation.
In the U.S., about {{c1::1 in 20::Ratio}} Caucasians and {{c1::1 in 100::Ratio}} African-Americans have Factor V Leiden.
This mutation causes a higher risk of thrombosis, especially in women using hormonal birth control.
People with {{c1::Factor V Leiden}} have a tendency to <u>clot faster</u> than normal.
The mutation makes factor V resistant to inactivation by activated protein C (aPC), increasing thrombotic risk.
The mutation in Factor V Leiden makes Factor V resistant to inactivation by {{c1::activated protein C (aPC)}}, increasing thrombotic risk.
Probable reasons for Deep Vein Thrombosis include sitting for long periods, pregnancy, obesity, and {{c1::Protein S}} / {{c1::Protein C}} deficiency.
Other factors include smoking, birth control pills, and hormone replacement therapy, which increase clot risk.
{{c1::Blood thinners}} are the most common medications used to treat <u>DVT</u>.
Other treatment options include oral anticoagulants and compression stockings to prevent clot growth and recurrence.
Treatment options for Pulmonary Embolisms involve the use of anticoagulants such as {{c1::warfarin}}, {{c1::heparin}}, {{c1::rivaroxaban}}, and {{c1::dabigatran}}.
Predisposing conditions for Pulmonary Embolisms include immobilization, smoking, and {{c1::Protein S}} / {{c1::Protein C}} deficiency.
<u>Heparin</u> binds to Factor {{c1::IXa}} and {{c1::Xa}} and is monitored with {{c2::aPTT}}.
Monitored with aPTT because Factor IX is part of the intrinsic pathway
Warfarin is a {{c3::Vitamin K Antagonist}} that inhibits Factor {{c2::IIa (Thrombin)}}, {{c2::VIIa}}, {{c2::IXa}}, and {{c2::Xa}}. It is monitored using {{c1::PT}}.
Monitored with PT because it affects Factor VII which is part to of the extrinsic pathway
Patients are advised to avoid vitamin K-rich foods like spinach and Swiss chard when on {{c1::warfarin}}.
Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant that inhibits vitamin K-dependent factors.
<u>Anti-platelet agents</u> like {{c1::aspirin}} and {{c1::plavix}} are used to prevent platelet aggregation.
The most dangerous aspect of <u>hemophilia</u> is {{c1::internal bleeding}}.
Internal bleeding in the brain, joints, muscles, and tissues can be fatal.
<u>Von Willebrand disease (VWD)</u> is caused by missing or defective {{c1::von Willebrand factor (VWF)}}.
VWF is a clotting protein that helps bind Factor VIII and platelets to form a platelet plug during clotting.
People with <u>VWD</u> experience symptoms like {{c1::frequent nosebleeds}}, {{c1::easy bruising}}, and {{c1::excessive bleeding}} during procedures.
Women with VWD may also experience heavy menstrual bleeding and hemorrhaging after childbirth.
Type {{c3::1}} Von Willebrand disease is characterized by a {{c1::mild reduction}} in von Willebrand factor and is usually inherited as an {{c2::autosomal dominant::Inheritance Pattern}} trait.
Type 1 is the most common form of Von Willebrand disease.
Type {{c3::2}} Von Willebrand disease involves the loss of {{c1::high-molecular-weight multimers}} and is generally inherited as an {{c2::autosomal dominant::Inheritance Pattern}} trait.
This type affects the structure and function of von Willebrand factor.
Type {{c3::3}} Von Willebrand disease is characterized by a {{c1::severe reduction}} in von Willebrand factor and is usually inherited as an {{c2::autosomal recessive::Inheritance Pattern}} trait.
It is the <u>rarest</u> and <u>most severe</u> form of Von Willebrand disease, leading to severe bleeding symptoms.
Protein S acts as a cofactor of {{c1::protein C}} and {{c1::TFPI}}, inhibiting Factor {{c2::IXa}} to form the Xase complex, which reduces thrombin formation.
Protein S enhances the anticoagulant effects of protein C and TFPI, facilitating the degradation of factors Va and VIIIa.
A {{c1::nucleoside}} consists of a nitrogenous base and a sugar.
Nucleosides are simpler than nucleotides, lacking phosphate groups.
A {{c1::nucleotide}} is composed of a nitrogenous base, a sugar, and one or more phosphate groups.
Nucleotides are building blocks of DNA and RNA, differing from nucleosides by the presence of phosphate groups.
Both DNA and RNA contain the purine bases {{c1::adenine}} and {{c1::guanine}}.
Thymine and uracil are structurally similar but differ in methylation; uracil replaces thymine in RNA.
{{c1::Purines}} have a double-ring structure, while {{c1::pyrimidines}} have a single-ring structure.
Unusual bases may protect DNA or RNA from degradation by {{c1::nucleases}}.
This protection is crucial for the stability and <u>longevity</u> of certain nucleic acids.
Stabilization is important in maintaining the functional conformation of RNA molecules.
These chemical modifications change the properties of the bases, often altering their function.
Deoxyribose lacks an {{c1::oxygen}} atom on carbon {{c1::2'}} of the sugar ring.
Ribose has a {{c1::hydroxyl}} group on carbon {{c1::2'}} of the sugar ring.
The presence of the hydroxyl group makes RNA more reactive and less stable than DNA.
The addition of a {{c1::pentose sugar}} to a base produces a nucleoside.
Nucleosides consist of a nitrogenous base and a sugar, but <u>lack phosphate groups</u>.
If the sugar in a nucleoside is ribose, a {{c1::ribonucleoside}} is produced.
Ribonucleosides are found in RNA and include bases like adenosine and cytidine.
If the sugar in a nucleoside is 2-deoxyribose, a {{c1::deoxyribonucleoside}} is produced.
Deoxyribonucleosides are found in DNA and include bases like deoxyadenosine and thymidine.
The ribonucleoside of A is {{c1::adenosine}}, G is {{c1::guanosine}}, C is {{c1::cytidine}}, and U is {{c1::uridine}}.
The deoxyribonucleoside of A is {{c1::deoxyadenosine}}, G is {{c1::deoxyguanosine}}, C is {{c1::deoxycytidine}}, and T is {{c1::thymidine}}.
The first phosphate group in a nucleotide attaches to the {{c1::5'-OH}} of the pentose via an {{c1::ester linkage}}.
This forms a nucleoside-5'-phosphate, also referred to as a 5'-nucleotide.
When a nucleotide contains the sugar ribose, it is referred to as a {{c1::5'-ribonucleotide}}.
Ribonucleotides are the primary building blocks of RNA.
When a nucleotide contains the sugar deoxyribose, it is known as a {{c1::5'-deoxyribonucleotide}}.
Deoxyribonucleotides are the primary building blocks of DNA.
Nucleotides are classified based on the number of attached {{c1::phosphate}} groups.
The purine ring is primarily synthesized in the {{c1::liver::Organ}}.
Atoms in the purine ring are contributed by amino acids such as {{c1::aspartate}}, {{c1::glycine}}, and {{c1::glutamine}}.
The formation of the purine ring involves reactions that add carbon and nitrogen atoms to a preformed {{c1::ribose 5-phosphate}}.
Ribose 5-phosphate serves as the backbone for purine construction.
The synthesis of {{c1::5-phosphoribosyl-1-pyrophosphate (PRPP)}} is the first step in purine nucleotide synthesis.
The enzyme {{c1::PRPP synthetase}} catalyzes the formation of {{c2::PRPP}} from {{c2::ribose 5-phosphate}}.
This reaction requires ATP and is activated by inorganic phosphate (Pi).
AMP and GMP are products of de novo synthesis, so they inhibit PRPP Synthetase via feedback inhibition.
The rate-limiting step of purine synthesis is catalyzed by {{c1::PRPP Synthetase}}.
In the synthesis of 5'-phosphoribosylamine, the {{c1::amide group of glutamine}} replaces the pyrophosphate group attached to carbon 1 of PRPP.
The enzyme {{c1::glutamine pyrophosphate amidotransferase}} catalyzes the formation of {{c2::5'-phosphoribosylamine}} from {{c2::PRPP}}.
Glutamine pyrophosphate amidotransferase is inhibited by {{c1::AMP}} and {{c1::GMP}}
These are the end products of the purine synthesis pathway.
The rate of 5'-phosphoribosylamine synthesis is increased by increased cellular concentration of {{c1::PRPP}}.
PRPP concentration is typically low, so small changes significantly affect the reaction rate.
The synthesis of {{c2::inosine monophosphate (IMP)}} requires {{c1::ATP}} and {{c1::N10-formyltetrahydrfolate}}.

ATP is essential for the energy-intensive steps in IMP synthesis.

N¹⁰-formyltetrahydrofolate contributes formyl groups necessary for purine ring construction.
In IMP synthesis, the base of IMP is {{c1::hypoxanthine}}.
Hypoxanthine is the precursor base for adenine and guanine in purine nucleotides.
{{c1::Sulfonamides::Drug Class}} block the bacterial enzyme {{c2::dihydropteroate synthetase}}, preventing synthesis of {{c3::dihydrofolic acid}}.
This blockage inhibits folate synthesis in bacteria, affecting their DNA replication.
{{c1::Trimethoprim::Drug}} blocks {{c2::dihydrofolate reductase::Enzyme}} in bacteria, preventing conversion of dihydrofolic acid to {{c3::tetrahydrofolic acid (THF)}}.
Trimethoprim targets bacterial THF synthesis specifically, making it an effective antibacterial drug.
In humans, the anticancer drug {{c1::methotrexate}} blocks the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase.
This inhibition prevents the formation of tetrahydrofolate (THF), crucial for DNA synthesis.
{{c1::p-Aminobenzoic acid (PABA)::Substrate}} is required by bacteria to synthesize dihydrofolic acid, but it is not required in humans.
This difference allows drugs like sulfonamides to target bacterial cells specifically without affecting human cells.
{{c1::Adenylosuccinate synthetase::Enzyme}} catalyzes the {{c3::GTP}}-dependent conversion of {{c2::IMP}} and {{c2::aspartic acid}} to {{c3::adenylosuccinate}}.
{{c1::IMP dehydrogenase::Enzyme}} catalyzes the {{c2::NAD⁺}}-dependent oxidation of {{c3::IMP}} to {{c3::xanthosine monophosphate (XMP)}}.
{{c1::GMP synthetase::Enzyme}} catalyzes the amination of {{c2::xanthosine monophosphate (XMP)}} to form {{c2::GMP}}.
If both {{c1::GMP}} and {{c1::AMP}} levels are adequate, de novo purine synthesis is turned off at the {{c2::amido transferase}} step.
Mycophenolic acid is an inhibitor of {{c1::IMP dehydrogenase}}, depriving rapidly proliferating T and B cells of nucleotides.
This drug is used to prevent organ graft rejection by suppressing immune cell proliferation.
Nucleoside diphosphate and triphosphates are interconverted by {{c1::nucleoside diphosphate kinase::Enzyme}}
This enzyme allows the cell to maintain balanced levels of diphosphate and triphosphate nucleotides.
Nucleoside diphosphates are synthesized from nucleoside monophosphates by {{c1::base-specific nucleoside monophosphate kinases::Enzyme}}.
These kinases do not distinguish between ribose and deoxyribose in the substrate.
{{c1::Adenylate kinase::Enzyme}} catalyzes the interconversion of {{c2::AMP}} and {{c2::ATP}} to {{c2::2 ADP}}.
This enzyme is specific for adenine nucleotides and helps maintain ATP levels in cells.
The salvage pathway for purines primarily uses the enzyme {{c1::hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT)}} to convert {{c2::hypoxanthine}} and {{c2::guanine}} into nucleotides.
HGPRT helps form IMP from hypoxanthine and GMP from guanine using PRPP.
APRT uses PRPP as a ribose-5-phosphate donor to form AMP.
Purine nucleotides synthesized in the liver are degraded, and free bases are salvaged by {{c1::peripheral tissues}}.
This process reduces the need for energy-intensive de novo synthesis outside the liver.
Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme {{c1::hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT)}}.
In Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, the inability to salvage {{c2::hypoxanthine}} and {{c2::guanine}} results in increased levels of {{c1::PRPP}} and decreased levels of {{c1::IMP}} and {{c1::GMP}}.
Increased PRPP and decreased IMP/GMP lead to upregulated de novo purine synthesis.
Increased {{c2::de novo purine}} synthesis in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome results in excess production of {{c1::uric acid}}, the end product of purine degradation.
High levels of uric acid lead to hyperuricemia
The major symptoms of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome include {{c1::hyperuricemia}}, {{c1::motor dysfunction}}, and {{c1::self-mutilating behavior (biting of lips and fingers)}}.
Hyperuricemia can lead to gout-like symptoms and neurological issues in patients.
In Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, high levels of PRPP and low levels of GMP enhance de novo purine synthesis by activating {{c3::glutamine pyrophosphate amidotransferase::Enzyme}}.
Deoxyribonucleotides are synthesized from {{c1::ribonucleotide diphosphates}} by the enzyme {{c1::ribonucleotide reductase}}.
This conversion occurs during the S-phase of the cell cycle and is essential for DNA replication.
{{c1::Ribonucleotide reductase::Enzyme}} acts on both pyrimidine and purine ribonucleotides to produce deoxyribonucleotides.
This enzyme is crucial for maintaining a balanced supply of deoxyribonucleotides for DNA synthesis.
Ribonucleotide reductase takes {{c1::two}} protons from thioredoxin and {{c1::oxygen}} from ribonucleoside diphosphate, releasing them as {{c1::H₂O}}.
This process converts ribose to deoxyribose in the nucleotide.
Thioredoxin is oxidized in the ribonucleotide reductase reaction and is regenerated by {{c1::thioredoxin reductase}} using {{c2::NADPH}}.
Thioredoxin reductase restores thioredoxin to its reduced form, enabling continuous deoxyribonucleotide production.
Binding of {{c1::dATP}} at the activity sites of ribonucleotide reductase inhibits the reduction of all ribonucleotides.
High dATP levels signal sufficient deoxyribonucleotides, halting further production to maintain balance.
{{c1::ATP}} activates ribonucleotide reductase by binding to the activity sites, promoting deoxyribonucleotide synthesis.
ATP binding increases enzyme activity, ensuring adequate dNTPs for DNA synthesis.
When {{c1::dATP}} or {{c1::ATP}} binds to the substrate specificity site, ribonucleotide reductase accepts {{c2::UDP}} and {{c2::CDP}} into the catalytic site.
This regulation allows the enzyme to selectively reduce specific ribonucleotides based on cellular needs.
Binding of {{c1::dGTP}} at the substrate specificity site allows {{c2::ADP}} into the catalytic site of ribonucleotide reductase.
This selective binding controls the reduction of ADP, balancing purine and pyrimidine dNTPs.
By inhibiting deoxyribonucleotide synthesis, hydroxyurea helps limit DNA synthesis in rapidly dividing cancer cells.
Recombinant {{c1::urate oxidase::Enzyme}} is used in humans to catalyze the conversion of {{c2::uric acid}} to {{c2::allantoin}}, helping patients with hyperuricemia.
Urate oxidase is not naturally present in humans, but it is used therapeutically to manage high uric acid levels.
In most mammals, uric acid is further oxidized to {{c1::allantoin}}; however, humans lack this pathway.

Small Intestine Nucleic Acid Degradation:

{{c1::Ribonucleases::Enzyme}} and {{c1::deoxyribonucleases::Enzyme}}, secreted by the {{c2::pancreas}}, hydrolyze dietary RNA and DNA to {{c3::oligonucleotides}}.
These enzymes initiate the breakdown of nucleic acids in the small intestine.

Small Intestine Nucleic Acid Degradation:

Pancreatic {{c1::phosphodiesterases::Enzyme}} further hydrolyze oligonucleotides to produce a mixture of {{c2::3'-}} and {{c2::5'-mononucleotides}}.

Small Intestine Nucleic Acid Degradation:

At the intestinal mucosal surface, {{c1::nucleotidases::Enzyme}} remove phosphate groups, releasing {{c2::nucleosides}}.

Small Intestine Nucleic Acid Degradation:

Nucleosides are taken into enterocytes and degraded by {{c1::nucleoside phosphorylases::Enzyme}} to produce {{c2::free bases}} and {{c2::(deoxy) ribose 1-phosphate}}.
AMP deaminase converts {{c1::AMP}} to {{c1::IMP}} in the purine degradation pathway.
This conversion initiates the breakdown of AMP to uric acid.
Adenosine deaminase converts {{c1::adenosine}} to {{c1::inosine}}, a crucial step in purine degradation.
Deficiency in this enzyme leads to severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).
Purine nucleoside phosphorylase converts {{c1::inosine}} to {{c1::hypoxanthine}} and {{c2::guanosine}} to {{c2::guanine}}.
Deficiency in this enzyme affects T cell development and leads to immunodeficiency.
Allopurinol inhibits {{c1::xanthine oxidase}}, reducing uric acid production and managing hyperuricemia in gout.
Allopurinol decreases the risk of urate crystal formation in joints and kidneys.
Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency is an {{c1::autosomal-recessive::Inheritance Pattern}} disorder causing severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).
SCID involves T-cell, B-cell, and natural killer-cell depletion, leading to severe immunodeficiency.
Untreated children with ADA deficiency usually die before age 2 due to {{c1::overwhelming infection}}.
Treatment options include bone marrow transplant (BMT), enzyme replacement therapy (ERT), and gene therapy.
Purine nucleoside phosphorylase (PNP) deficiency is a rare {{c1::autosomal-recessive::Inheritance Pattern}} disorder affecting {{c2::T-cell::Cell Type}} development.
PNP deficiency is less severe than ADA deficiency but still impacts immune function.
These symptoms are due to impaired T-cell function, affecting immune response and development.
Gout is characterized by high levels of {{c1::uric acid}} in the blood, a condition known as hyperuricemia.
Hyperuricemia leads to the <u>deposition of urate crystals</u> in the joints and soft tissues.
In gout, hyperuricemia leads to the deposition of {{c1::monosodium urate crystals (Tophi)}} in joints, causing acute inflammation.
This inflammation can progress to chronic gouty arthritis if untreated.
Hyperuricemia can be caused by either the {{c1::underexcretion}} or {{c1::overproduction}} of uric acid.
Environmental factors contributing to underexcretion of uric acid include thiazide diuretics and lead exposure.
{{c1::Thiazide diuretics::Drug}} can cause uric acid retention by competing with uric acid for transport via organic anion transporter 1 (OAT1).
This competition results in higher levels of uric acid in the blood.
Adenosine deaminase (ADA) is highly expressed in {{c1::lymphocytes::Cell Type}} and is crucial for purine metabolism.
ADA is expressed in various tissues but is especially important in immune cells.
ADA deficiency results in the accumulation of {{c1::adenosine}}, which is converted into {{c2::dATP}}.
Elevated dATP inhibits DNA synthesis by affecting deoxynucleotide production.
{{c1::Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II (CPS II)::Enzyme}} is responsible for synthesizing carbamoyl phosphate in pyrimidine synthesis.
CPS II uses the γ-amide group of glutamine as the nitrogen source and operates in the cytosol.
CPS II is found in the {{c1::cytosol}}, while CPS I is found in the {{c1::mitochondria}}.
Dihydroorotate is oxidized to orotate by dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, which is located in the {{c1::mitochondria}}.
This step marks the transition from cytosolic to mitochondrial enzyme activity in pyrimidine synthesis.
{{c1::UMP synthase::Enzyme}} has two catalytic domains: {{c2::orotate phosphoribosyltransferase}} and {{c2::OMP decarboxylase}}.
Low activity of UMP synthase results in {{c1::orotic aciduria}}, leading to poor {{c2::growth}}, {{c2::megaloblastic anemia}}, and elevated {{c2::orotate}} in the urine.
Orotic aciduria is treated with uridine supplementation, which improves anemia and reduces orotate excretion.
In mammalian cells, the carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II  domain of the CAD complex is inhibited by {{c1::UTP}} and activated by {{c1::PRPP}}.
This regulatory mechanism balances pyrimidine synthesis according to cellular nucleotide levels.
In prokaryotic cells, aspartate transcarbamoylase is inhibited by {{c1::CTP}} and is the {{c2::regulated step}} in pyrimidine synthesis.
This <u>feedback inhibition</u> controls pyrimidine levels in prokaryotes.
{{c1::UMP}} is phosphorylated to form UDP, which is further phosphorylated to produce UTP.
{{c1::CTP synthetase::Enzyme}} converts {{c2::UTP}} to {{c2::CTP}} by adding an amino group from {{c3::glutamine}}.
This step is essential for creating cytidine triphosphate (CTP), used in RNA synthesis.
{{c1::Thymidylate synthase::Enzyme}} catalyzes the conversion of dUMP to dTMP, using THF as a methyl donor.
This enzyme is essential for producing thymidine nucleotides for DNA synthesis.
In the conversion of dUMP to dTMP, THF provides a {{c1::one::#}}-carbon unit and {{c1::two::#}} hydrogen atoms, becoming oxidized to DHF.
This reaction is unique in that THF is both a carbon and hydrogen donor.
5-Fluorouracil is metabolically converted to {{c1::5-FdUMP}}, which {{c1::irreversibly}} binds to {{c2::thymidylate synthase}}, acting as a suicide substrate.
This mechanism inhibits thymidine synthesis, preventing DNA replication and is used as an anticancer drug.
Methotrexate inhibits {{c1::dihydrofolate reductase::Enzyme}}, blocking the regeneration of THF from DHF.
By inhibiting DHF reductase, methotrexate prevents dTMP synthesis and is also used as an anticancer drug.
